You lay before us a beautiful green world, full of freedoms and opportunities... You give us ownership of our lives for the first time... and you ask no more of us than you do of yourselves: to live by the rules... rules that aren't made to keep one people subordinate to another, but rules that exist to preserve equality.  You aspire to very high ideals here.

completion: Ah!  You sly rogue, I see that will influence you.

prompt: This is a very good inn.  Shall we stop for dinner?
completion: This may be a very good inn for Germany, but it would not pass in old Ireland.  Corbach is only a league off, let us push on for Corbach.

prompt: O'Grady.
completion: Oh, yes, of course, Ambassador O'Grady...

prompt: My companion treated me with great civility, and asked me a thousand questions about England, which I answered as best I might.  But this best, I am bound to say, was bad enough.  I knew nothing about England, and I invented a thousand stories which I told him; described the king and the ministers to him, said the British ambassador in Berlin was my uncle, and promised my acquaintance a letter of recommendation to him.
completion: What is your uncle's name?

prompt: The coward!
completion: He has paid off your uncle's mortgage.  He gave Dorothy a coach- and-six.  That coward of a fellow has been making of your uncle's family.  Faith, the business was well done.  Your cousins, Michael and Harry, never let him out of their sight, though he was for deserting to England, until the marriage was completed, and the happy couple off on their road to Dublin.  Are you in want of cash, my boy?  You may draw upon me, for I got a couple of hundred out of Master Best for my share and, while they last, you shall never want.

prompt: Mrs. John Best!  Was there another Mr. John Best?!
completion: No, the very same one, my boy.  He recovered from his wound.  The ball you hit him with was not likely to hurt him.  It was only made of tow. Do you think the Dugans would let you kill fifteen hundred a-year out of the family?  The plan of the duel was all arranged in order to get you out of the way, for the cowardly Englishman could never be brought to marry from fear of you.  But hit him you certainly did, Roderick, and with a fine thick plugget of tow, and the fellow was so frightened that he was an hour in coming to. We told your mother the story afterwards, and a pretty scene she made.

prompt: Good heavens!  Whatever?  Has she died of grief?
completion: She took on so at your going away that she was obliged to console herself with a husband.  She is now Mrs. John Best.

prompt: Is Miss Dugan well?
completion: There's only six Miss Dugans now... poor Dorothy.

prompt: We must write to her today, and you can tell her that you are safe and married to "Brown Bess."
completion: I see you are thinking of a certain young lady at Duganstown.

prompt: I had news of you in Dublin.  Faith, you've begun early, like your father's son, but I think you could not do better than as you have done. But why did you not write home to your poor mother?  She has sent half-a-dozen letters to you in Dublin.
completion: I suppose she addressed them to me in my real name, by which I never thought to ask for them at the post office.

prompt: A man of honor dies, but never apologizes.  I'll see the captain hanged before I apologize.
completion: Grogan gave me a wink of recognition, but offered no public token of acquaintance and it was not until two days afterwards that he called me into his quarters, and then, shaking hands with me cordially, gave me news which I wanted, of my family.

prompt: It must have been some other gate.
completion: Look here, Roderick, my boy; this is silly business.  The girl will marry Best, mark my words; and as sure as she does, you'll forget her.  You are but a boy.  Best is willing to consider you as such.  Dublin's a fine place, and if you have a mind to take a ride thither and see the town for a month, here are twenty guineas at your service.  Make Best an apology, and be off.

prompt: But swords are today impossible; Captain Best is -- is lame.  He knocked his knee against the swinging park gate last night, as he was riding home, and can scarce move it now.
completion: Not against Castle Dugan gate, that has been off the hinges these ten years.

prompt: Oh, it's with pistols we fight.  You are no match for Best with the sword.
completion: I'll match any man with the sword.

prompt: I am Harry James' son, and will act as becomes my name and quality.
completion: I hope to spoil this sport, and trust to see this sword of mine in that big bully's body.

prompt: It was with this sword that my late father, Harry James, God rest his soul, met Sir Huddelstone Fuddelstone, the Hampshire baronet, and was fatally run through the neck.  He was quite in the wrong, having insulted Lady Fuddelstone, when in liquor, at the Brentford Assembly.  But, like a gentleman, he scorned to apologize.
completion: And now you risk the same fate.  If you are killed, your mother is all alone in the world.

prompt: Your cousins go out with him.
completion: That's a very handsome sword you have there.

prompt: The meeting is arranged.  Captain Best is waiting for you now.
completion: My mare is saddled and ready; who's the captain's second?

prompt: In faith, I believe you are not; for a lad I never saw more game in my life.  Give me a kiss, my dear boy. You're after my own soul.  As long as Jack Grogan lives, you shall never want a friend or a second.
completion: Have you taken my message to him?

prompt: Well, if it must be, it must.  For a young fellow, you are the most bloodthirsty I ever saw.  No officer, bearing His Majesty's commission, can receive a glass of wine on his nose, without resenting it -- fight you must, and Best is a huge, strong fellow.
completion: He'll give the better mark.  I am not afraid of him.

prompt: And this is the return you make for his kindness!  Didn't he harbor you in his house when your father died, and hasn't he given you and your mother, rent-free, your fine house of Jamesville yonder?
completion: Mark this, come what will of it, I swear I will fight the man who pretends to the hand of Dorothy Dugan.  I'll follow him if it's into the church, and meet him there. I'll have his blood, or he shall have mine.  Will you take my message to him, and arrange the meeting?

prompt: A pretty day's work of it you have made, Master Roderick.  Knowing your uncle to be distressed for money, and try and break off a match which will bring fifteen hundred a-year into the family?  Best has promised to pay off the four thousand pounds which is bothering your uncle so. He takes a girl without a penny -- a girl that has been flinging herself at the head of every man in these parts these ten years past, and missing them all, and a boy who ought to be attached to your uncle as to your father.
completion: And so I am.

prompt: Dorothy might love me or not, as she likes, but Best will have to fight me before he marries her!
completion: Faith, I think you are a lad that's likely to keep your word.

prompt: This is a pretty way to recommend yourself to the family.
completion: The man that marries Dorothy Dugan must first kill me -- do you mind that?

prompt: Repeat the words again, and I run you through the body.
completion: Tut, tut!  I can play at fencing as well as you, Mr. Roderick James. Ah!  You change color, do you?  Your secret is known, is it?  You come like a viper into the bosom of innocent families; you represent yourself as the heir to my friends the O'Higgins of Castle O'Higgins; I introduce you to the nobility and gentry of this methropolis; I take you to my tradesmen, who give you credit.  I accept your note for near two hundred pounds, and what do I find?  A fraud.

prompt: Sirrah!  Sirrah, I am as good a gentleman as any in Ireland!
completion: You're an impostor, young man, a schemer, a deceiver!

prompt: I have heard of them.
completion: Whom have I been harboring in my house?  Who are you, sirrah?

prompt: Oh, I am thinking of the O'Higgins of Redmondstown.  General O'Higgins was a close friend of my wife's dear father, Colonel Granby Somerset.
completion: Ah -- I see.  No, I'm afraid mine are the O'Higgins of Watertown.

prompt: Mr. O'Higgins, we are in your debt, and rest assured, sir, you have friends in this house whenever you are in Dublin.  Mister O'Higgins, I wonder if I know your good father?
completion: Which O'Higgins do you know?  For I have never heard your name mentioned in my family.

prompt: Mr. O'Higgins, I cannot say how grateful I am for your timely assistance to my wife.
completion: I am only sorry that I was unable to prevent the villain from carrying off all her ladyship's money and pearls.

prompt: Your Grace, if I am so tame as to take this, then I must give up an honorable and lucrative occupation.
completion: I have said all there is to be said. I am at your disposal for whatever purposes you wish.  Good night.

prompt: Your Grace owes me seventy thousand frederics, which I have honorably won.
completion: Chevalier, if you will have your money now, you must fight for it. If you will be patient, maybe I will pay you something another time.

prompt: I deny your Grace's accusations, and beg you to say how you have been cheated?
completion: I don't know.

prompt: The gentleman has nothing contraband.
completion: Chevalier, though I cannot say how, I believe you have cheated me.

prompt: As you please.
completion: I have no luggage.

prompt: Your honor must lower his voice.
completion: All Europe shall hear of this!

prompt: I have orders to gag your honor if you cry out, and to give you this purse containing ten thousand frederics if you do not.
completion: Ten thousand?  But the scoundrel owes me seventy thousand.

prompt: You are going to drive to the frontier.
completion: It is shameful -- infamous!  I insist upon being put down at the Austrian ambassador's house.

prompt: I will let down the steps for your honor.
completion: Good gracious!  What is this?

prompt: Perfectly certain, because I shall make him tremble.
completion: Where is my rascal, Lazlo?

prompt: I risk nothing, for I am certain to kill him.
completion: Certain?

prompt: It is distasteful to kill a scoundrel -- that should be work for a hangman.
completion: To risk one's life against such people is an imposition.

prompt: When the Duke of Courland brought fourteen lackeys each with bags of florins, and challenged our bank to play against the sealed bags, what did we ask?
completion: Sir, we have but eighty thousand florins in bank, or two hundred thousand at three months; if your highness' bags do not contain more than eight thousand, we will meet you.

prompt: Gentlemen, I wish you a good day. Will you please go to the house from whence we set out this morning, and tell my man there to send my baggage on to Three Kings at Dresden?
completion: Then ordering fresh horses, the Chevalier set off on his journey for that capital.  I need not tell you that I was the Chevalier.

prompt: Make your mind easy, you shall not be left behind, I warrant you.  Do take a last look at your barracks, make your mind easy, say a farewell to your friends in Berlin.  The dear souls, how they will weep when they hear you are out of the country, and, out of it, you shall go.
completion: But how, sir?

prompt: I have faced that problem before.
completion: But, if they send you away, then what is to become of me?

prompt: Have no fear.  It will come out well for me.
completion: I believe they will deport you.

prompt: We will practice in the mornings, my boy, and I'll put you up to a thing or two worth knowing.
completion: But they will prevent a meeting at whatever the cost.

prompt: The cards are now my only livelihood.  Sometimes I am in luck, and then I lay out my money in these trinkets you see.  It's property, look you, and the only way I have found of keeping a little about me. When the luck goes against me, why, my dear, my diamonds go to the pawnbrokers and I wear paste.  Do you understand the cards?
completion: I can play as soldiers do, but have no great skill.

prompt: And I think he was as much affected as I was at thus finding one of his kindred; for he, too, was an exile from home, and a friendly voice, a look, brought the old country back to his memory again, and the old days of his boyhood.
completion: I'd give five years of my life to see the old country again, the greenfields, and the river, and the old round tower, and the burying place.

prompt: Who else can give me information about you?
completion: Only the agency of servants.

prompt: For whom else have you worked?
completion: No one, sir.  Before that I served in the army but had to leave due to weakness of the loins.

prompt: You come highly recommended by Herr Seebach.
completion: Herr Seebach was a very kind employer.

prompt: Your name is Lazlo Zilagyi?
completion: Yes, sir.

prompt: You are the young man who M. de Seebach recommended?
completion: Yes, sir.  Here is my letter.

prompt: That is a trifle strong.
completion: Take to your legs, low Irish dog.

prompt: On the instant.  Everyone must yield to such a nobleman as you.
completion: Very well; but a man who yields takes to his legs.

prompt: Very well!  Now that I know it, I will no longer love her.
completion: Then you yield to me.

prompt: Certainly, monseigneur, does not Your Excellency consider her worthy of love?
completion: Perfectly so; and what is more, I will tell you that I love her, and that I am not of a humor to put up with rivals.

prompt: Old fool!
completion: I entered here, monsieur, at a bad moment for you; it seems that you love this lady.

prompt: Roderick, you know well enough that I have never loved but you!  Was I ever so wretched that a kind word from you did not make me happy? Ever so angry, but the least offer of good-will on your part did not bring me to your side?  Did I not give a sufficient proof of my affection for you in bestowing one of the finest fortunes of England upon you?  Have I repined or rebuked you for the way you have wasted it? No, I loved you too much and too fondly; I have always loved you. From the first moment I saw you, I saw your bad qualities, and trembled at your violence; but I could not help loving you.  I married you, though I knew I was sealing my own fate in doing so, and in spite of reason and duty.  What sacrifice do you want from me?  I am ready to make any, so you will but love me, or, if not, that at least, you will gently us me.
completion: Lady Cosgrove, you are an old fool.

prompt: We then spent an hour in the most eloquent silence except that, from time to time, her ladyship cried out:  "Oh, my God.  Is it true -- I am not dreaming?"
completion: My Lady Cosgrove's relationship with me was a singular one.  Her life was passed in a series of crack-brained sort of alternation between love and hatred for me.  We would quarrel for a fortnight, then we should be friends for a month together sometimes.  One day, I was joking her, and asking her whether she would take the water again, whether she had found another lover, and so forth.  She suddenly burst out into tears, and, after a while, said to me:

prompt: Let me give a thousand kisses to that heavenly mouth which has told me that I am happy.
completion: As soon as I saw you loved me, I was pleased, and I gave you every opportunity to fall more in love with me, being certain that, for my part, I would never love you.  But after our first kiss, I found that I had no power over myself.  I did not know that one kiss could matter so much.

prompt: O, my dearest love.  Enough!  I beg you.  Stop believing in your experience.  You have never known love.  My very soul is leaving me! Catch it on your lips, and give me yours!
completion: Without you, my dearest, I might have died without ever knowing love. Inexpressible love!  God of nature! Bitterness than which nothing is sweeter, sweetness than which nothing is more bitter.  Divine monster which can only be defined by paradoxes.

prompt: Sir William Cosgrove is a man who is dying, and yet I envy him more than any man in Christendom.  He enjoys a privilege of which I am deprived. He may take you in his arms whenever he pleases, and no veil keeps his senses, his eyes, his soul from enjoying your beauty.
completion: Shall I tell you something -- I believed what was called love came after the union -- and I was surprised when my husband, making me a woman, made me know it only by pain, unaccompanied by any pleasure. I saw that my imaginings had stood me in better stead.  And so we became only friends, seldom sleeping together and arousing no curiosity in each other, yet on good terms for a while, as whenever he wanted me, I was at his service, but since the offering was not seasoned with love, he found it tasteless, and seldom demanded it.

prompt: Let us give each other complete happiness, and let us be sure that as many times as we satisfy our desires, they will each time be born anew.
completion: My husband has convinced me of the contrary.

prompt: I know better than you do.  Love wants a more substantial fare, and if it is stubbornly withheld, it withers away.
completion: Our abstinence makes our love immortal.  If I loved you a quarter of an hour ago, now I should love you even more.  But I should love you less if you exhausted my joy by satisfying all my desires.

prompt: Will we always leave it at this?
completion: Always, my dear one, never any further.  Love is a child to be pacified with trifles.  A full diet can only kill it.

prompt: Poor man.  And, for that reason, you want to begin where people end?
completion: I ask only a payment on account today -- after that, you will find me undemanding, obedient and discreet.

prompt: You will do as you please.  It seems to me that such a matter can hardly be discussed until after people know each other.  Do you not agree?
completion: Yes -- but I am afraid of being deceived.

prompt: And if she does not choose to show you some kindness?
completion: Then I will respectfully take leave of her.

prompt: Be so good as to tell me with whom you think you are?
completion: With a woman who is completely charming, be she a princess or a woman of the lowest condition, and who, regardless of her rank, will show me some kindness, tonight.

prompt: Deceiving someone without knowing it is something new for me.  If I do not know it, I am innocent.
completion: But you deceive me nonetheless if I believe you, for it will not be in your power to love me when you love me no longer.

prompt: To love you until death.  To subscribe to all your commands.
completion: The amusing thing is that you deceive me without knowing, if it is true that you love me.

prompt: It is my only object.
completion: To make me wretched in two weeks.

prompt: By loving you, with no hope of possessing you.
completion: You want my heart?

prompt: I believe you, and I see I must hasten to leave, for otherwise I shall become the unhappiest of men.
completion: How so?

prompt: I agree; but God put us on earth to take that risk.
completion: A man may need to do that, and find it amusing; but a girl is bound by other laws.

prompt: That is true, but it seems to me impossible that you should be unhappy in love.
completion: It is only too possible.  Love requires a mutual harmony which is difficult, and it is even more difficult to make it last.

prompt: It is nonetheless a misfortune, and you will know it when you love.
completion: But if, when I love, I am unhappy, I will know that my empty heart was my good fortune.

prompt: Then you have never loved?  Your heart is empty.
completion: Your word "empty" makes me laugh. Is it fortunate, or unfortunate?  If it is fortunate, I congratulate myself.  If it is unfortunate, I do not care, for I am not aware of it.

prompt: What!  You have not met a man worthy of your attention?
completion: Many worthy of attention; but valuing is something more.  I could value only someone whom I loved.

prompt: Have you not a man whom you value?
completion: That man has, perhaps, not yet been born.

prompt: How can I believe that there is not a man who has inspired desires in you?
completion: Not one.

prompt: But, for a time... a passing fancy?
completion: Not even that.

prompt: Have you had one?
completion: Never.

prompt: Indeed, Miss Dorothy, I intend to have his blood as sure as my name's Roderick.
completion: No.

prompt: Jump twenty feet!  You wouldn't dare to do any such thing on Daisy. There's the captain's horse, Black George, I've heard say that Captain Bes --
completion: Monster!  Your father was a tailor, and you are always thinking of the shop.  But I'll have my revenge, I will!  Roddy, will you see me insulted?

prompt: What, with me on the pillion?  Would you kill poor me?
completion: Well, then, I'll tell you what I'd do.  I'd jump Daisy into the river, and swim you both across, where no enemy could follow us.

prompt: Suppose, now, Roderick, you, who are such a hero, was passing over the bridge and the enemy on the other side.
completion: I'd draw my sword, and cut my way through them.

prompt: If ever I meet him again, you shall see which is the best man of the two.  I'll fight him with sword or with pistol, captain as he is.
completion: But Captain Best is already known as a valiant soldier, and is famous as a man of fashion in London.  It is mighty well of you to fight farmers' boys, but to fight an Englishman is a very different matter.

prompt: But you refused me, Dorothy.
completion: Oh!  I can dance with you any day, and to dance with your own cousin at a ball as if you could find no other partner.  Besides, Roderick, Captain Best's a man, and you are only a boy, and you haven't a guinea in the world.

prompt: Were you obliged to dance five times with Captain Best, and then stroll out with him into the garden?
completion: I don't care a fig for Captain Best; he dances prettily to be sure, and is a pleasant rattle of a man.  He looks well in his regimentals, too; and if he chose to ask me to dance, how could I refuse him?

prompt: I hate Miss Clancy, you know I do! And I only danced with her because -- because -- the person with whom I intended to dance chose to be engaged the whole night.
completion: I had not been in the room five minutes before I was engaged for every single set.

prompt: Why are you shaking?
completion: With pleasure at finding the ribbon.

prompt: I feel the ribbon.
completion: Then you must get it.

prompt: Agreed.
completion: Do you see the gate at the end of the field?  The first to touch it will be the winner.

prompt: All right, five hundred guineas.
completion: I accept, but I insist on a wager. The loser must do whatever the winner pleases.

prompt: It is entirely up to you.  I want the best.
completion: Last month, the Duke of Suffolk spent no more.

prompt: Yes, for I wish to entertain splendidly.
completion: All the same, you must name an amount.

prompt: As much as possible.
completion: As much as possible?

prompt: Well, Mr. Cosgrove, I'll answer you point by point.  The King is exceedingly averse to make peers, as you know.  Your claim, as you call them, have been laid before him, and His Majesty's gracious reply was, that you were the most impudent man in his dominions, and merited a halter, rather than a coronet.  As for withdrawing your support from us, you are perfectly welcome to carry yourself whithersoever you please.  And, now, as I have a great deal of occupation, perhaps you will do me the favor to retire, or tell me if there is anything else in the world in which I can oblige you.
completion: I am at your service, Mr. Cosgrove. How much do you wish to spend?

prompt: Have you done, Mr. Cosgrove?
completion: Yes!

prompt: By name only.
completion: Well, sir, this nobleman is one of the gentlemen of His Majesty's closet, and one with whom our revered monarch is on terms of considerable intimacy.  I should say you would be wise to fix upon this nobleman your chief reliance for the advancement of your claim to the Viscounty which you propose to get.

prompt: And, to be sure, I did know someone who knew precisely how these things were done, and this was the distinguished solicitor and former Government Minister, Lord West, whose acquaintance I made, as I had so many others, at the gaming table.
completion: Do you happen to know Gustavus Adolphus, the thirteenth Earl of Crabs?

prompt: Then this must be done tomorrow.
completion: What is to be done?

prompt: The King has determined to send the Chevalier out of the country.
completion: When is he to go?

prompt: A meeting with the Prince of Turbingen is impossible.
completion: The Prince left him only that choice.

prompt: In so far as I can tell these things -- no.  I believe the Chevalier won the money fairly.
completion: Hmm-mmmm.

prompt: Yes, Minister, I am interested in any work in which I can be of service to Captain Galgenstein.
completion: Was he cheated?

prompt: You must be very cautious with regard to the company you should meet in Dublin, where rogues and adventurers of all countries abound. I hope you will do me the honor of accepting lodgings in my own house, where Captain O'Reilly will welcome with delight, my gallant young preserver.
completion: Does this assignment interest you?

prompt: That's very kind of you, Mr. O'Higgins.
completion: How different was her lively rattle to the vulgar wenches at Kilwangan assemblies.  In every sentence, she mentioned a lord or a person of quality.  To the lady's question about my birth and parentage, I replied that I was a young gentleman of large fortune, that I was going to Dublin for my studies, and that my mother allowed me five hundred per annum.

prompt: O'Higgins... Mohawk O'Higgins.
completion: As you have been robbed of your purse, may I have permission to lend your ladyship a couple of pieces to pay any expenses which you might incur before reaching your home?

prompt: I am riding to Dublin myself, and if your ladyship will allow me the honor of riding with you, I shall do my best to protect you from further mishap.
completion: But I shouldn't like to put you to such trouble, Mister...?

prompt: Everything -- my purse, containing upwards of a hundred guineas, my jewels, my snuff-boxes, watches. And all because this blundering coward fell to his knees...
completion: That fool didn't know what was the meaning of a hundred-pound bill, which was in the pocket-book that the fellow took from me.

prompt: Oh, I am grateful to you, sir.  I am the wife of Captain O'Reilly hastening to join him at Dublin.  My chair was stopped by a highwayman; this great oaf of a servant-man fell down on his knees, armed as he was, and though there were thirty people in the next field, working, when the ruffian attacked, not one of them would help but, on the contrary, wished him "good luck."
completion: Be off to your work, you pack of rascals, or you will have a good taste of my thong.  Have you lost much?

prompt: When I asked them in what form they would accept her ladyship's assurances, they said that they were only prepared to accept them if her ladyship confirms her written consent by word of mouth, in their presence, at their counting-house in Birchin Lane, London.  I requested they come here, and save her ladyship and yourself the inconvenience of the trip to London, but they declined, saying that they did not wish to incur the risk of a visit to Castle Hackton to negotiate, as they were aware of how other respectable parties, such as Messrs. Sharp and Salomon had been treated here.
completion: What has happened, madam, to annoy your ladyship?

prompt: Mister Bracegirdle said to me that he had heard her ladyship lives in some fear of her life, and meditated a separation, in which case, she might later repudiate any documents signed by herself while in durance, and subject them, at any rate, to a doubtful and expensive litigation. They were quite insistent on this point, and said they must have absolute assurance of her ladyship's perfect freewill in the transaction before they would advance a shilling of their capital.
completion: I see.

prompt: May I be quite frank with you?
completion: Yes, of course.

prompt: There are a few other points we should discuss.  The loan agreement can only be executed by her ladyship's signature, and provided that Bracegirdle and Chatwick can be assured of her ladyship's freewill in giving her signature.
completion: Provided that they can be assured of her ladyship's freewill?  Are you serious?

prompt: Considering your financial circumstances, Mr. Cosgrove, it has been impossible to find anyone at all prepared to do any business with you.  I think you may count yourself lucky to have this opportunity. But, obviously, if you would reject this offer, I shall keep trying to find a better one.
completion: I am prepared to accept the terms, Mr. Newcombe.

prompt: I have good news for you, Mr. Cosgrove.  The firm of Bracegirdle and Chatwick, in the city of London, are prepared to lend you 20,000 pounds, pledged against your interest in the Edric mines.  They will redeem the encumbrances against the property, which amount to some 10,000 pounds, and take a twenty- year working lease on the mines. They will lend you the 20,000 pounds against the lease income, which they will apply to the loan as it comes in, and they will make a charge of 18% per annum interest on the outstanding loan balance.
completion: Mr. Newcombe, I have made some difficult loans during the past few years, at very onerous terms, but 18% a year interest seems very stiff indeed.

prompt: Yes, he's fine.
completion: Brooksy was better than you, papa, he used not to swear so, and he taught me many good things while you were away.

prompt: Your bother is in America fighting the rebels.
completion: Is he all right, papa?

prompt: I promise your lordship a good flogging if you even so much as go to Doolan's farm to see him.
completion: Yes, papa.

prompt: One of the boys in the stable told Nelly that you've already bought my horse, and that it's at Doolan's farm, where Mick the groom is breaking it in.  Is that true, papa?
completion: What the devil?  What kind of fools do we have here?  Pottle, who told the lad this story?

prompt: Papa?
completion: Yes?

prompt: Good night, papa.
completion: Good night, my little darling.

prompt: But I will have it on my birthday, won't I?
completion: Well, we'll just have to wait and see, won't we?

prompt: Did you buy the horse, papa?
completion: Now, just have a little patience, my boy.  Your birthday isn't until next week.

prompt: Sir, let those laugh that win.
completion: I am sorry for you Mr. James.  I'm grieved to keep you or any gentleman waiting.  Had you not better to arrange with my doctor or get the cook to flavor my omelette with arsenic?  What are the odds, gentlemen, that I don't live to see Mr. James hang yet?

prompt: I hope that you are not thinking of leaving us soon, knight?
completion: Not so soon, my dear, as you may fancy perhaps.  Why, man, I have been given over many times these four years, and there was always a candidate or two waiting to apply for the situation.  Who knows how long I may keep you waiting.

prompt: Well, if my intentions are what you think they are -- if I do wish to step into your shoes, what then?  I have no other intentions than you had yourself.  Lady Cosgrove's wealth may be great, but am I not of a generous nature enough to use it worthily?  Her rank is lofty, but not so lofty as my ambition.  I will be sworn to muster just as much regard for my Lady Cosgrove as you ever showed her; and if I win her, and wear her when you are dead and gone, corbleu, knight, do you think that it will be the fear of your ghost will deter me?
completion: Is it not a pleasure, gentlemen, for me, as I am drawing near the goal, to find my home such a happy one; my wife so fond of me, that she is even now thinking of appointing a successor?  Isn't it a comfort to see her; like a prudent housewife, getting everything ready for her husband's departure?

prompt: Faith, sir, if I want to learn good principles, it's surely better I should apply for them to your lady, and your chaplin than to you?
completion: He wants to step into my shoes!  He wants to step into my shoes!

prompt: I think, Sir William Cosgrove, you have had too much drink.  Your chaplin, Mr. Hunt, has introduced me into the company of your lady to advise me on a religious matter, of which she is a considerable expert.
completion: Gentlemen, see this amiable youth! He has been troubled by religious scruples, and has flown for refuge to my chaplin, Mr. Hunt, who has asked for advise from my wife, Lady Cosgrove, and between them both, they are confirming my ingenious young friend in his faith.  Did you ever hear of such doctors and such a disciple?

prompt: I beg your pardon?
completion: Come, come, sir.  I am a man who would rather be known as a cuckold than a fool.

prompt: Sir William Cosgrove, with his complication of ills, was dying before us by inches.  He was continually tinkered up by doctors, and, what with my usual luck, he might be restored to health and live I don't know how many years.  If Cosgrove would not die, where was the use of my pursing his lady?  But my fears were to prove groundless, for on that very night, patient nature would claim her account.
completion: Good evening, Mr. James, have you done with my lady?

prompt: The milkmaid's daughter?
completion: Well, why not a milkmaid's daughter? No man of sense need restrict himself or deny himself a single amusement for his wife's sake; on the contrary, if he selects the animal properly, he will choose such a one as shall be no bar to his pleasure, but a comfort in his hours of annoyance.  For instance, I have got the gout; who tends me?  A hired valet who robs me whenever he has the power.  My wife never comes near me.  What friend have I?  None in the wide world.  Men of the world, as you and I are, don't make friends, and we are fools for our pains.

prompt: Would you have me spend my life all alone?
completion: In truth, sir, yes, but, if you must marry, then marry a virtuous drudge.

prompt: Hang it, Mr. Roderick James, you have no more manners than a barber, and I think my black footman has been better educated than you; but you are a young fellow of originality and pluck, and I like you, sir.  because you seem determined to go to the devil by a way of your own.
completion: Indeed, you are right, sir.  Look at me.  Marriage has added forty years to my life.  I am dying, a worn-out cripple, at the age of fifty.  When I took off Lady Cosgrove, there was no man of my years who looked so young as myself.  Fool that I was! I had enough with my pensions, perfect freedom, the best society in Europe -- and I gave up all these, and married and was miserable.  Take a warning from me, Mr. Roderick, and stick to the trumps.  Do anything, but marry.

prompt: Tender Hegenheim.
completion: I made Sir William Cosgrove's acquaintance as usual at the play- table.  One could not but admire the spirit and gallantry with which he pursued his favorite pastime; for, though worn out with gout and a myriad of diseases, a cripple wheeled about in a chair, and suffering pangs of agony, yet you would see him every morning, and every evening at his post behind the delightful green cloth.

prompt: Will he wish to know the details of this night?
completion: He will believe that it will please me if he asks about it, and I shall tell him everything except some circumstances which might humiliate him.

prompt: If his love were like mine, he would not permit you to come here.
completion: He loves me, as I love you.

prompt: And he doesn't care about me?
completion: He is only curious to know who you are.

prompt: Do you expect me to believe that your lover brought you here tonight?
completion: Yes.  He brought me in his carriage, and he will call for me at midnight.

prompt: Black-eyed Sczortarska.
completion: Dark Valdez.

prompt: Old friend. Haven't talked to him in -- 911. Can I use your phone?
completion: Charming Schuvaloff.

prompt: Bill Styles...
completion: Who?

prompt: Hurricane kept you up, too?
completion: Yeah, and I could've used the sleep. I'm supposed to meet people here tonight, try and get some work going.

prompt: You know the law -- no liquor before noon. Could lose my license.
completion: Don't you mean "don't need no liquor license not taken away from me"?

prompt: It's ten thirty in the morning.
completion: Yeah, if you've slept.

prompt: You know that was like a quadruple negative?
completion: Can I at least have a drink?

prompt: None of that matters now. We got two dead bodies and a story that explains them. You're either with us, or against us -- which is it?
completion: Don't like 'em, don't eat 'em, don't make no damn difference to me.

prompt: Maybe he's dead too. Maybe you killed them both, Mueller --
completion: You framed-him...

prompt: Maybe he'll be there. Either way, we have to go.
completion: He is the only one unaccounted for.

prompt: It was the grenade you fucking idiot. Look at him!
completion: What about Pike?

prompt: Fine.
completion: Did -- did you --

prompt: Whoever it is isn't shooting at us...
completion: I don't want to go --

prompt: Fuck, what the fuck is going on --
completion: What do we do?

prompt: I thought I was gonna have an attack. Go into a fit and bite off my own tongue in the middle of the bayou. Childs could tell I wasn't right.
completion: Just safety your shit and get behind me, okay? I'll take care of this.

prompt: I'm -- I'm sorry...
completion: A target, Kendall, cap a fucking target. What's wrong with you?

prompt: Shut up, Mueller.
completion: Don't you ever point a gun at me!

prompt: HEY!
completion: West was one thing, but this --

prompt: I don't know!
completion: Shut the fuck up, you fucking faggot, You just shut the FUCK UP.

prompt: We got -- I don't know, we got separated
completion: Before or after the explosion?  Mueller --

prompt: You killed him you fucking faggot --
completion: We found him like this! Kendall was with me the whole -- Listen to me!

prompt: Hey, I --  Holy fuck... holy fuck, what the fuck did you guys do?
completion: We found him like this --

prompt: This isn't our area. Whose area is this --
completion: Can anybody hear me!

prompt: You too?
completion: We can still come out of this okay. Pike got free, he got a gun, he came after us. That's the story.

prompt: Yeah, right...
completion: Shut up.  West's dead.

prompt: Holy fuck... Holy fuck, what the fuck did you guys do?
completion: We found him like this...

prompt: What about you, wandering around alone? At least we have an alibi --
completion: What do you mean, alone?

prompt: We finished the course and came here, then heard an explosion --  Where's Pike?
completion: We don't know. West is dead.

prompt: Washout rejects, guys he said were "dumbfucks too stupid to know they dead"...
completion: He's telling the truth up to a point...

prompt: You won't find them. Won't find West, either. He's too good.
completion: I promised them I'd ask you where West and the others are...

prompt: I guess Nunez wasn't dead after all. He came after us with a vengeance.  You know the rest.
completion: And the bodies?

prompt: Do what?
completion: Hunting -- we had to hunt him --

prompt: Jesus!
completion: He -- He made me do it --

prompt: We've found all of them.
completion: Not true, Cadet, I've got a gun --

prompt: We don't need the tapes --
completion: Oh, you don't? What else do you have on me? You haven't found any bodies yet, have you?

prompt: We're not finished yet --
completion: You wanna bet?

prompt: Raymond, for you to have any chance of coming out of this, we need to locate the other bodies and examine them to corroborate your testimony. Otherwise this is just another story --
completion: Mr. Hardy, I joined the army for college money. I didn't ask for any of this -- I tried to do the right thing out there and people got killed. You say finding those bodies'll help me, then go find them. I don't want to die.

prompt: You saved Kendall's life --
completion: But not Pike's.

prompt: You shot Childs and Nunez.
completion: They would have killed us both. You want me to write a confession, I'll write a confession.

prompt: And he'd been shot.
completion: Yeah --

prompt: You saw West's body.
completion: Of course --

prompt: Yeah, we know, Pike did.
completion: I apologize --

prompt: So Childs made some side money, so what? People are dead, Ray, and the only one we have to blame is you --
completion: I didn't shoot West --

prompt: Fuck "you're serious", Raymond, you got exactly zero truck with us; right now we'd take the word of a crackhead over yours, so if you've got something to say, say it.
completion: Did Kendall tell you about the PX?

prompt: Well, why didn't you say so? We'll just drop all your charges, then --
completion: I'm serious --

prompt: That'd be my reaction too --
completion: He's lying.

prompt: Hey, Ray! Just had a nice talk with your buddy Kendall -- seems you killed three people!
completion: That son of a bitch.

prompt: This is one of those interrogation tricks, isn't it? You don't give me a cigarette till I tell you more.
completion: No, actually, I just left mine in the car and was hoping you had some.

prompt: Yeah. And that's all I'm saying.
completion: You smoke, Ray?

prompt: Tell me about them.
completion: And those were the guys who went on the exercise with you?

prompt: Okay... but I would like to know about the other cadets. What they were like -- nice guys?
completion: Some.

prompt: Why'd you ask for a cop, Ray?
completion: I'm not telling you what happened.

prompt: Right. Now, I'm gonna go get you another donut and you think about whether you want to talk more, okay?
completion: Okay.

prompt: There's no need...
completion: They're dead, aren't they?

prompt: You did Basic here?
completion: Fifteen years ago under Sergeant West. Piece of work, that guy. I remember, he used to have these two silver .45's with ivory handles and if you weren't quick enough, he'd knock you on the head with one of them. He still carry those guns?

prompt: I don't know... I like the Army.
completion: C'mon, Ray, everyone hates the Army during Basic. I'll tell you straight, I hated it here.

prompt: I just don't like it.
completion: What do you like then?

prompt: It's... too slow.
completion: Well, it's a game of anticipation, that's the beauty.

prompt: I asked for a policeman.
completion: You're under military arrest, it's not gonna happen. What's wrong with baseball?

prompt: Just a guess. Maybe they're not where they're supposed to be. Maybe somebody moved them. Habeas Corpus -- no bodies, no crime, and Nunez still plays as self defense. Face it detectives... you have nothing.
completion: Why not?

prompt: Ohhhh, I don't think so...
completion: How do you know that?

prompt: We can prove that you're not Ray Dunbar. Impersonating a fellow Cadet is a court-martial in and of itself --
completion: Did I ever claim I was Raymond Dunbar? Was I ever told to state my name rank and serial number for the record? No. You assumed who I was, because I was wearing this uniform. Don't believe me?

prompt: Can't do that now, though, can you?
completion: Is that what I did, now? And of course, you can prove all of it.

prompt: Don't know on a map. West told us it was there, we just found it. Maybe the hurricane took it away.
completion: You kept Kendall alive to corroborate your story and he did it all they way up to the end. You even gave him his own motive in case we decided to burn him, too.

prompt: Would you have believed me?
completion: Where's the cabin?

prompt: Yeah.
completion: Why didn't you tell us all this in the first place?

prompt: Back up.
completion: Mueller was alone in the cabin?

prompt: What about the phosphorous grenade?
completion: One went off, yeah, but it didn't touch him -- I thought you knew this --

prompt: Where?
completion: The creek bed --

prompt: What business?
completion: Pills, shots, you name it, Basic's a lot easier when you don't feel pain --

prompt: He said he worked there --
completion: No, did he tell you about it? About the business Childs ran?

prompt: Epilepsy.
completion: Yeah. Spent half his time in the infirmary. Only reason he enlisted was his father. West didn't section him till last week.

prompt: There were six of us...
completion: He was sickly. Had that shaking thing, whatd'yacall it, epoxy?

prompt: That first night with Pike. I made the mistake of letting him sit down at around 0300.
completion: Tell us about the other guys, the ones West weeded out.

prompt: Are you saying Sergeant West tried to kill you?
completion: No, ma'am, he just wanted us to quit. Making it through was kind of an honor. Some of the other guys on the base told us that if you could hack Section Eight, Command would consider you at the top of the class.

prompt: What the fuck is going on?
completion: Your weapons, Sergeant.

prompt: Sir, yes, sir!
completion: The rest of you, fallout for physicals!

prompt: Sir, yes, sir!
completion: Dunbar you are to stand here and guard this nigger for the next twenty- four hours! He is not to be given food, water, or clothes! If he so much as moves, you are to blow his nigger brains out, is that clear?

prompt: Sir, Dunbar, sir!
completion: You know how to work a pistol, Dunbar?
Cadet, what's your name!

prompt: So did we. Why didn't you come?
completion: So you killed him?

prompt: West... he's dead.
completion: Pike and I got separated... then I heard gunfire. Close.

prompt: We were each given three so whoever killed West will be missing one.
completion: Jesus, what happened?

prompt: Shut up.  Let me see your grenades.
completion: Why?

prompt: Oh, bullshit, he's a fucking convict. You know how much he hated West --
completion: I hated West, Childs hated West, everyone with a goddamn brain hated West but that doesn't mean we killed him!

prompt: Put it down!
completion: He wouldn't kill anybody...

prompt: We wait and I'm a dead man. I got a black face, a criminal record, and over a hundred other cadets who'll testify how much I hated West -- my court martial will take six minutes. It's either me or them, Ray, and you gotta decide right now.
completion: A test will no doubt link you to the killing --

prompt: There's no time to think, Ray, we gotta get out of here! You untie me, we grab the guns, get Kendall and Nunez, and make a run for it --
completion: No... no, we can just wait till we get back and then tell the M.P.'s --

prompt: What don't you know?
completion: This is a lot of information to be getting... I have to think --

prompt: Mueller and Childs. One of them must've taken the grenade from my pack on the chopper...
completion: I... I don't know...

prompt: Way I figure it, West must have found out about their little business and was gonna bust them, so they decided to get rid of him first...
completion: They?

prompt: His chest was hamburger --
completion: That's close range. You go full auto on a guy from close range, you're gonna be swimming in blood. Look at my uniform. Nothing.

prompt: Full clip to the body --
completion: From up close or far away?

prompt: That still doesn't mean you didn't kill him.
completion: You saw West, right? How was he killed?

prompt: Why... why didn't you tell me?
completion: Becoming a morphine addict during Basic ain't exactly something you want to broadcast. Only Mueller and Childs know.

prompt: You're lying --
completion: Pull up my sleeve. Right arm.

prompt: Just look. Little pocket.
completion: Combat grade morphine. Mueller sold it to me.

prompt: Look in my pack.
completion: Why?

prompt: Enough to go to prison? Childs' PX scam, Mueller was in on it --
completion: Bullshit.

prompt: Who you gonna trust, Ray? Him or your friend?
completion: You hated West, Mueller loved him --

prompt: We're sweeping our area and suddenly he's gone. Couple minutes later, phosphorous grenade pops off about a third of a click away --
completion: That's exactly what he says about you.

prompt: Mueller.
completion: Oh, come on --

prompt: Ray, this is my life here. I ain't gonna pretend I'm not happy West is gone, but you know I couldn't have done this. It's not in me.
completion: If not you, then who?

prompt: You're the only one missing a grenade.
completion: Which anyone coulda taken out of my gear on the chopper. Were you watching your pack on the ride in?

prompt: You hated West more than any of us.
completion: Maybe, but that don't make me a killer --

prompt: Yeah...
completion: You gotta untie me.  I didn't do this thing, Ray.

prompt: Do I?
completion: Right?

prompt: Why?
completion: You know it's not like that --

prompt: Roberto, what the fuck?
completion: We just want to check your pack --

prompt: Where have you been, Jay?
completion: Wandering through a hurricane trying to find this place. It's gettin' bad out there --  Where's West?

prompt: What do you mean, West's?
completion: I mean I killed him.  Isn't that what we all wanted?

prompt: Whose blood is that, Jay?
completion: West's. Any kindling for afire?

prompt: MAYBE WHAT --
completion: Maybe he...

prompt: Where are they!
completion: Maybe --

prompt: You lied to us, Levi, you're going to the gas chamber unless you tell us where to find them!
completion: I don't know --

prompt: I didn't --
completion: But you can't prove it! You can't prove anything until we find the bodies!

prompt: Because I was standing next to him.
completion: Or you, Levi? When is it finally going to come out that you were the one who killed him?

prompt: Because of what I saw.  Who really killed West.
completion: How do you know?

prompt: I didn't do anything --
completion: Why?

prompt: I was just thinking of what's going to happen to your careers when my father gets through with you.
completion: Jail if he's lucky, the gas chamber if he's not --

prompt: Then we'll leave it up to the courts -- His word against mine. What does his father do again? Steelworker?  Doesn't matter, I'm sure justice will be served. In any case, my father will definitely want to talk to you about all these questions, these accusations on his son. He's quite protective.
completion: Something funny, Levi?

prompt: Sorry to disappoint. I'm on painkillers for the injury -- they cloud the mind. You're right, it was Nunez. Any more questions?
completion: Dunbar will testify that you were.

prompt: I believe your next line is "What are you trying to hide?"
completion: Well?

prompt: No. I said Dunbar.
completion: Huh. You know, I really thought you said Nunez. I thought you said "Dunbar was gone," My fault, I gotta check the tape on that.  Oh, yeah we taped the last interview. This one too. Cause it'd be a real break for us to catch you in a lie.

prompt: So I should stay silent about his misdeeds? The guns went off, I ran in, Childs shot me, Pike and Mueller were dead, and Dunbar was running out the door with the smoking gun --
completion: Dunbar was running out the door? Ohhhhhh... See that's where I was confused, because I thought you said Nunez was running out the door.

prompt: There's that word again.  As I told you, I wasn't in the room when everyone started shooting.
completion: Why did you tell us he shot everybody, Levi? You put him in for three murders, the man saved your life --

prompt: My heart weeps.
completion: Is it the truth?

prompt: Can I go to jail for punching a guy who's been shot?
completion: Epileptic attacks are murder on your system. Rattle your internal organs like a paint mixer.

prompt: You tried to pin three stone murders on Dunbar --
completion: How many murders did you cover up? One? Five? Maybe an even ten.

prompt: Somebody emptied a full clip into him --
completion: Stop.

prompt: Okay. I think that's it. He rises and walks to the door.
completion: Mr. Hardy?

prompt: Why did he come back for you?
completion: I honestly don't know. Maybe to have someone to cover for him. And I wish I could, but there's no doubt in my mind he killed those men.

prompt: He admitted it.
completion: Right in front of us. Mueller went after him but we held him back.

prompt: But you didn't.
completion: No. Poetic justice, though.

prompt: Then who did?
completion: Maybe I shouldn't tell you that. Maybe I should tell you I wasn't scared at all. But I was...  Enough to almost kill him.

prompt: What happened to "degrees"?
completion: I didn't kill him --

prompt: Levi, I don't know if you're familiar with investigative work, but we have this little thing called "motive" and you just gave yourself one.
completion: You said you wanted to know what happened -- I'm telling you the truth.

prompt: I think you just blew "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" out of the fucking water.
completion: The Sergeant discovered this relationship and wanted me expelled. My father interceded, so instead, West Sectioned me and made sure every other cadet knew that I was gay.

prompt: Senator Daddy must be thrilled.
completion: He is not, shall we say, wild about the idea. He has asked me on numerous occasions to be more discreet about my proclivities, and I have done my best to oblige him. However, in the last four weeks, I began a relationship with another cadet. What do you think of that?

prompt: My, my, my, how did things turn so hostile so quickly? If I didn't know better, I'd say you two were out to get me.
completion: My father is a powerful man. Over the years he's used that power to protect me, in one form or another, from certain... unpleasantries.  I am a homosexual.

prompt: I've done nothing wrong.  I'm the victim here.
completion: But not the only victim, right?

prompt: That's it. You're that policeman with friends in low places. Tell me, how's Guissepe Torres doing these days? Those racketeering indictments must have really been a downer --
completion: Levi, you got about four hours before armed men show up here, put you on a plane to Washington, and lock you in a very small dark room. I suggest you talk to us.

prompt: You... I've seen you around the Base. But you...  You're not Army, are you?
completion: Coast Guard, special detective detail. We feel this incident may have put the beaches of Florida at risk.

prompt: For the last time, I have no idea what you're talking about --
completion: Get your hands away from the desk!

prompt: You're crazy --
completion: You can't duck this, Bill. I may have done every goddamn thing in my life wrong but I won't let this happen.

prompt: Not for long.
completion: No more witnesses. West's a ghost. But it doesn't matter because we have your signature, the hospital log, and Kendall's toxicology report. And that'll be enough.

prompt: No! You will stand there and you will listen! What happened to you, Bill? You were the one who joined up to do good in the world. You were the one who believed in it --
completion: You want to get into a finger pointing contest about character? The army kicked you out for drugs, the cops fired you for taking bribes from a mobster, and you think you can stand there and lecture me on codes of conduct? There's only one criminal standing in this room and it's you.

prompt: You poisoned him, Bill. You heard our interrogation, you knew he was ready to crack, so you killed him, just like Pike.
completion: I'm not even going to dignify that --

prompt: Toxicology report came back. Kendall's attack was caused by a drug known as anephadrine, maybe you've heard of it. It's for asthmatics. If an epileptic takes enough, it kills them. I checked with the nurses at the hospital -- you're the only other person who visited Kendall.
completion: I wanted to see if he was okay --

prompt: What I can't understand is why you signed these. If you'd just let West take care of the paperwork, no one would have known, but you got careless. So when Pike finally told the truth you had to get rid of him, too.
completion: That's preposterous --

prompt: Or what? You've gone round the bend --
completion: West had a partner. Someone who knew how to get things done.

prompt: I'm not going to cover for you, Bill. Not for this.
completion: Stay where you are.

prompt: If you let him testify then it would have all come out. West was supposed to take care of it out there, shut Nunez up and then disappear. But it got messy and people got killed. So you called your old pal Tom Hardy, figuring if worse came to worse, he'd cover for you.
completion: You're drunk --

prompt: It was so good, I actually forgot you're one of the bigger dogs now. The Base Commander. The one in control. You couldn't let him testify, could you?
completion: What are you talking about?

prompt: You're a good soldier, Bill.
completion: I thought you said that wasn't a compliment.

prompt: I'm sorry, Bill.
completion: Don't be. I'm not cut out to deal with the West's of the world.

prompt: They're taking your command, aren't they?
completion: The Senator...

prompt: You think you could explain all this to me?
completion: I wouldn't know where to start.  I guess it was about one man framing another. He thought if the other guy got blamed, people would over look his own wrong doings.

prompt: That's horseshit and you know it.
completion: Maybe. But it's my fault and I'll carry it.

prompt: Does Osborne agree?
completion: It's over. Time of death was 4:42. JAG's been notified and I called the Senator myself. My report will reflect that his medical condition made this unavoidable... you two had no culpability in the matter.

prompt: Was dead right. You think Dunbar's on the level?
completion: Yeah.

prompt: I'm talking about West! We had him, Bill, we were there. You're the fucking Base Commander, you knew what he did to Cadets and you let him go on the way he always he has --
completion: What I said before --

prompt: You want a confession? Why don't you confess, Bill: people are dead and you don't give a shit about it! Only reason you called me is to protect your fucking job, you know this is your fault --
completion: What the hell are you talking about --

prompt: Home, I'm done.
completion: What about the confession?

prompt: JAG gets here in three hours. Try for the confession.
completion: Tom, where are you going --

prompt: Not for me.
completion: You mean not enough to save you.

prompt: Nevertheless --
completion: Nevertheless what'? Kendall will testify and that'll be enough.

prompt: Without the body we have no physical proof. We need a confession.
completion: From Dunbar? I hate to break this to you, but I don't think he's gonna be all that psyched to put himself in for the death penalty.

prompt: Habeas Corpus -- you have to have a body to have a crime.
completion: Okay, then let's widen the search to include the endzone in Giants Stadium and the trunk of my car --

prompt: We've already been over the terrain twice. Nothing.
completion: There was a hurricane, Bill, the wind probably moved it.

prompt: Who killed Pike?
completion: Someone must have got a shot off. He wasn't exactly a moving target.

prompt: He can wait. Kendall's out of surgery.
completion: Pike killed West, Dunbar killed Mueller, Childs, and Nunez.

prompt: I'm not gonna let that happen.
completion: He's not done by a longshot, I can get more out of him --

prompt: And I'm the closest thing to it, right?
completion: Tom, bottom line: I let those kids go out there. If JAG shows up and I don't have any answers for them, my career is finished --

prompt: Which gives us about five hours. Why'd you call me?
completion: The guy in interrogation said he'd only talk to a cop.

prompt: I'm assuming that's what made him the dead one?
completion: Cadet Roberto R. Nunez. Killed right in front of me.

prompt: And the problem is you only got three.
completion: No, the problem is one's dead, one's got a bullet in his arm, and one won't talk. The one who won't talk was trading live fire with the dead one as we reached the pick-up.

prompt: Well, he's a good soldier.
completion: The exercise was one of his Section Eight "private sessions". Left around 2100 yesterday and were scheduled for pick up at 0630 this morning.

prompt: It's not West, is it? Tell me it's not West.
completion: A few years ago, the Army picked our good buddy as their go to non-com to trot out to the press to talk about the kinder, gentler military. He even did the standard video greeting played to all incoming Basic cadets across the country.

prompt: And here you are going out of house. How's that make you feel, Jules?
completion: The official term for it is "Clusterfuck". By the time Beth hit us, I'd canceled all off base exercises save one -- a six man cadet team and their Drill out in the bush. We're missing three and the Sergeant. The cadets are in their eighth week of the cycle, nobody here knows much about them, up to and including their names. But the Sergeant...

prompt: Tell me what I can do.
completion: This is Warrant Officer Julia Osborne, the closest thing we have to an in- house investigator.

prompt: That bad?
completion: Would I have called you if it wasn't? If there was any other way --

prompt: Been better.  I read about what's been happening with you... I should have called --
completion: What kind of trouble are you in?

completion: How long have you worked for the agency?

prompt: Mr. Nevins?
completion: Who's this?

prompt: So?
completion: Felt promising. It's a start.

prompt: Alright...
completion: Let's give him half an hour.

prompt: Is it fresh?

prompt: See, that's a problem for me, Nicky. Whatever he's doing, we need to end it. This isn't the kind of mess you walk away from.

prompt: Not good enough. You're the person who floated this amnesia story.  Ever feel sorry for him? For what he'd been through?

prompt: So he fooled you.
completion: If you say so.

prompt: Believed what?

prompt: Are you an expert in amnesia?

prompt: I'm curious about Bourne. Your interpretation of his condition. You have specific training in the identification and diagnosis of psychological conditions?

prompt: Good luck.
completion: You were his local contact. You were with him the night Conklin died. You're coming with us.

prompt: Amnesia?
completion: Before this? Before Bourne? No.

prompt: What kind of problems?
completion: Depression. Anger. Compulsive behaviors. They had physical symptoms -- headaches -- sensitivity to light --

prompt: Yes. In that order.
completion: And what about you, anything?

prompt: We're looking at all Berlin outbound. Good news is, every train station in Berlin has thirty to forty fixed, digital security cameras. Common feed.
completion: Are we hacking or asking?

prompt: His wife. In room 645. Then she shot herself.
completion: Alright... I want you, Kurt and Kim to stay on Bourne, track everything that's out there...

prompt: Here's what I've got.  Remember Vladimir Neski? Russian politician? Seven years ago, he was due to speak to a group of European Oil ministers here at the hotel. He never did. He was murdered.
completion: By who?

prompt: Black coat, possibly leather. Dark slacks. Dark t-shirt.  He says they're gonna try and corral the guests on the street over there, and then check them out, but...
completion: Yeah, that'll work...What the hell was he doing here?

prompt: No. Munich's a bust. He's loose.
completion: Are we locked up?

prompt: What the hell is a "Treadstone?"
completion: Anything?

prompt: Do we know what this says?
completion: Yup...  The main word there, the file heading, translates as: Treadstone.

prompt: Then we'll just have a peek at the wounds.  Dig 'em up!
completion: They've been sanctified and buried in the holy rites of God's church, and any hand that disturbs them now takes on eternal damnation. So please -- do it.

prompt: What it means in England -- and in Scotland too -- is that rebels have forfeited their lands. We were ambushed last night. But the Scots dragged their dead away.
completion: My brother and nephew perished two days ago, when their hay cart turned over.

prompt: Someone dead from this household?
completion: We just had a funeral, isn't that what it means in England as well?

prompt: What are they doing?
completion: Saying goodbye in their own way -- in outlawed tartans, with outlawed pipes, playing outlawed tunes.

prompt: It was in Latin, sir.
completion: Non loquis Latinum? You don't speak Latin? We have to fix that, won't we?  Did he give the poetic benediction? The Lord bless thee and keep thee? Patris Benefactum et --  ...It was Malcolm's favorite.

prompt: Didn't want your father to die either, did ya? But it happened.
completion: Did the priest say anything about the Resurrection? Or was it all about Judgment?

prompt: We'll sleep here tonight. You'll come home with me. We'll let the house, and the lands too; plenty of willing neighbors.
completion: I don't want to leave.

prompt: I will meet you, but only one way -- if Robert the Bruce is there, and puts his hand on my Bible, and swears his loyalty to Scotland.
completion: He has already agreed to come.

prompt: So let the council swear publicly.
completion: We cannot. Some scarcely believe you are alive. Other think you'll pay them Mornay's wages. We bid you to Edinburgh. Meet us at the city gates, two days from now, at sunset. Pledge us your pardon and we will unite behind you. Scotland will be one.

prompt: You've all sworn to Longshanks.
completion: An oath to a liar is no oath at all. An oath to a patriot is a vow indeed. Every man of us is ready to swear loyalty to you.

prompt: It is suicide.
completion: Sir William. We come to seek a meeting.

prompt: We cannot defeat this --
completion: With cavalry -- not heavy, like the English, but light, fast horsemen, like you nobles employ -- we could outmaneuver their bowmen!

prompt: We must sue for peace.
completion: Peace?!

prompt: Invade?! That's impossible, it --
completion: A thousand.  You have made me Guardian of Scotland. So I tell you this is what we face.

prompt: But... what will you do?
completion: I will invade England. And defeat the English on their own ground.

prompt: Longshanks promised!
completion: You are surprised he would lie? Balliol was murdered in a church yesterday. You are Longshanks' new designate. You will be king.

prompt: He won't come.
completion: He will. I know he will.

prompt: The crown is that of Scotland. And Scotland is William Wallace.
completion: That is another matter. There is a price to all this, required both by Longshanks and our nobles. Pay it, and you will be our king. And we will have peace.

prompt: If I pay homage to another's throne, then how am I a king?
completion: Homage is nothing. It is the crown that matters!

prompt: He was a modest man.
completion: It will not be long before Longshanks too is encased in stone, and his crowns divided for others to wear.

prompt: No. But his weight with the commoners could unbalance everything. The Balliols will kiss his ass, so we must.
completion: May he rest in peace... You have already sealed the coffin?

prompt: He strained his leg so that it pains him to ride. But he sends his greetings -- and says that I speak for all the Bruces. And for Scotland.
completion: Does anyone know his politics?

prompt: Clearly meant to draw more of his supporters here.
completion: A wise plan. And how is your father? We have missed him at the council.

prompt: Young Robert, we are honored --
completion: My father hears that Longshanks has granted prima noctes.

prompt: His legend grows! It will be worse than before!
completion: You let Wallace escape your whole army. You cannot blame me for this.

prompt: But if we have not caught Wallace --
completion: He is gone! Finished! Dead! If he has not yet bled to death or had his throat cut for him, he will not survive the winter. It is very cold -- is it not, our flower?

prompt: The Scots will fight for us?
completion: What choice do they have? Now they must serve us or starve.

prompt: So the Scots will have none of them, will they? My armorers have already made a thousand.
completion: Now we kill two birds at one stroke. We recruit from Scotland for our armies in France.

prompt: Impossible.  How dare you bring a panicky lie.
completion: The weapon has been outlawed by the Pope himself!

prompt: I have ordered conscriptions...
completion: Wallace has sacked York!

prompt: Nothing new, Majesty. We have sent riders to speed any word.
completion: While I am in France fighting to expand your future kingdom I learn that Stirling castle is lost, our entire northern army wiped out! And you have done nothing?!

prompt: I hear. This Wallace is a bandit, nothing more.
completion: What news of the north?

prompt: Before he lost his powers of speech, he told me his one comfort was that he would live to know Wallace was dead.
completion: Scottish rebels have routed Lord Bottoms!

prompt: I respect him. At worst he was a worthy enemy. Show mercy... Oh thou great king... and win the respect of your own people.
completion: Nor you. To you that word is as unfamiliar as love.

prompt: I have come to beg for the life of William Wallace.
completion: You fancy him.

prompt: When will his trial be?
completion: Wallace's? For treason there is no trial. Tomorrow he will be charged, then executed.

prompt: Is it true? Wallace is captured?
completion: Simply because he eluded your trap, do you think he is more than a man? My father is dying. Perhaps you should think of our coronation.

prompt: The little cow is insane --
completion: Grant, as you do everything else, with treachery. Offer him a truce to discuss terms, and send me to my castle at Locharmbie as your emissary. He trusts me. Pick thirty of your finest assassins for me to take along. And I will set the meeting, and the ambush.

prompt: Wallace's followers.
completion: Wallace himself. If you wish to pretend a ghost rallies new volunteers in every Scottish town, I leave you to your hauntings. If you wish to take him, I know a way.

prompt: You mock us with a smile?
completion: I am cheerful with a plan to soothe your miseries. All of England shudders with the news of renewed rebellion.

prompt: You may.
completion: Good day to you, M'Lords.

prompt: Now, my flower, do you understand?
completion: Yes. I had thought that... I was loathsome to you. Perhaps I am. If I may be excused, M'lord.

prompt: No, M'lord.
completion: Look at me. I said LOOK AT ME!

prompt: ...His majesty was quite keen that you should understand --
completion: All so very boring! He wants me to learn to fight too, so let me do it!

prompt: Scotland. He intends --
completion: Shut up, would you! How can I concentrate?!

prompt: You directed me to report to you the moment the king's conference was ended.
completion: So I did! And what was so important about it?

prompt: No. One of us is enough.
completion: What is it?!

prompt: My dreams of Marion are gone. I killed them myself. If I knew I could live with her on the other side of death, I'd welcome it.
completion: Keep these. We're going too.

prompt: We've lived a dream together. A dream of freedom!
completion: Your dreams aren't about freedom! They're about Marion! You have to be a hero, because you think she sees you! Is that it?

prompt: Nor I! I want to live! I want a home and children and peace. I've asked god for those things. But He's brought me this sword. And if He wills that I must lay it down to have what He wants for my country, then I'll do that too.
completion: That's just a dream, William!

prompt: Probably. But we can't win alone. We know that. This is the only way.
completion: I don't want to be a martyr.

prompt: Your rest is making me exhausted.
completion: You know it's a trap.

prompt: Rest, William.
completion: I rest.

prompt: Thanks for the food and drink. And for bringing 'em yourselves.
completion: We're here to stay. We don't care to live, if we can't fight beside ya.

prompt: Stephen ready?
completion: Aye.

prompt: The Bruce is not coming, William.
completion: Mornay has come. So will the Bruce.

prompt: We make spears. A hundred spears. Fourteen feet long.
completion: Fourteen? --

prompt: I'll wait... back there.
completion: Hamish, I... thank...

prompt: Good to see you again.
completion: I should'a remembered the eggs.

prompt: You'll move
completion: I will not.

prompt: Can you do it when it matters? As it matters in battle? Could you crush a man with that throw?
completion: I could crush you like a roach.

prompt: I still say this is no test. A catapult can throw a stone farther than a man can.
completion: That depends on the man.

prompt: Call it a test of soldiery, then. The English won't let us train with weapons, so we train with stones.
completion: The test of a soldier is not in his arm. It's here.

prompt: Test of manhood.
completion: You win.

prompt: We'll get those English pigs tomorrow.
completion: Aye, we'll get 'em.

prompt: Wanna stay with me tonight?
completion: I wanna have supper waitin'.

prompt: With your father and brother gone, they'll kill us and burn the farm!
completion: It's up to us, Hamish!

prompt: Armed?
completion: They're English soldiers, ain't they?

prompt: How many?
completion: Three, maybe more!

prompt: They used hounds on us in Ireland, it's the only way!
completion: They're coming!

completion: We don't split up!

prompt: A common thief.
completion: A patriot!

prompt: In order to find his equal, and Irishman is forced to talk to God.  Yes, Father!...  The Almighty says don't change the subject, just answer the fookin' question.

prompt: All right, Father, I'll ask him!  If I risk my neck for you, will I get a chance to kill Englishmen?

prompt: In my heart I had begun to hope that he would never break.

prompt: He broke because of me. I saw it. He lost all will to fight.
