prompt: He was so brave. With courage alone he nearly won.
completion: So more men were slaughtered uselessly!

prompt: He will fight you forever. But what does he fight for? Freedom first, and peace. So grant them.
completion: I am the one who is rotting. But I think your face looks graver than mine.

prompt: I have faced him. Have you?
completion: Let her speak.

prompt: Forgive me, Sire. I thought that generosity might demonstrate your greatness to those you mean to rule.
completion: My greatness is better demonstrated with this.

prompt: No. I have it to ease the suffering of the children of this war.
completion: This is what happens when you must send a woman. And a fool.

prompt: The Scottish nobles have sent him no support. His army starves. Our stall has worked, he must withdraw. You may return to your embroidery.
completion: Humbly, M'lord.

prompt: You spoke with this Wallace in private. What kind of man is he?
completion: ...A mindless barbarian. Not a king like you, M'lord.

prompt: Then why does he stay? My scouts say he has not advanced.
completion: He waits. For you. He says he will attack no more towns -- if you are man enough to come fight him.

prompt: My son's loyal wife returns, unkilled by the heathen. So he accepted our bribe.
completion: No. He did not.

prompt: Shall I leave, M'lord?
completion: If he wants his queen to rule, then you stay and learn how! I will deal with him.

prompt: Your pardon, M'lord, he asked me to come in his stead.
completion: I sent for him -- and the little coward send you?!

prompt: Then on the morrow, thou shalt receive they purification... And in the end, I promise you'll beg for the axe.
completion: Where is my son?

prompt: Confess, and you may receive a quick death. Deny, and you must be purified by pain. Do you confess? ...DO YOU CONFESS?!
completion: I do not confess.

prompt: It matters not, he is thy king!
completion: -- while many who serve him have taken and broken his oath many times. I cannot commit treason, if I have never been his subject!

prompt: Against thy king, thou vile fool! Hast thou anything to say?
completion: Never, in my whole life, did I swear allegiance to your king --

prompt: ...Tonight!
completion: Treason. Against whom?

prompt: My parents are growing suspicious! I can't keep meeting you every night!
completion: Then when?

prompt: Shush. It's only been a day.  And it's seemed like forever.
completion: Tonight then.

prompt: I will be with you, like this. Forever.
completion: I've missed you.

prompt: I don't want to scare you. I want to be yours, and you mine. Every night like this one.
completion: This night is too beautiful to have again.

prompt: But I won't give you up to any nobleman.
completion: You scare me.

prompt: I'm not just saying it!
completion: Nor I!

prompt: I want... to marry you!
completion: I... accept your proposal!

prompt: Did it work?
completion: No. You don't choose your dreams. Your dreams choose you.

prompt: You've been here before?
completion: Some nights. I have dreams. Mostly dreams I don't want. I started riding at night to fill up my mind so that when I did sleep I'd dream only of the ride and the adventure.

prompt: I'll invite you again, but your mother thinks I'm crazy.
completion: You are. And I'll come again.

prompt: Thank you for accepting.
completion: Thank you for inviting.

prompt: Your father doesn't like me, does he?
completion: It's not you. He dislikes that you're a Wallace. He just says... the Wallaces don't seem to live for very long.

prompt: I need you so much! I love you!
completion: Wake up, William. Wake up!

prompt: I don't want to wake. I want to stay with you.
completion: And I with you. But you must wake.

prompt: I'm dreaming.
completion: Yes, you are. And you must wake.

prompt: Knowing his passion for his lost love, they next plotted to take him by desecrating the graves of his father and brother and setting an ambush at the grave of his wife. He fought his way through the trap and carried her body to a secret place! Now that is romance, Oui?
completion: ...I wouldn't know.

prompt: This Scottish rebel... Wallace? He fights to avenge a woman?
completion: A magistrate wished to capture him, and found he had a secret lover, so he cut the girl's throat to tempt Wallace to fight -- and fight he did.

prompt: He shouldn't be telling secrets in bed.
completion: Ah, Oui! Englishmen don't know what a tongue is for.

prompt: How do you know this?
completion: Last night I slept with a member of the War Council.

prompt: I can't bear the thought of your torture. Take it!
completion: When the king returns he will bury them in those new clothes. Scotland is in chaos. Your husband is secretly sending an army north.

prompt: Drink this! It will dull your pain.
completion: It will numb my wits, and I must have them all. If I'm senseless, or if I wail, then Longshanks will have broken me.

prompt: You will die! It will be awful!
completion: Every man dies. Not every man really lives.

prompt: Mercy... is to die quickly. Perhaps even live in the Tower. In time, who knows what can happen, if you can only live.
completion: If I swear to him, then everything I am is dead already.

prompt: Sir, I... come to beg you to confess all, and swear allegiance to the king, that he might show you mercy.
completion: Will he show mercy to my country? Will he take back his soldiers, and let us rule ourselves?

prompt: No. But can you love me for the sake of all you loved and lost? Or simply love me... because I love you?
completion: M'lady... what kindness of you to visit a stranger.

prompt: You understand. Consider, before you laugh and say no. You will never own a throne, though you deserve one. But just as the sun will rise tomorrow, some man will rule England. And what if his veins ran not with the blood of Longshanks, but with that of a true king?
completion: I cannot love you for the sake of revenge.

prompt: You have... you have a husband.
completion: I have taken vows. More than one. I've vowed faithfulness to my husband, and sworn to give him a son. And I cannot keep both promises.

prompt: Why did you?
completion: Because of the way you're looking at me now. The same way... as when we met.

prompt: A meeting in a barn. It had to be a trap. And only you would know I would be aware of it.
completion: It does me good to see you.

prompt: I understand you have suffered. I know... about your woman.
completion: She was my wife. We married in secret because I would not share her with an English lord. They killed her to get to me. And she was pregnant.

prompt: Peace is made is such ways.
completion: SLAVES ARE MADE IN SUCH WAYS!

prompt: Let us talk plainly. You invade England. But you cannot complete the conquest, so far from your shelter and supply. The King proposes that you withdraw your attack. In return he grants you title, estates, and this chest with a thousand pounds of gold, which I am to pay to you personally.
completion: A Lordship. And gold. That I should become Judas.

prompt: York was the staging point for every invasion of my country. And that royal cousin hanged a hundred Scots, even women and children, from the city walls.
completion: That is not possible.

prompt: I have been given nothing. God makes men what they are.
completion: Did God make you the sacker of peaceful cities? The executioner of the king's nephew, my husband's own cousin?

prompt: But now that I am here, will you speak with a woman?
completion: I understand that you have recently been given the rank of knight.

prompt: I come as the king's servant, and with his authority.
completion: It's battle I want, not talk.

prompt: I am the Princess of Wales.
completion: Wife of Edward, the king's son?

prompt: I must... consult with my father.
completion: And I will consult with mine.

prompt: I am trying.
completion: Then tell me what a king is! Is he a man who believes only what others believe? Is he one who calculates the numbers for and against him but never weighs the strength in your own heart? There is strength in you. I see it. I know it.

prompt: Nobles? What does that mean -- to be noble? Your title gives you claim to the throne of our country. But men don't follow titles, they follow courage! Your arm speaks louder than your tongue. Our people know you. Noble and common, they respect you. If you would lead them toward freedom, they would follow you. And so would I.
completion: War finds me willing. I know it won't bring back all I have lost. But it can bring what none of us have ever had -- a country of our own. For that we need a king. We need you.

prompt: We all end up dead. It's only a question of how. And why.
completion: I'm no coward! I want what you want! But we need the nobles.

prompt: And the common man who bleeds on the battlefield, does he risk less?
completion: No. But from top to bottom this country has no sense of itself. Its nobles share allegiance with England and its clans war with each other. If you make enemies on both sides of the border, you'll end up dead.

prompt: Aye. But it won't let me dream.
completion: Wait! ...I respect what you said. But remember, these men have lands, castles. Much to risk.

prompt: Bring out our spearmen and set them in the field.
completion: Come, it'll help you sleep.

prompt: No English lord would trust an Irishman!
completion: Fine speech. Now what do we do?

prompt: Exactly.
completion: I thought I was dead when ya pulled that dagger!

prompt: The dogs have a scent. My scent. Someone must have given it to them.
completion: Who would do such a thing?

prompt: They've tricked us.
completion: What's the crazy man saying, Lord?

prompt: When I asked Evan about his drawing, well, he didn't remember doing it.
completion: We can't stop!

prompt: Of course. There is one more thing, Mrs. Treborn. And I feel bad for mentioning it...
completion: What?

prompt: Yesterday I had all the children draw pictures of what they wanted to be when they grew up. Most of them made drawings of what their parents did, but this...
completion: Thank you for showing it to me first. I'll... I'll take care of it. Can I have the picture?

prompt: I was going to show this to the principal, but I wanted to talk to you first.
completion: What is it?

prompt: Mrs. Treborn! I need to speak with you!
completion: I'm sorry, but can it wait til tonight? I'm already late for work --

prompt: No dances, just tell me.
completion: The hemorrhaging... the neural damage is irreparable. I'm frankly surprised he still has use of his motor functions.

prompt: Actually, these tests weren't available twenty years ago.
completion: So what did you find.

prompt: Evan wake up, oh please wake up!
completion: Nine, ten. And you're awake! Open your eyes, dammit!

prompt: It's worth a shot. I can arrange a controlled meeting. A careful dose of sedatives for Jason, some security, you and I monitoring. Evan comes in for a quick visit and with any luck, no more missing father complex.
completion: How soon?...

prompt: You'd be surprised how often they are.
completion: Well, he has been pushing me to meet his father, but I've been putting it off.

prompt: Plenty. Who knows? Maybe he's got severe coping problems about not having a father. Did you say the last blackout occurred when he was with his friend's dad.
completion: Come on, I doubt the answer's that simple.

prompt: If I had to guess, I'd say the blackouts are stress related.
completion: But he's seven. What kind of stress can he have?

prompt: Unfortunately, we've got nothing to work with. It's harder playing detective now.
completion: But you must have something to go on?

prompt: Well, the good news is that the results are negative. I've found no evidence in the way of lesions, hemorrhaging, tumors...
completion: And the bad news?

prompt: Why? What for?
completion: It could be extremely useful to jog his memory. See if he remembers anything new the next day. And I'll have the test results back in a few days.

prompt: Anything.
completion: A journal. Just have him write down everything he does.

prompt: Just tell me that Evan doesn't have Jason's illness...
completion: Look, Andrea, I'm sure he'll test negative for brain disorders. But there's something else you can try to monitor his memory.

prompt: Not according to his teacher. It just got me thinking about Jason and what if Evan's inherited his father's condition?
completion: Hold it, hold it, Andrea. Let's not jump to conclusions. I'll run some preliminary tests, see what we can rule out.

prompt: Don't worry. I'm gonna get you out of here.
completion: And you say he doesn't remember any of it?

prompt: You told me that on Parents' Weekend. Remember? Wait, that wasn't me. Or you.
completion: Just. Like. Jason.

completion: A champagne cocktail, please.

prompt: Good.
completion: What is your name?

prompt: Thank you, but I hardly think --

prompt: Well?
completion: You will find a market there for this ring. I am forced to sell it at a great sacrifice.

prompt: Yes, sir.
completion: Excuse me, but you look like a couple who are on their way to America.

prompt: Yes, I come, I will do it.
completion: I want you to take Miss Lund home.

completion: -- Tonight he forgot.

prompt: Yes, I come.

prompt: Goodnight.
completion: Goodnight, Monsieur Rick.

prompt: Monsieur Rick!

prompt: So could I. And I'm a poor businessman.
completion: I have a proposition for whoever has those letters. I will handle the entire transaction, get rid of the letters, take all the risk, for a small percentage.

prompt: Practically no one.
completion: If I could lay my hands on those letters, I could make a fortune.

prompt: No hurry. I'll have it sent over. Have a drink with me.

prompt: My dear Rick, when will you realize that in this world today isolationism is no longer a practical policy?
completion: I see the bus is in. I'll take my shipment with me.

prompt: Suppose we ask Sam. Maybe he'd like to make a change.

completion: Signor Ferrari thinks it might just be possible to get an exit visa for you.

prompt: My dear Mademoiselle, perhaps you have already observed that in Casablanca, human life is cheap. Good night, Mademoiselle.

prompt: That is also true, except for one destination, to return to occupied France.

completion: You needn't be concerned about me.

prompt: Yes.
completion: She tried everything to get them, and nothing worked. She did her best to convince me that she was still in love with me, but that was all over long ago. For your sake, she pretended it wasn't, and I let her pretend.

prompt: And I said I would never leave you.
completion: And you never will. But I've got a job to do, too. Where I'm going you can't follow. What I've got to do you can't be any part of. Now, now...

prompt: But what about us?
completion: We'll always have Paris. We didn't have, we'd lost it, until you came to Casablanca. We got it back last night.

prompt: No.
completion: Maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, but soon, and for the rest of your life.

prompt: When did you first find out he was alive?
completion: Just before you and I were to leave Paris together. A friend came and told me that Victor was alive. They were hiding him in a freight car on the outskirts of Paris. He was sick, he needed me. I wanted to tell you, but I, I didn't care. I knew, I knew you wouldn't have left Paris, and the Gestapo would have caught you. So I... well, well, you know the rest.

prompt: Why weren't you honest with me? Why did you keep your marriage a secret?
completion: Oh, it wasn't my secret, Richard. Victor wanted it that way. Not even our closest friends knew about our marriage. That was his way of protecting me. I knew so much about his work, and if the Gestapo found out I was his wife it would be dangerous for me and for those working with me.

prompt: And then?
completion: It wasn't long after we were married that Victor went back to Czechoslovakia. They needed him in Prague, but there the Gestapo were waiting for him. Just a two-line item in the paper: "Victor Laszlo apprehended. Sent to concentration camp." I was frantic. For months I tried to get word. Then it came. He was dead, shot trying to escape. I was lonely. I had nothing. Not even hope. Then I met you.

prompt: For the last time, put them on the table.
completion: If Laszlo and the cause mean so much to you, you won't stop at anything. All right, I'll make it easier for you.

prompt: Put them on the table.
completion: No.

prompt: -- All right. I tried to reason with you. I tried everything. Now I want those letters. Get them for me.
completion: I don't have to. I've got them right here.

prompt: No. Oh, Richard, I'm sorry. I'm sorry, but, but you, you are our last hope. If you don't help us, Victor Laszlo will die in Casablanca.

prompt: Please. Please listen to me. If you knew what really happened, if you only knew the truth --

prompt: Please.
completion: Your unexpected visit isn't connected by any chance with the letters of transit? It seems that as long as I have those letters I'll never be lonely.

prompt: Richard, I had to see you.
completion: You use "Richard" again? We're back in Paris.

prompt: The stairs from the street.
completion: I told you this morning you'd come around, but this is a little ahead of schedule. Well, won't you sit down?

prompt: No, Rick. No, you see, Victor Laszlo is my husband... and was, even when I knew you in Paris.
completion: How did you get in?

But the one who looked at me with such hatred... well, I'll be leaving Casablanca soon and we'll never see each other again. We knew very little about each other when we were in love in Paris. If we leave it that way, maybe we'll remember those days and not Casablanca, not last night.

prompt: Well, you can tell me now. I'm reasonably sober.

prompt: Why did you come back? To tell me why you ran out on me at the railway station?

prompt: It's about a girl who had just come to Paris from her home in Oslo. At the house of some friends she met a man about whom she'd heard her whole life, a very great and courageous man. He opened up for her a whole beautiful world full of knowledge and thoughts and ideals. Everything she knew or ever became was because of him. And she looked up to him and worshipped him with a feeling she supposed was love.
completion: Yes, that's very pretty. I heard a story once. As a matter of fact, I've heard a lot of stories in my time. They went along with the sound of a tinny piano playing in the parlor downstairs, "Mister, I met a man once when I was a kid," it'd always begin. Huh. I guess neither one of our stories was very funny. Tell me, who was it you left me for? Was it Laszlo, or were there others in between? Or aren't you the kind that tells?

prompt: I don't know the finish yet.
completion: Well, go on, tell it. Maybe one will come to you as you go along.

completion: Well, I did. Every one of them. Mostly I remember the last one. A wow finish. A guy standing on a station platform in the rain with a comical look on his face, because his insides had been kicked out.

prompt: In America they'd bring only a penny. I guess that's about all they're worth.

prompt: Here's looking at you, kid.

prompt: Are you ready Ilsa?

completion: I love you very much, my dear.

prompt: Yes, Victor, I was.
completion: I know how it is to be lonely.  Is there anything you wish to tell me?

completion: When I was in the concentration camp, were you lonely in Paris?

prompt: Yes. He said, "Ask your wife." I don't know why he said that.
completion: Ilsa, I --

prompt: He does. Could we have a table close to him?

prompt: Yes, I see. When I had trouble getting out of Lille, why didn't you leave me there? And when I was sick in Marseilles and held you up for two weeks and you were in danger every minute of the time, why didn't you leave me then?
completion: I meant to, but something always held me up. I love you very much, Ilsa.

prompt: But, Victor, if the situation were different, if I had to stay and there were only a visa for one, would you take it?
completion: Yes, I would.

prompt: No, Victor, no.
completion: No, Ilsa, I won't let you stay here. You must get to America. And believe me, somehow I will get out and join you.

prompt: We are only interested in two visas, Signor.
completion: Please, Ilsa, don't be hasty.

prompt: Goodnight.
completion: Goodnight.

prompt: Goodnight.
completion: Goodnight.

prompt: Be careful.
completion: I will, don't worry.

prompt: This time they really mean to stop me.
completion: Victor, I'm afraid for you.

prompt: You are very kind.

prompt: I can't get over you two. She was asking about you earlier, Rick, in a way that made me extremely jealous.
completion: I wasn't sure you were the same. Let's see, the last time we met --

prompt: Well then, perhaps you also ---
completion: -- This is Mr. Laszlo.

prompt: Hello, Rick.
completion: Oh, you've already met Rick, Mademoiselle?

prompt: -- Is what?
completion: Well, Mademoiselle, he's the kind of a man that, well, if I were a woman and I...  were not around, I should be in love with Rick. But what a fool I am talking to a beautiful woman about another man.

prompt: Rick? Who's he?
completion: Mademoiselle, you are in Rick's and Rick is --

prompt: Yes.
completion: He came from Paris with Rick.

prompt: Captain, the boy who is playing the piano, somewhere I have seen him.
completion: Sam?

prompt: I understand.
completion: Here it is.

prompt: Yes.
completion: But you didn't know she was at my place last night when you were. She came there for the letters of transit. Isn't that true, Ilsa?

prompt: Monsieur Blaine, I don't ask you to explain anything.
completion: I'm going to anyway, because it may make a difference to you later on. You said you knew about Ilsa and me.

prompt: Everything in order?
completion: All except one thing. There's something you should know before you leave.

prompt: No. It's all arranged.
completion: Good. I've got the letters right here, all made out in blank.

prompt: But we made a deal.
completion: Oh, never mind about that. You won't have any trouble in Lisbon, will you?

prompt: I brought the money, Monsieur Blaine.
completion: Keep it. You'll need it in America.

prompt: Monsieur Blaine, I don't know how to thank you.
completion: Oh, save it. We've still lots of things to do.

prompt: You love her that much?
completion: Apparently you think of me only as the leader of a cause. Well, I am also a human being.

prompt: You seem to know all about my destiny.
completion: I know a good deal more about you than you suspect. I know, for instance, that you are in love with a woman. It is perhaps strange that we both should be in love with the same woman. The first evening I came here in this cafe, I knew there was something between you and Ilsa. Since no one is to blame, I, I demand no explanation. I ask only one thing. You won't give me the letters of transit. All right. But I want my wife to be safe. I ask you as a favor to use the letters to take her away from Casablanca.

prompt: Yes, I get the point.
completion: I wonder if you do. I wonder if you know that you're trying to escape from yourself and that you'll never succeed.

prompt: What of it? Then it'll be out of it's misery.
completion: You know how you sound, Monsieur Blaine? Like a man who's trying to convince himself of something he doesn't believe in his heart. Each of us has a destiny, for good or for evil.

prompt: Don't you sometimes wonder if it's worth all this? I mean what you're fighting for?
completion: We might as well question why we breathe. If we stop breathing, we'll die. If we stop fighting our enemies, the world will die.

prompt: Had a close one, eh?
completion: Yes, rather.

prompt: Well, this might come in handy.
completion: Thank you.

prompt: I said, ask your wife.
completion: My wife?

prompt: There is. I suggest that you ask your wife.
completion: I beg your pardon?

prompt: My friend, you could make it a million francs, or three, my answer would still be the same.
completion: There must be some reason why you won't let me have them.

prompt: I appreciate it, but I don't accept it.
completion: I'll raise it to two hundred thousand.

prompt: Yes. I found that a very expensive hobby, too. But then I never was much of a businessman.
completion: Are you enough of a businessman to appreciate an offer of a hundred thousand francs?

prompt: What of it?
completion: Isn't it strange that you always happened to be fighting on the side of the underdog?

prompt: I'm not interested in politics. The problems of the world are not in my department. I'm a saloon keeper.
completion: My friends in the underground tell me that you have quite a record. You ran guns to Ethiopia. You fought against the fascists in Spain.

prompt: Right.
completion: You must know it's very important I get out of Casablanca. It's my privilege to be one of the leaders of a great movement. You know what I have been doing. You know what it means to the work, to the lives of thousands and thousands of people that I be free to reach America and continue my work.

prompt: Monsieur Blaine, I wonder if I could talk to you?

completion: Good morning.

prompt: Nothing important, but may I speak to him now?

prompt: Yes.

prompt: -- Thank you.

prompt: Thank you.

prompt: Merely to welcome you to Casablanca and wish you a pleasant stay. It is not often we have so distinguished a visitor.

prompt: I am Captain Renault, Prefect of Police.

The scanner shows it to be some sort of fault in the communications laser, down by the Emergency Air Lock. Can't pinpoint it exactly, but I'm going down there with a starsuit and try to find it.

prompt: I wish I had my board with me now. Even if I could only polish it once in awhile.
completion: Lieutenant Doolittle, this is Talby. Lieutenant?

prompt: Don't worry about it. We'll find out when it goes bad.

prompt: The waves at Malibu and Zuma were fantastic in the springs Talby. I can remember running out on the beach early spring mornings with my board and a wet suit...
completion: I can't seem to locate the malfunction exactly...

prompt: I can't talk to the others, but with time to myself, I think about back home, back home at Malibu. I used to surf a lot, Talby. I used to be a great surfer.
completion: Lieutenant Doolittle, I'm getting a definite malfunction on one of the closed-circuit computer systems...

completion: I'm getting something here, on this readout...

prompt: Phoenix Asteroids? Never heard of 'em.
completion: They are a body of asteroids that make a complete circuit of the universe once every 12.3 trillion years. The Phoenix Asteroids... From what I've heard, Doolittle, they glow... glow with all the colors of the rainbow. Nobody knows why. They just glow as they drift around the universe. Imagine all the sights they've seen in the time they've been travelling -- the birth and death of stars, things we'll never see. The universe is alive, Doolittle. I thought it was all empty, but it isn't. In between the stars, it's seething with light and gasses and dust. There are little pebbles drifting around, planets no one on Earth has ever seen... No one but the Phoenix Asteroids...

prompt: You'll have plenty of time for that, you know. Figure it this way: twenty years in space and we've only aged three, so there'll be plenty of time to stare around...
completion: You know, Doollttle, if we're going into the Veil Nebula, we may actually find a strange and beautiful thing: the Phoenix Asteroids. They should be passing through there about now...

prompt: ...Should spend some time below, see more of the rest of the ship...

prompt: Commander Powell, this is Doolittle. Ah, there's something serious come up, sir, and I have to ask you something.

prompt: What the hell are you doing?

prompt: He's got exposure.  He sees you starin' at fifteen to life, there's a chance you could roll over, cop a plea, who knows? Man's figured the odds...and he can't take a chance.

Overnight the government, the police, everything intended to protect the people had been turned against them.

completion: Forget?  You ask me to forget... Why, my ancestors would rise from their graves... and I'd only have to bury them again... A Firefly never forgets...

prompt: Bah!!
completion: THEN IT'S WAR!

prompt: Yes.
completion: How're ya fixed for ammunition?

prompt: That's it!  No man lives who can call a Firefly an upstart.
completion: Then it's war?

prompt: Once more!
completion: You upstart!

prompt: Give me that again!
completion: You worm!

prompt: That's what you think.
completion: You swine!

prompt: This has gone far enough!  This interruption is humiliating, to say the least...
completion: Well, why not say the least and get it over with?

completion: What can this mug offer you?  Wealth and family.  I can't give you wealth...  ...but we can have a little family of our own.

prompt: And Vera niece, too.
completion: When you get through with her feet, you can start on mine.  I haven't been to a chiropodist in two years...  If that's not an insult, I don't know what is.  Gloria, I love you.  I --

prompt: Go ahead.
completion: You don't understand.  This is my niece Vera.

prompt: Why yes.  I met you at the dog races -- say, you could have won that race if you tried a little harder.
completion: Excellency, may I present my niece.

prompt: I'll tell you what I'll do.  I'll give you Mrs. Teasdale as security.  or my jackknife.  If you want my advice, you'll take the jackknife... I've a better proposition...  Make it $25 and I'll give you a first mortgage on my son and I hope you foreclose.
completion: Your Excellency, haven't we met before?

prompt: Well, in the meantime, could you let me have $50 personally?
I'll keep the greetings -- but you can send back the good will... what we need right now is twenty million dollars.
completion: Twenty million dollars is a considerable sum...  I'll have to discuss that with my Minister of Finance.

prompt: That's even a greater honor.
completion: I bring you the greetings of my President and the good will of my people.

prompt: You know I think they think I should be king.  Although it would please me to govern the throng, suppose I were king and then everything went wrong.
completion: The king can do no wrong!

prompt: But -
completion: You satisfied your selfish whims, while nations tottered, dynasties rocked and the world plunged headlong into a chasm of chaos and oblivion --  Not bad, eh?

prompt: I said - I suspect the Secretary of War.
completion: THIS IS TREASON!!  What a fool I was to listen to your siren song and fall a helpless victim under the insidious spell of your irresistible charms --

prompt: I -- I may be wrong, but I suspect the Secretary of War.
completion: Don't bother me - I'm thinking -- What was that?

prompt: My purse has been stolen -- the plans of war are in it.
completion: WHAT  ?

prompt: Your Excellency, something terrible has just happened.
completion: That's all right.  I'll fix you right up.

prompt: I hope I'm not interrupting.
completion: Take a seat -- you're next.

prompt: Why -- why -- of course.
completion: You can call me Gloria too.  Gloria -- what a beautiful name.  When I was born my mother named me Gloria -- two minutes later she found out her mistake...

prompt: Oh, your Excellency, you take me off my feet.
completion: Gloria -- may I call you Gloria?

prompt: Now -- er --
completion: Well -- they might come better but they don't come any bigger... and the bigger the better.  The bigger the betta you've got on a horse, the more you lose, and speaking about horses, why don't you marry me. Come, come -- say yes and you'll never see me again.  I'll go 'way if it means your happiness...

prompt: Well, maybe I am a little headstrong...  But, you know, it's awfully hard to forget what he called me.
completion: Guard them with your life... don't leave them out of your sight...  If the enemy gets those papers  we're lost.  If they don't get them, we're lost.  Can't you see what I'm trying to tell you?  I love you...   Mrs. Teasdale, you're the salt of the earth.  They don't come any better than you...

prompt: Let him patch up his own breeches...
completion: Oh, won't you reconsider...

prompt: So -- you've come to ask for clemency! I'll give the enemy no quarter -- not a dime...
completion: But Your Excellency -- the Ambassador is here on a friendly visit...  He came to ask you to patch up the breach.

prompt: Oh, Your Excellency, I don't know what to say.
completion: I wouldn't know what to say either if I was in your place.  Maybe you can suggest something.

prompt: Oh, Rufus!
completion: All I can offer you is a Rufus over your head.

prompt: Why, that's the speech that Lincoln made at Gettysburg...
completion: He did?... I told my son not to leave it laying around... Where is son?

prompt: Your Excellency, you mustn't forget your appointment at the House of Representatives... Have you got your speech ready?
completion: I wrote a speech last night that'll knock them off their seats...  Four score and seven years ago, our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation --

prompt: You've made a wonderful impression. Your views are liberal... It is easy to see you have an open mind.
completion: That's what I get for dressing in a hurry.

prompt: If it's not asking too much --  For our information just for illustration  Tell us how you intend to run the nation.
completion: These are the laws of my administration: No one's allowed to smoke or tell a dirty joke -- And whistling is forbidden...

prompt: Your Excellency, the eyes of the world are upon you.  Notables from every land are gathered here in your honor --  This is a gala day for us.
completion: Well, a gal a day is enough for me. I couldn't handle any more.

prompt: Your Excellency!
completion: You're not so bad yourself, Mrs. Teasdale, when I look at you I can see that we're facing a crisis. We've got to balance the budget -- we've got to cut down everything including, you.

prompt: Why - er -- my husband passed away...  I was with him to the very end.
completion: No wonder he passed away.  I'd like to be with you to the very end. Can't you see what I'm trying to tell you -- I love you.

prompt: The future of Freedonia rests upon you.  Promise me you will follow in my husband's footsteps.
completion: I haven't been on the job five minutes and already she's making advances to me.  Not that I care -- but where is your husband?

prompt: In choosing you, I feel that I serve my country well.  I heartily endorse everything you stand for.
completion: Well, I won't stand for much.  And I won't stand for you if you don't show some improvement soon.  Look at your report card last month -- "D" in spelling...  six in behavior. Now who were the six?  A fine state of affairs -- no wonder you can't matriculate, now what were you saying?

prompt: What'll I do with this card?
completion: You can keep it -- I've got a whole pack...  Now what were you saying?

prompt: Oh, would you...?
completion: For you, I would do anything...

prompt: This is terrible!
completion: Mrs. Teasdale, I'm willing to pocket my pride and do anything I can to make up with his Excellency.

prompt: I didn't come here to be insulted.
completion: I shall report this indignity the my President.  Mrs. Teasdale,  I feel this regrettable occurrence will plunge our countries into war.

prompt: Gloria -- I've waited for years.  I won't be put off!  I love you!  I want you!  Can't you see that I'm at your feet?
completion: Gentlemen!  Gentlemen!

prompt: Oh.  Then there his somebody else?
completion: Well no -- not exactly -- but --

prompt: ...but would further cement the relations of our countries.
completion: Ambassador Trentino, I am indeed honored...  But you see - well - I --

prompt: Ambassador!  I am so anxious for you to meet our new dictator.
completion: Mrs. Teasdale -- no matter who rules Freedonia, to me you will always be the first lady of the land.

prompt: Your uncle has been such a friend to us in every crisis.  Without his country's financial aid --
completion: What is money?  Mrs. Teasdale, for you -- I would do anything.

prompt: If only we can get his Excellency to listen to reason...
completion: Perhaps he will listen to you...

prompt: Fine nothing!  I didn't want war... My plan was to marry Mrs. Teasdale and overthrow Firefly.
completion: Maybe you can still win the old dame over -- why not try to --

prompt: This is all Firefly's fault -- that idiot, that fool...
completion: I thought everything was working out fine.

completion: It is every woman's problem.  Who supplies the sons? -- the brothers? -- the husbands?  Who...

completion: Uncle, you can't do this!

prompt: With Mrs. Teasdale as my wife and Freedonia under my control --
completion: Maybe it's not going to be so easy. From what I've heard, Mrs. Teasdale is rather sweet on this Rufus T. Firefly.

prompt: If only I could find her. If only she could see me now, here, with such lovely kind friends. You, Mrs. Treves, and you, Mr. Treves. Then maybe she would love me as I am. I've tried to hard to be good.
completion: So that's the one you want to marry.

prompt: She has the face of an angel... She was an angel. She was so kind... so kind to me. It's not her fault, for in the fourth month of her maternal condition she was knocked down by an elephant. I'm sure I must have been a great disappointment to her.
completion: Oh no, Mr. Merrick. No. No son as loving as you are could ever be a disappointment.

prompt: Oh, yes.
completion: Oh... why Mr. Merrick she's beautiful.

completion: Oh Frederick.

completion: Frederick, just what is it that you are saying?

completion: Oh that's absurd, Frederick. No, no Frederick, that's all wrong! John is happier and more fulfilled now than he has ever been in his entire life. And, that is completely due to you.

completion: Oh, Freddie. What could that wretched vampire say to upset you?

prompt: Hmmm?
completion: ...Freddie! What's the matter? You've been like this all evening.

completion: More romances for John?

prompt: And here are my mother and father.
completion: You stay with me.

prompt: Do you?
completion: Yes.

prompt: I've only got until two o'clock tomorrow afternoon, when Carr Gomm meets him. Somehow, between now and then I've got to make John Merrick at least seem like an intelligent man... Why am I fooling myself? Nothing short of John delivering the Sermon on the Mount is going to sway Carr Gomm...
completion: John loves the house.

prompt: I'm sorry... I don't know either. I just don't know.
completion: Well, these things take time.

completion: I'm sure I don't know, Freddie.

prompt: I don't know. I can't explain it. If this is an intelligent man, trapped in the body of a monster, then I'm under a moral obligation to help free that mind, free that spirit as best I can, to help him live as full and content a life as possible. But! If he's an imbecile, who's body I can't treat and who's mind I can't touch, well, then my obligation is discharged. They can put him where they will; he won't be bothered, I won't be bothered, and everyone's conscience can remain free and untroubled. And that is my dilemma... what is in his mind?
completion: Perhaps you're just polishing a stone, endowing this Elephant Man with qualities he doesn't possess?

prompt: He is. I mean, I've always thought he was. I think he must be. Is he simple? Or is that just something I've wished upon him to make things simpler for myself?
completion: Frederick, why are you so interested in this particular case?

completion: But I thought you said that he was rather... simple?

completion: What do you mean?

prompt: No, I think a whiskey.
completion: Freddie?... Freddie, don't look so discouraged.

prompt: It's only a physical problem. He has trouble with certain sounds because of the constrictive deformity of the mouth. prompt: He's doing very well. In fact that's why I came to see you. If the committee had a chance to speak with him, hear him say a few words for himself, I'm sure they would see him as a patient, rather than as a violation of the rules.
completion: A few words? I thought he was imbecile?

prompt: Ah, no sir. I had planned to see them in the morning.

completion: Have you contacted the British Home and the Royal Hospital?

completion: I certainly sympathize with your problem, Treves... Why don't you try the British Home, or the Royal Hospital for perhaps they would have a place for him.

completion: Oh, is he a friend of yours?

prompt: Yes sir.

prompt: Well sir, he's quite seriously deformed, and I fear the other patients would find him... rather shocking.

completion: Why isn't he in the General Ward, then?

prompt: Indeed!
completion: A hospital is no place for secrecy, Mr. Treves. Doctors spiriting hooded figures about are liable to cause comment. Why wasn't this patient properly admitted, and why is he in isolation? Is he contagious?

prompt: Don't be mad. This muck can kill you.
completion: Don't be frightened. He won't hurt you.

prompt: You've acquired a taste for this?

prompt: Three quarters of an hour.

prompt: I know no way to mince it in love, but directly to say "I love you". What! A speaker is but a prater; a rhyme is but a ballad. A good leg will fall; a straight back will stoop; a black beard will turn white; a curl'd pate will grow bald; a fair face will wither; a full eye will wax hollow; but a good heart, Kate, is the sun and the moon, or rather the sun and not the moon; for it shines bright and never changes, but keeps his course truly.
completion: How long has this man been here?

prompt: What say you, fair one? That the tongues of men are full of deceits?
completion: Oui, dat de tongues of de mans is be full of deceits.

prompt: An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel.
completion: O bon Dieu! les langues des hommes sont pleines de tramperies.

prompt: O fair Katharine, if you will love me soundly with your French heart, I will be glad to hear you confess it brokenly with your English tongue. Do you like me, Kate?
completion: Pardonnez-moi, I cannot tell vat is "like me".

completion: Your majesty shall mock at me; I cannot speak your England.

prompt: Oh no?
completion: Oh no... no... you're a Romeo.

completion: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.

prompt: Have you read it?
completion: No, but I certainly shall.

prompt: Romance!

prompt: Tell me about it, please!
completion: It's very difficult to put into a nutshell, but I should say the theater is the shrine of the imagination, where one may suspend disbelief and travel anywhere in the world, to any time you desire. You may look over the shoulders of kings, unobserved, battle with ruthless tyrants, and marry the beautiful princess, all in the space of a few hours. Onstage you may be whoever you wish to be, do anything you please, and always, always live happily ever after. The theatre is all the brightest and best things of the world, Mr. Merrick. It is lights and music, gaiety and joy. It's... well, it's romance.

prompt: Alas, no.
completion: Well you must go. It is one of the most beautiful places on earth. Of course, I'm rather partial.

prompt: Well, even to work there would be wonderful. Is it beautiful?
completion: You've never been?

prompt: Mr. Treves says that you are in the theatre. Do you live there?
completion: Oh no, Mr. Merrick. I just work there.

prompt: She's very pretty, your mother.

prompt: I want you to know that I don't go about giving my pictures to just anyone.

prompt: Oh, no.

prompt: Good day...!
completion: I've brought you some things. I hope you'll like, Mr. Merrick. I hope you don't think it too forward.

prompt: Well, it's all quite... I've never heard... It's quite...
completion: Yes.

prompt: Is he... dying then?

prompt: It's all arranged. I'll send over some evening gowns for the sisters that you select to accompany Mr. Merrick. You'll be using the Royal entrance and Princess Alexandra herself will be there to welcome him to her private box.

prompt: John, I'd like you to meet one of the brightest lights of the British stage, Mrs. Kendal. Mrs. Kendal, John Merrick.
completion: Good day, Mr. Merrick.

prompt: Oh, yes.
completion: You know, I saw you once there, in London. You're a great attraction.

completion: Say hello to London for me. I miss her.

prompt: Of course! You want out?
completion: Yes.

Like rotten mushrooms, like an excessively chlorinated swimming pool, like a tuna fish's retirement party. They all stink. From the Queen of England to Bonanza Jellybean, they stink.

prompt: I've always been proud of the way nature singled me out. It's the people who have been deformed by society I feel sorry for. I've been steady moving for eleven years and some months. Maybe I should rest up for a spell, I'm not as young as I used to be.
completion: Shit O goodness, you won't be thirty for another year, and you're more beautiful than ever.

prompt: A born freak can only go uphill.
completion: Freak, schmeek. Most of us are freaks in one way or another. Try being born a male Russian countess into a white middle class Baptist family in Mississippi and you'll see what I mean.

prompt: Tired...
completion: That's the very first time in the eons that I've known you that I've ever heard you complain. And now you're tired, poor darling.

prompt: I think I found something...
completion: To my own special Sissy. Cheers! And welcome. So my letter brought ya flying, eh? Where were you? Salt Lake City? La Conner? Well, I may have a little surprise for you. But first, tell me about yourself. It's been six months, hasn't it? In some circles that's half a year. How are you?

prompt: Holy shit...
completion: Justin?

prompt: Shit! Do not do that! Where the fuck are you?
completion: I'm in the Second Containment area. It's pitch black in here. There must have been a coolant leak. Man, this shit is everywhere. I can't see a damn thing.

prompt: ...do you copy?
completion: Uh, yeah Coop, I'm still here.

prompt: You still need the rope? I thought you were one a those spacemen with ice in ya veins.
completion: I'd rather be on the rope and not need it than need it and not have it. Now step aside, old man.

prompt: I can see why they sent you along.
completion: So if the ship didn't blow up, what happened?

prompt: That means top-secret, Cooper.
completion: I heard it.

prompt: Ballast.
completion: I am your best friend. I am a lifesaver and a heartbreaker...

prompt: Will it work?
completion: It worked for Weir. Prep the tanks.

prompt: ...and the gravity drive goes where no man has gone before.
completion: You prep the gravity couches. I'm going to manually arm those explosives.

prompt: Captain Miller, we're ready to repressurize the Clark.
completion: On my way.

prompt: But Justin...
completion: I'll get him.

prompt: The containment, Second Containment...
completion: Hold on, Coop...

prompt: We have a man down...
completion: Coop, where are you...

prompt: You've had plenty EVA, Coop, it's Justin's turn. Stay on station. If anything happens...
completion: I'll be all over it.

prompt: You're convinced the crew could still be alive? After seven years?
completion: ...come on, Skipper, I already put my shoes on...

prompt: EVERYBODY SHUT UP! Let the man speak.
completion: From what?

prompt: This is Cooper, what the hell do you do on this ship, anyway?
completion: ...cancel our leave and send us out on some bullshit mission...!

prompt: Okay, listen up. As you all know by now, we have an addition to our crew. Dr. Weir, this is: Starck, navigation; Smith, pilot, Justin, ship's engineer --
completion: You can call him Baby-bear, he loves that...

prompt: Time to play Spam in the can.
completion: Don't start with me, Cooper.

prompt: Smith, clear that airlock, man, I'm coming in.
completion: Roger that.

prompt: We're still venting trace gasses, gimme twenty minutes to plug the hole.
completion: Solid as a rock.  Hey, Smith...

prompt: What about the accumulator...?
completion: It's holding... She's holding...!

prompt: You're sucking too much nitrogen in your mix.
completion: We'll have to re-route through the port conduit to the APU.

prompt: Shit, Smith, you're going Biblical on me.
completion: You know what happened to the Tower of Babel, don't you? It fell down.

prompt: What?
completion: You heard me. This ship, it's crazy: trying to go faster'n light, that's like the Tower of Babel.

prompt: You been out there a long time. Trying to break my record?
completion: I'd rather spend the next twelve hours Outside than another five minutes in this can. This ship is bad. It watches you.

prompt: What you saw could have been an optical effect caused by gravitational distortion.
completion: I know what I saw and it wasn't a fucking "optical effect!"

prompt: I don't know what happened to Justin.
completion: I'm telling you, I saw it...

prompt: You weren't there. I saw it.
completion: Saw what, Mr. Cooper? What did you really see, because what you're describing is not physically possible...

prompt: It was like... nothing was there... and then Justin appeared and the Core... became metal...
completion: No, he didn't.

prompt: The Event Horizon only had life support for eighteen months. It seems impossible, but in light of the transmission... I have to think that someone has managed to endure until now.
completion: Skipper, do we get hazard pay for this?

prompt: Coffee.
completion: No, thank you.

prompt: Damn, Dr. Weir, don't scare us like that. Coffee?
completion: What?

prompt: What...?
completion: Run!

prompt: I'm gonna activate the emergency beacon.
completion: Hurry.

prompt: I don't know the process, Dr. Weir was the expert...
completion: I don't want to go where the last crew went. I'd rather be dead.

prompt: There must be a way! What about Engineering?
completion: Can you shut it down?

prompt: You're okay now, it's over...
completion: How? The Bridge is gone.

prompt: I don't know, the screens are dead...!
completion: Let me breathe, let me breathe...

prompt: It is not.
completion: What's happening?

prompt: Oh God...
completion: Is that an offer?

prompt: Oh, God, DJ, what do I... how do I...
completion: Please... kill...

prompt: Weir. He used one of the explosives from the Corridor.
completion: Please...

prompt: DJ. The Clark's gone. Smith and Cooper are dead.
completion: What happened?

prompt: "Save yourself. From Hell."  What are you saying, are you saying that this ship is possessed?
completion: No. I don't believe in that sort of thing.  But if Dr. Weir is right, this ship has passed beyond the boundaries of our universe, of reality. Who knows where this ship has been... What it's seen...  And what it's brought back with it.

prompt: Hear what?
completion: It sounds like "ex infera:" "ex," from; "infera," the ablative case of "inferi." "Hell."

prompt: It gets worse.
completion: Do you hear it? Right there.

prompt: They thought it said, "Liberatis me," "Save me," but it's not "me." It's "tutemet:" "Save yourself."
completion: It's not a distress call. It's a warning.

prompt: I've been listening to the transmission. And I think Houston made a mistake in the translation.
completion: Go on.

prompt: No.
completion: What is it?

prompt: "Another man?" Who?
completion: I, I tried to go back for him, to save him, but I couldn't get to him in time. The fire... Have you ever seen fire in zero-gravity? It's like a liquid, it slides over everything. It was like a wave breaking over him, a wave of fire. And then he was gone.  I never told anyone until now. But this ship knew, DJ. It knows about the Goliath, it knows about Corrick. It knows our secrets. It knows what we're afraid of.  And now you're going to tell me it's carbon dioxide.

prompt: We'll make it.
completion: Of course not. Justin just climbed into the airlock because he felt like it. Just one of those things.  I swore I'd never lose another man. I came close today. Real close.

prompt: I don't need sleep, DJ. I need answers.
completion: He'll live... if we ever make it back.

prompt: Goddammit, DJ, it was not a hallucination! I saw a man, he was on fire. And then he disappeared.
completion: To conserve our oxygen, we should severely restrict our activity. Anyone who can should get some sleep.

prompt: His vitals are stable, but he's unresponsive to stimuli. He might wake up in fifteen minutes. He might not wake up at all.
completion: Carbon dioxide poisoning produces hallucinations, impaired judgement...

prompt: No time. We need whatever's left in our suits to repair the Clark. Like it or not, this is the only oxygen for three billion kilometers.
completion: How is he?

prompt: And this is mission specialist Dr. William Weir. We all know where we're going. Dr. Weir is going to tell us why.
completion: We haven't tested the air yet. It could be contaminated...

prompt: He's a rescue technician. Peters, medical technician. DJ...
completion: Trauma.

prompt: His peritoneum has ruptured...
completion: One thing at a time, let's keep him breathing. Start the drip, 15cc's fibrinogen, Christ, he's bleeding out...

prompt: He's crashing...
completion: Intubate, pure oxygen feed, get the nitrogen out of his blood...

prompt: Pressure?
completion: 90 over 50 and falling... .

prompt: You didn't hear it? You must have heard it!
completion: I've got a pulse, he's alive...

prompt: A power drain --
completion: What's wrong?

prompt: Nothing. It's nothing.
completion: What's happening...?

prompt: Don't thank me, Bill. I'm not doing you any favors.
completion: What's wrong?

prompt: It's against my better judgement, but I'll run this by the Man downstairs. You'll know my decision by the end of the day.
completion: Thank you.

prompt: That ship was lost in deep space, seven years ago. If the Titanic sailed into New York harbor, I'd find it more plausible.  Houston wants Aerospace to send out a search and rescue team, investigate the source of the transmission. If it really is the Event Horizon, they'll attempt a salvage.  We need you to prepare a detailed briefing on the ship's systems for the salvage crew...
completion: A written briefing can't possibly anticipate the variables on a mission like this. I have to go with them.

prompt: I wouldn't bring you here on a hoax. Houston confirms the telemetry and I.D. codes.
completion: It's the Event Horizon. She's come back.

prompt: I apologize for the short notice, Bill, but we've had something come up that requires your immediate attention. Lyle?
completion: Incredible... These are the same coordinates before the ship disappeared... this, this happened? This isn't some kind of hoax?

prompt: The Lewis and Clark just returned from patrol in the asteroid belt, she's docked in bay four.
completion: You wanted to see me, Admiral?

prompt: Some things you don't get over.
completion: I want our best people on this. Where's Miller?

prompt: He doesn't belong on this mission. Responsible or not, he blames himself. He's too close to it.  And then there's his wife.
completion: It's been two years since she died. He's over it.

prompt: Does he know that?
completion: What's on your mind?

prompt: The official inquiry blamed Weir's design for the ship's loss.
completion: That doesn't mean a damn thing. They were looking for a scapegoat and Weir fit the bill. But he's not responsible for what happened to the ship.

prompt: You're not seriously considering sending him?
completion: You don't just dismiss Bill Weir. The man held Oppenheimer's chair at Princeton. If the Event Horizon had worked, he would have gone down in history as the greatest mind in physics since Einstein.

prompt: It's not that simple.  Lyle, play the recording for Dr. Weir.
completion: Navigation Control tried to hail the vessel. This was the only response.

prompt: Oh my god OH MY GOD...
completion: Starck!

prompt: "The dark inside..."? I don't understand.
completion: From the Other Place...

prompt: The dark inside me.
completion: ...It's inside and it eats and eats until there's nothing left.

prompt: It won't stop, it goes on and on and on...
completion: What does?

prompt: I'm going in.
completion: What, Justin, what shows you?

prompt: I've reached another containment door. This thing's huge...
completion: That's the Second Containment Seal. Beyond that, engineering.

prompt: We still have pressure. The radiation count's steady at 7 millirads an hour.
completion: Background radiation. Perfectly safe.

prompt: I built it.
completion: You've reached the First Containment Seal. The engineering decks are on the other side.

prompt: ...is zero. That's what the singularity does: it folds space, so that point A and point B coexist in the same space and time. After the ship passes through this gateway, space returns to normal.  It's called a gravity drive.
completion: How do you know all this?

prompt: But I can't... I gotta get out of here... Skipper, please...
completion: Justin. I won't let you die.

prompt: ...I don't want to die...!
completion: You're not going to die! Not today! I want you to do exactly as I say and I'm gonna get you out of there, alright?

prompt: Justin.
completion: Skipper, you gotta help me...

prompt: Almost done, I just gotta check one thing...
completion: Patch me through to him.

prompt: Yes, sir!
completion: Justin, finish your sweep.

prompt: Start the countdown.
completion: Okay. We do it the hard way. Deck by deck, room by room. Starck, deploy the umbilicus. I believe you're up for a walk, Mr. Justin. Go get your bonnet on.

prompt: Someone sent that message. Admiral, you have to put me on that ship.
completion: Everything green on my boards, Skipper.

prompt: The crew? Could they still be alive?
completion: The ship had life support systems for eighteen months. They're been gone seven years.

prompt: This is not about my reputation! This is not about me at all!  The Event Horizon was created for one reason: to go faster than light. Imagine mankind exploring new solar systems, colonizing new worlds. Seven years ago, we didn't just lose the ship and the crew. We lost the dream.  I have to go.
completion: Since the initial transmission, there's been no further contact. Just the beacon, every two minutes.

prompt: I designed the ship's propulsion system. I am the only person capable of evaluating the performance of the gravity drive. You can't send a Search and Rescue team out there alone and expect them to succeed. That would be like... like sending an auto- mechanic to work on the shuttle.
completion: I can understand your desire to redeem your reputation, Dr. Weir, but it doesn't factor into this.

prompt: Dr. Weir, Admiral Hollis would like to see you as soon as possible.
completion: Dr. Weir, you have no experience with salvage procedures.

prompt: Thanks.
completion: This is Weir.

prompt: Peters. We need to know what happened to the crew. Before it happens to us.
completion: I'll get back to the log. But on the bridge, I won't go back, back in there...

prompt: That's a negative, Starck.
completion: Justin.

prompt: I can run the image through a series of filters, try to clean it up.
completion: Do it.

prompt: I can use the station in Medical, keep an eye on Justin...
completion: Fine. Starck, I want you to repeat the bio-scan...

prompt: Yeah. I'm -- I'm okay.
completion: Peters, I want you to go through the ship's log, see if we can't find some answers.

prompt: Peters...
completion: ...you okay?

prompt: Can anybody hear me...
completion: Skipper...

prompt: ...how's the client?
completion: Crystallized.

prompt: Frozen.
completion: Justin, check the containment for radiation leaks. Peters...

prompt: I found one.
completion: Alive?

prompt: Everything's been shut down. Conserving power, I guess. Green light on the hull, it's intact.
completion: The science workstation has power, I'll see if I can find the crew from here.

prompt: Okay. I'm on the bridge.
completion: What you got, Peters?

prompt: The blood came from somewhere, Peters...
completion: There's no one here, Skipper.

prompt: I can see the hatch.
completion: Starck, you still showing those readings?

prompt: Peters is right, no one's here.
completion: I don't know, this place is really dark, I can't see a thing...

prompt: That means they didn't abandon ship.
completion: So where are they? Starck, any luck with the bio-scan?

prompt: Jesus its huge.
completion: Ice crystals everywhere. This place is a deep freeze.

prompt: We've got pressure.
completion: Clear and open on my mark. Three... two... one... mark.

prompt: No, no, its alright. I talked to my ex, he'll keep Denny over Christmas and I'll get him this summer.  Goddam it, Skipper... I haven't seen him in two months.
completion: I am sorry. But now we have to go to work.

prompt: Just loading the last of the CO2 scrubbers.  Good for four months.
completion: I put in for a replacement for you but no one...

prompt: NOOO!
completion: What's the hold up?

prompt: Starck... Cooper...
completion: You can't have them. Go to hell.

prompt: You're lying...!
completion: I'm not asking you to believe me. You'll see for yourself... and so will your crew. You're all coming with me.

prompt: Better if I just show you.
completion: There is no Devil. There is no God. There is only... NOTHING.

prompt: I'm not the Devil.
completion: Then what, what are you? Tell me...

prompt: You know.
completion: You want me to believe you're the Devil, well, I don't, that's bullshit!

prompt: Your fear. Do you remember the Goliath, Miller?
completion: What are you?

prompt: Weir is dead.
completion: Then who the fuck are you?

prompt: If you miss me, you'll blow out the hull. You'll die too.
completion: What makes you think I'll miss?

prompt: What are you talking about?
completion: Do you know what a singularity is, Miller? Does your mind truly fathom what a black hole is?  It is NOTHING. Absolute and eternal NOTHING. And if God is Everything, then I have seen the Devil.  It's a liberating experience.

prompt: Your eyes...
completion: I don't need them anymore. Where we're going, we won't need eyes to see.

prompt: I told you... She won't let you leave...
completion: Son of a bitch!

prompt: You can't leave. She won't let you.
completion: Just get your gear back onto the Lewis and Clark, doctor, or you'll find yourself looking for a ride home.

prompt: You... You can't do that!
completion: Watch me.

prompt: What about my ship?
completion: We will take the Lewis and Clark to a safe distance and then launch tac missiles at the Event Horizon until I am satisfied that she has been destroyed.  Fuck this ship.

prompt: Don't... don't do this...
completion: It's done.

prompt: You're insane. You've lost your mind.
completion: Maybe you're right. But it's still my command, and I have leeway to abort when I feel there is an unacceptable threat to my crew. And I think there is.  Starck, download all the files from the Event Horizon's computers. Coop, Smith, finish moving the CO2 scrubbers back onto the Clark.

prompt: You can't, your orders are specific...
completion: "...to rescue the crew and salvage the ship." The crew is dead, Dr. Weir. This ship killed them. And now it's killing us.

prompt: That's exactly what we don't have, Doctor.
completion: We're leaving.

prompt: The "Other Place," what is that...?
completion: I DON'T KNOW!  I don't know. There's a lot of things going on here that I don't understand. Truth takes time.

prompt: Where has it been for the past seven years?
completion: I don't know...

prompt: To what? Where did this ship go? Where did you send it?
completion: I don't know...

prompt: You said this ship creates a gateway...
completion: Yes...

prompt: That's bullshit and you know it! You built this fucking ship and all I've heard from you is bullshit!
completion: What do you want me to say?

prompt: I want to know what caused that noise. I want to know why one of my crew tried to throw himself out of the airlock.
completion: Thermal changes in the hull could have caused the metal to expand and contract very suddenly, causing reverberations --

prompt: Is that your "expert opinion?" The only answer we've had out of you is "I don't know."
completion: Justin just tried to kill himself. The man is clearly insane.

prompt: I think I can stabilize the fields around the singularity, that should prevent another power drain.
completion: Do it.

prompt: Check the Core for radiation. Carbon dioxide may be the least of our worries.
completion: We're a long way from home and we're in a bad place. Let's not make it worse. If anyone has any constructive suggestions, now is the time.

prompt: The Core...!
completion: We don't get the power back, our air's gonna go bad.

prompt: I don't know.
completion: We barely have enough power for life support as it is, if we can't stop the drain, we're not gonna make it.

prompt: Intense gravitational fields effect the passage of time, it's possible...  Black holes make sense on paper, it's all math, you see, but as to what really happened...  The Event Horizon has passed beyond our plane of reality, and like Lazarus, returned from the dead.
completion: What the hell is that? Dr. Weir?

prompt: Exactly. The ship's internal clock is off by seven years.
completion: Explanation?

prompt: The Event Horizon's computer think's it's 2034.
The date.
completion: What about it?

prompt: Your black hole damn near ripped my ship apart. It may have killed one of my men.  No one goes near that thing.
completion: You have something, Dr. Weir?

prompt: I want this room sealed. The Second Containment is off limits.
completion: There's no danger. The black hole is contained behind three magnetic fields, it's under control.

prompt: If it worked.
completion: If it worked, yes.

prompt: It's insane.
completion: "Insane?" The finest astronauts fought to be posted to this ship. It would take the Lewis and Clark a thousand years to reach our closest star. The Event Horizon could be there in a day...

prompt: It's complicated...
completion: How much time do you need? We have seventeen hours and forty-two minutes. Now: what is in the Core?

prompt: It's possible that a burst of gravity waves escaped from the Core, distorting space-time. They could be what hit the Lewis and Clark.
completion: What could cause them?  What's in the Core?

prompt: One of my men is down. I want to know what happened to him.
completion: Hold on, what's this "gravitational distortion?"

prompt: Dr. Weir's right. Get on board the Event Horizon. I'll meet you at the airlock.
completion: Yes.

prompt: They're empty, Dr. Weir. Moving forward.
completion: It beats dying, Mister Smith.

prompt: Negative.
completion: No one?

prompt: Captain Miller, the foredecks are just ahead.
completion: Any survivors?

prompt: In an emergency, the charges detonate in series, destroying the central section and separating the personnel areas from the rest of the ship. That way, if the gravity drive malfunctions, the crew could use the foredecks as a lifeboat.
completion: Easy, Peters, we're okay, we're okay. Let's finish the sweep.

prompt: Peters and I will search the forward decks. Justin, take Engineering. No hot-dogging, not on this one, alright?
completion: I can see that, what're they for?

prompt: -- once we've secured the ship, that's the way it is!  I need you to guide us from the comm station. This is where I need you. Help us to do our job.
completion: You're in the central corridor. It connects the personnel areas to Engineering.

prompt: Once the ship is secured, we'll bring you on board --
completion: That is not acceptable --

prompt: Dr. Weir, I need you on the bridge.
completion: Captain, I didn't come out here to sit on your bridge, I need to be on that ship...

prompt: Smith, use the arm and lock us onto that antennae cluster.
completion: Be careful. It's not a load bearing structure...

prompt: NSA encryption specialists have deciphered some of the message...
completion: That's the engineering containment. And there's the main airlock. We can dock there.

prompt: That's what we're here to find out.
completion: What does it say?

prompt: It was the ship's maiden voyage, to test the drive. The Event Horizon moved to safe distance using ion thrusters. They received the go-ahead to activate the gravity drive.  And the ship vanished from all our scopes. No radar contact, no enhanced optical, no radio contact of any kind. They disappeared without a trace.  Until now.
completion: Where has it been for the last seven years?

prompt: I've been authorized to brief you and the crew once we reach Neptune space.
completion: Until then, do what you're told and stay out of my way.

prompt: Captain Miller, I appreciate this opportunity...
completion: Doctor Weir, my crew is not going on your mission because we want to. We were pulled off a well deserved leave, to be sent out to the middle of nowhere, and no one's even told us why.

prompt: Captain Miller, I just want to say...
completion: The clock is running, Dr. Weir. If you'll follow the rest of the crew, they'll show you to the gravity tanks.

prompt: Where is it, where is it...
completion: Smith? Smith! Fuck!

prompt: No, no, we just got her back together...
completion: Get out of there now!

prompt: One of the explosives is missing from the corridor. I think Weir may have put it on the Clark.
completion: Get off the Clark now and wait for me at the airlock.

prompt: Smith, get out of there...
completion: Come again, Skipper?

prompt: What is it, Smith?
completion: I just saw Weir, I think he was messing around on the Clark.

prompt: Alright. Prep the Clark for launch. I'll find her.
completion: Skipper...

prompt: Now what?
completion: She was right behind me, I turn around, she's gone. She could be anywhere.

prompt: Thank you.
completion: Captain, we got a problem.

prompt: Sir.
completion: Get outside, go back to work. I'll join you shortly.

prompt: ...you break all the laws of physics, you think there won't be a price? You already killed the first crew...
completion: That's enough!

prompt: We don't have time, Smith. In twenty hours we run out of air.
completion: Understood.

prompt: I'm here, Smith, how's the Clark?
completion: I've found a six inch fracture in the outer hull. We should be able to repair it and re-pressurize, it's gonna take some time.

prompt: You heard me, Smith. Peters, are you with me?
completion: Captain Miller, you copy?

prompt: They're gone.
completion: But...

prompt: We're losing pressure at 280 liters a second and our oxygen tanks are cracked. In three minutes, our atmosphere will be gone. We are fucking dead.
completion: No one's dying on my watch, Smith! What about the reserve tanks?

prompt: Do we have enough time for a weld?
completion: We don't have time to fart.

prompt: Smith, where the hell have you been?!
completion: We have a situation here...

prompt: Starck, give me a read.
completion: Captain Miller...

prompt: Love to.
completion: It is now.  We're locked in.

prompt: Starck...
completion: Put it through TACS. Smith, you up for a flyby?

prompt: Where is it?
completion: Proximity warning! 900, 800 meters, 700... we're right on top of it, we're gonna hit!

prompt: I noticed. Starck, anybody home?
completion: 1500 meters. We're getting too close...

prompt: Dr. Weir...!
completion: We've got some weather.

prompt: I guess we're about to find out. Keep us slow and steady.
completion: Yes, sir.

prompt: What are you trying to say? "If God had intended Man to fly, he would have given us wings?"
completion: Something like that, yeah.

prompt: We're all on edge, Smith. We're a long way out...
completion: That's not it. That ship was built to go faster than light... That's just wrong, it goes against everything we know...

prompt: We have a lock on the Event Horizon's navigation beacon. It's in the upper ionosphere, we're in for some chop.
completion: Bring us in tight. Starck, get on the horn, see if anyone's listening...

prompt: ...Make your approach vector negative fourteen degrees...
completion: One-four degrees...

prompt: What is that?
completion: Heading three-three-four...

prompt: Locked and cocked.
completion: Jesus...

prompt: He's dead...
completion: I don't like it either, but you know the rules: we get the call, we go. Is the course locked in?

prompt: Miller, he's back, he was in the tank...
completion: Weir.

prompt: We're armed. This fucker's ready to blow...
completion: ...repeat, we're armed...

prompt: I'll do it --
completion: No. I'll be right back.

prompt: Blow it up?
completion: We blow the Corridor. Use the foredecks as a lifeboat, separate it from the rest of the ship. We stay put...

prompt: We've got to shut it down, we've got to...
completion: BLOW THE FUCKER UP.

prompt: Whatever was on that bridge wasn't Weir.
completion: Weir activated the drive. He's sending us to the Other Place.

prompt: Five seconds.
completion: Weir can't be alive.

prompt: You better hurry. He's engaged the override, we can't open the inner door.
completion: Tuck yourself into a crouched position, shut your eyes as tight as you can!

prompt: Stay here! Don't stop working!
completion: I'm on my way, Starck.

prompt: What?
completion: He's awake, he's in the airlock, he's not wearing a suit.

prompt: What's going on in there, Starck?
completion: Justin's in the airlock.

prompt: I'm going outside to work on the Clark. And Starck... don't tell anyone what you just told me. We've got enough to worry about.
completion: Miller, come in...

prompt: What I want is to survive the next ten hours.
completion: Nine hours and twenty-two minutes.

prompt: If you knew it was impossible, then why'd you waste my time?
completion: I thought you wanted an answer. And that's the only one I have.

prompt: Starck, do you know how crazy that sounds? It's impossible.
completion: I know that.
