prompt: Friend?
completion: A companion. A female. Like me, so she won't hate me.

prompt: What can I do?
completion: There is something I want.  A friend.

prompt: I don't know.
completion: Then perhaps I believe in evil after all.

prompt: Trace memories in the brain, perhaps.
completion: Stolen memories. Stolen and hazy. They taunt me in my dreams. I've seen a beautiful woman lying back and beckoning for me to love her. Whose woman was this? I've seen boys playing, splashing about in a stream. Whose childhood friends were these?  Who am I?

prompt: You're wrong. Do you know I knew how to play this?
completion: In which part of me did this knowledge reside? In these hands? In this mind? In this heart?  And reading and speaking. Not things learned... so much as things remembered.

prompt: What of my soul? Do I have one? Or was that a part you left out?  Who were these people of which I am comprised? Good people? Bad people?
completion: Materials. Nothing more.

prompt: Why, Victor? Why? What were you thinking?
completion: There was something at work in my soul which I do not understand.

prompt: I see it before me.
completion: I'm not sure I believe. But then I had no one to instruct me. I had no mother... and my father abandoned me at birth.

prompt: How dare you. You're disgusting and evil.
completion: Evil?  Do you believe in evil?

prompt: Fine words from a child killer. You who murdered my brother.
completion: Your crime... as well as mine.

prompt: Then why am I here? What did you want with me?
completion: More to the point, why am I here? What did you want with me?  What does one say to one's Maker, having finally met him face to face? Milton gave it voice.  Did I request thee, Maker, from my clay to mould me Man? Did I solicit thee from Darkness to promote me?

prompt: Kill me and have done with it.
completion: Kill you? Hardly that.

prompt: How did you find me?
completion: The letters in your journal. That and a geography book.  Your Elizabeth sounds lovely.

prompt: You speak.
completion: Yes, I speak. And read. And think... and know the ways of Man.  I've been waiting for you. Two months now.

prompt: Fine.
completion: Come warm yourself if you like.

prompt: Read him one of the old letters and rephrase it. We'll say it came today. It'll set his mind at ease.
completion: Are you all right?

prompt: Elizabeth. If it's true, travel into Germany would be banned. You'd never get near Ingolstadt.  Besides, they're only rumors.
completion: And not a word of them to Father. He's agitated enough not hearing from Victor.

prompt: So have I
completion: I should go. I should leave today.

prompt: It's been months. It's not like him.
completion: Something's wrong. I know it.  I've heard rumors of cholera spreading south from Hamburg.

prompt: He was almost expelled for calling one of his professors a "pompous...  Fellow..."
completion: Nothing. Still nothing.

prompt: And you look so lovely.
completion: Must've been a terrible row.

prompt: One-two-three, one-two-three, twirl- two-three...
completion: You dance so beautifully together.

prompt: Elizabeth, really! He's quite mad!
completion: Scandalous! What would your dear mother say?

prompt: That's the nature of all progress, William. Don't let your brother sway you otherwise.
completion: Quite right!

prompt: Poor William! What indignant tears!
completion: There, there... shhh...

prompt: Claude rode over there to see if held lost track of time. They say he never arrived.
completion: It's far too late for him to still be out.

prompt: Have you seen Willie?
completion: Is he not back yet?

prompt: What does it say?
completion: Let this locket be a token of the vow we took the night I left.  He's coming home to marry me.

prompt: He always was opinionated.
completion: He set things right with a proper apology... and now they've put him in charge of dissection lab!

prompt: Victor!
completion: Open this door for no-one!

prompt: I remember the first time I ever saw you. Crossing the floor of the grand ballroom with my parents at your side. So beautiful even then.
completion: I have been waiting for this ever since.

prompt: Brother and sister no more.
completion: Now husband and wife.

prompt: Victor, tell me why! Trust me!
completion: I do. But you must trust me for now.

prompt: Does this have something to do with that man you saw?
completion: Yes. We're in danger here. Every moment we stay.

prompt: It is
completion: We'll leave this afternoon, right after the ceremony. Pack only what you need.

prompt: Why the change? What about your work?
completion: It was misguided and pointless. Is your answer yes?

prompt: A month at most, that's all I ask.  Elizabeth, please. Things have not yet resolved. I must take steps to see that they do. For our family's sake. For our sake.  You are life itself. We shall seal our vow. The moment I am done.
completion: No. Not tomorrow, not next week, Marry me today.

prompt: So do I.
completion: We need each other now, I need your comfort and strength, not separation and solitude.

prompt: It's not something I can explain now. Perhaps someday.
completion: What of our marriage? Victor, we've had so much tragedy. I want this family to live again.

prompt: I'm all right. I'm safe,
completion: What sort of task?

prompt: I know only that he is a killer. And I shall bring back his carcass.
completion: I thought I'd never see you again!

prompt: They've done a fine job. Hanging an innocent for the crime of a fiend.
completion: Do you know this man? Is there something between you?

prompt: I've no choice
completion: If what you say is true, it is a matter for the police!

prompt: My mind was not playing tricks. He was there in the storm... gloating over his crimes... challenging me to come.
completion: But why risk yourself? Hasn't this family suffered enough?

prompt: Victor. I love you,
completion: Elizabeth. My more than sister.

prompt: I give you my soul...
completion: ...until our wedding night. When our bodies will join.

prompt: Our decision. Together.
completion: Your decision. For us.

prompt: You make me weak.
completion: Not as weak as I.

prompt: Only you.
completion: I will be here when you return.

prompt: Then come with me to Ingolstadt. Marry me now.
completion: If only I could. But one of us must stay. Father's not strong. Willie's just a child. Who can look after them in your absence? Who can run the estate?

prompt: I wish to be your husband.
completion: I wish to be your wife.

prompt: Is that what makes it so delicious?
completion: Brother and sister still?

prompt: All my life I've known.
completion: This feels... incestuous.

prompt: To be the best there ever was. To push our knowledge beyond our dreams... to eradicate disease and pestilence... to purge mankind of ignorance and fear...
completion: I've loved you all my life

prompt: I'll have to do better than that.
completion: You will.  What do you want, Victor?

prompt: And you?
completion: Prouder still. You'll be the handsomest student there.

prompt: Quite a send-off, isn't it?
completion: Father's so proud.

prompt: Give me that child before you fill his head with drivel!
completion: Smell the air. Wonderful.

prompt: He needs to vent his outrage to the skies! Make yourself heard, Willie! Learning to walk is not an easy thing! Why should it be so?
completion: Don't listen, Willie. Progress is a feast to be consumed. Women would have you believe you must walk before you can run. Or run before you can waltz!

prompt: The world is a dizzying place.
completion: Oh, do give him here! He needs to be comforted and held!

prompt: He left a beautiful gift in her place. A baby boy. To cherish and love as our very own. Your brother
completion: Victor, have a care! You'll make him dizzy!

prompt: She was mother to me as well. But ours is the job of the living. It's up to us now to hold this family together. We must think of Father and be strong for him.  I cannot do that alone.
completion: God took her from us.

prompt: It's not ours to decide. All that live must die. It's God's will.
completion: What kind of God is He to will this?

prompt: Nothing can. Not ever.
completion: How could all my father's knowledge and skill fail to save her?

prompt: Aren't you?
completion: Are you sure it can't hurt us?

prompt: Aye, Captain.
completion: Don't cry, Elizabeth.

prompt: This ice will break yet.  How's our guest?
completion: He died. Raving about phantoms. He was mad, poor devil.  Gather a detail. Have the body removed from my cabin.

prompt: Then you run the danger of pushing them to mutiny.
completion: A warming wind.

prompt: Captain, I implore you. The men are frightened and angry. They want your assurance.
completion: They knew the risks when they signed on. I've come too far to turn back now.

prompt: It's going to ram us.
completion: It wouldn't dare.

prompt: Professor?
completion: Oh God.

prompt: No. But someday.
completion: Thank goodness. We'd be out of work.

prompt: I'm convinced. Not by treating symptoms, but by diving nature's most jealously-guarded secrets.
completion: Do you foresee this happening in our lifetimes?

prompt: I'm quite serious. Look at all the charity and clinic work we do. Up until thirty years ago, the concept of vaccine was unheard of.
completion: You're saying all disease will eventually be eradicated?

prompt: All that I once loved lies in a shallow grave. By my hand.
completion: Let it go.

prompt: Only if you'll tell me who he is.
completion: I owe you that. Done.

prompt: Yes, don't worry. I'll look after your father. You look after her.
completion: I'll be back as soon as I've got her far away and safe. We'll hunt this fiend down together.

prompt: I didn't find what I was looking for.
completion: Are you sure you'll be all right?

prompt: This. My home. My family.  If not for you, I'd be dead in a burial pit somewhere.
completion: What happened up there?

prompt: Thank you, Henry.
completion: For what?

prompt: Victor. This place looked like a charnel house. What went on here?
completion: Quite a place.

prompt: It's the down-and-outs I pity most. Those who can't fend for themselves. They'll be dead by the thousands before this is done. They don't stand a chance out there.
completion: No. They don't.

prompt: Everything in moderation, Clerval.
completion: Nothing in moderation, Frankenstein.

prompt: You've been going round-the-clock?
completion: We catch a few hours sleep where we can. Usually here at your bedside.

prompt: Is that your diagnosis?
completion: Mine and Professor Krempe's.  We've been trading off nursing you in shifts. The rest of the time we're out working with the cholera victims. It's his turn for that just now.

prompt: A... week?
completion: We feared cholera. Turned out to be pneumonia, brought on by nervous exhaustion and some idiot running around in a storm.

prompt: You'll be leaving then.  Just as well. You never were cut out for this, Henry. Goodbye.
completion: Thank God your fever broke.  Slowly, now. Just a sip.  I've been worried we might lose you. It's been touch-and-go for a week.

prompt: Yes? And?
completion: Listen to what I'm saying. The militia's arriving to quarantine the city. Most of us are getting out while we still can.

prompt: This is a bad time, Henry. I'm busy just now. What do you want?
completion: Things have gone worse with this cholera outbreak. Thousand new cases a day now. Classes have been suspended. University's shut down.

prompt: How much longer?
completion: Few months perhaps. I'm gathering the raw materials even now.

prompt: We all know how hard you took Waldman's death. Even Krempe is sympathetic. But it is time to move on. It is time to concern yourself with life.
completion: That is my concern.  I'm involved in something just now. I want to finish it in Waldman's memory.

prompt: Victor. This has got to stop.  Nobody's seen you in months. You haven't attended a single class.
completion: I've been preoccupied.

prompt: No. He had more important work.
completion: There are sick people who need our help. Here and now. Not in some future time. Consider that.

prompt: Blasphemy be damned! Waldman spent his life trying to help people!
completion: All the more reason for us to continue his work with the poor!

prompt: I resent God's monopoly.
completion: That's blasphemy!

prompt: Why Waldman? He of all people should have cheated death!
completion: You can't. Death is God's will!

prompt: It was wrong, Henry! It shouldn't have happened! The bastard deserves to die.
completion: You're making a scene!

prompt: Good. I'll be there to hear his worthless neck snap.
completion: Keep your voice down. You don't know what you're saying.

prompt: He was a frightened soul who acted out of fear and ignorance.
completion: They'll hang him all the same.

prompt: Nothing in moderation, Clerval.
completion: They just caught the man who did it.

prompt: Somebody has to!
completion: And here's to Him. Everything in moderation, Frankenstein.

prompt: But you haven't listened, Never in history has so much seemed possible. We're on the verge of answers undreamt of... but only if we have the courage to ask the questions.
completion: Only you would think of that!

prompt: These are exciting times, Henry. We're entering an era of amazing breakthroughs. Look at Edward Jenner. He wasn't content to bleed people with leeches, he pioneered a new frontier of thought
completion: ...yes, and thanks to him, smallpox has been virtually eliminated. I've heard this speech before.

prompt: It's a letter to my father.
completion: Now you've got him started.

prompt: You're a comfort to me, Henry.
completion: What now? Writing about it in your journal won't help.

prompt: Do me a favor then...  ...keep them to yourself.
completion: The entire school heard it. It wasn't something one could miss.

prompt: Can you think of a better reason?
completion: Quite a few.

prompt: Come now. Magnus? Agrippa? Next thing you know, you'll be teaching toadstools to speak.
completion: Rich old ladies and their daughters?

prompt: I know. You have a way of making an impression.
completion: Do you really think I'm mad?

prompt: Henry Clerval.
completion: Victor, Victor Frankenstein.

prompt: Are you having me on?
completion: Of course I am. It pays to humor the insane.

prompt: I am not mad.
completion: As a march hare.

prompt: I was just clearing my throat.
completion: Very well then.

prompt: So you have claimed. Yet you have no explanation for this.  The locket last seen in the hands of the poor murdered child was found hidden in your dress the morning following the murder. The locket you so coveted.  How did it come to be in your possession?
completion: I have no knowledge of that.

prompt: Is it also not true that you murdered his brother William in a misdirected crime of passion?
completion: Murder Willie? In my heart, he was our child. Victor's and mine. Such a thing could never have entered my mind.

prompt: And is it true, Miss Moritz, that you love Victor Frankenstein? That your heart was broken?  Answer the question. Do you love Victor Frankenstein?
completion: I have always loved him.

prompt: Despite the lack of challenge.
completion: Yes. I took refuge in the barn. Wouldn't you? Lost in the storm? Freezing and wet? I was exhausted and could search no longer.

prompt: Of Geneva.  Tell me, Mr. Frankenstein of Geneva. Do you wish to study medicine? Or mysticism?
completion: You seem to be adapting well to the approved curriculum.

prompt: What is your name?
completion: Victor Frankenstein, sir.  Of geneva.

prompt: Paracelsus?
completion: Or Albertus Magnus. Cornelius Agrippa...

prompt: Philosophical?
completion: Those which stir the imagination as well as the intellect. Paracelsus, for one.

prompt: In science, the letter of fact is the letter of law. Our pursuit is as dogmatic as any religious precept. Think of yourselves as disciples of a strict and hallowed sect. Someday you may be priests... but only if you learn the scripture chapter and verse.  Any questions?
completion: But surely, Professor, you don't intend we disregard the more... philosophical works.

prompt: I tell you what we need, my friends. Forget the symptoms and diseases. What we need is a vaccine for death itself.
completion: Oh, now you have gone too far. There's only one God, Victor.

prompt: Victor. He was trying to be gracious.
completion: The strain was evident.

prompt: Re-configure the leads?
completion: Numbers four and twelve directly into the nervous system?

prompt: Why?
completion: Our profession needs talent like yours. Destroy your career over an issue of pride? What a waste.

prompt: Nonsense. Tonight you will draft an apology to Professor Krempe...
completion: "...a sincere and heartfelt apology which you will then read aloud to him before the assembled student body and faculty.

prompt: It is a thrilling direction to explore. Thrilling and dangerous.  Nature can be wonderful and terrible. Science is not a realm for the reckless; it needs a conscience. We must proceed cautiously. Assess as we go.  What I do on my own time is my own business. The same holds true for you. You wish to expand your mind? Fine, do so. You can even join me here, if you like. But not at the expense of your normal studies.
completion: I doubt that decision is still mine to make.

prompt: Why? God alone knows what it means. Until it has proven value, it's nothing more than a ghoulish parlor trick. Hardly fit for the classroom.
completion: But the possibilities. Combining ancient knowledge with new? Something like this could change our fundamental views!

prompt: Electricity.
completion: It's utterly fantastic! This is the sort of thing I'm talking about! We should be learning this!

prompt: Preposterous.
completion: I once saw it done, as a boy in Canton. My parents were missionaries. The cure was nothing short of miraculous.  I've never forgotten it. Been fascinated ever since.

prompt: You disdain accepted wisdom?
completion: No, I embrace it... as something to be used or discarded as we advance the boundaries of what is known.

prompt: You have a way of provoking his.  I've been watching you. You seem impatient with your studies.
completion: To say the least. I came here to expand my mind, but honest inquiry seems strangled at every turn. All we do is cling to the old knowledge instead of seeking the new.

prompt: Victor, explain yourself.
completion: Krempe has a way of provoking my temper.

prompt: My name is Frankenstein...
completion: Professor Waldman.

prompt: We are kindred, you and I. Men of ambition. Let me tell you all that I have lost in such pursuits. I pray my story will come to mean for you all that is capricious and evil in man.
completion: Who are you?

prompt: Do you share my madness?
completion: Madness?

prompt: You'd persist at the cost of your own life? The lives of your crew?
completion: Lives are ephemeral. The knowledge we gain, the achievements we leave behind... those live on.

prompt: Your men are right to be afraid.
completion: Then explain it, whatever it is. It could save the voyage. I've spent years planning this. My entire fortune.

prompt: Creature? A... human like creature?
completion: You know of it?

prompt: I heard.
completion: I can't say I blame them. We're trapped in this ice and bedeviled by some sort of... creature.

prompt: Ah. An explorer.
completion: Would-be. I'm plagued with my share of difficulties just at the moment.

prompt: How is it you come to be here?
completion: There's a startling question, coming from you.  I'm captain of this ship. We sailed from Archangel a month ago, seeking a passage to the North Pole.

prompt: Frostbite. Gangrene. A simple diagnosis.
completion: Are you a physician?

prompt: You're awake. I've prepared some broth. It'll help restore you.
completion: I'm... dying.

prompt: We should go now.
completion: Maybe we should wait for Mr. Christy.

prompt: The killer is still out there.
completion: I will protect you.

prompt: So young, so pretty. What monster could have done such a thing?
completion: Bill -- Bill -- Bill is out there...

prompt: It's just this place. The storm. That's why you're all upset.
completion: No, no, they're all dead...

prompt: It will be all right. I'll take care of you.
completion: Jack? Marcie? Ned?

prompt: Good night, Brenda.
completion: He's dead... She's dead... all dead... Please save me... oh... poor Bill... Oh my God, oh my God... oh God...

prompt: I guess...
completion: Good night, Alice.

prompt: I think we should go wake them up. Just in case.
completion: Give them a little while longer. It's still early, anyway.

prompt: Melvin Belli.
completion: I was careless.

prompt: Tomorrow is another day.
completion: Right! Right!

prompt: I don't know. Marcie's got me paranoid.
completion: Shows how much you know. It's something about tomorrow.

prompt: Sure.
completion: What'd you see?

prompt: Thanks, Alice.
completion: I've got to go to town and pick up the trailer and all that other stuff, but I'll be back around ten. If you're still up, we can talk, okay?

prompt: You may not care a lot about this place, Alice, but I mean to make it my whole life. It's been my whole life. Gimme a chance. Stay a week. Help get it ready. Next Friday, if you're not happy, I'll put you on the bus myself. I'll be grateful.
completion: Next Friday.

prompt: You want to leave?
completion: I don't know. Probably be best for everybody.

prompt: Any particular reason?
completion: Just a feeling.  Nothing personal.

prompt: You draw very well.
completion: Oh, thanks. I wish I could spend more time at it.

prompt: That's got her. Thanks. I'm Steve Christy. Welcome to Camp Crystal Lake. You got some grubby clothes? Climb into 'em. Alice, see if Bill has cleaned out the boathouse. I want him to start with the canoes. What happened to Brenda?
completion: You told her to sweep the courts.

prompt: Cabin B is ready.
completion: Push on this side. Alice, this is Jack, Marcie and Ned. Push.

prompt: Why don't we run? Just run now?
completion: It's over twenty miles to the crossroads. Steve'll be back in an hour. Things will straighten out then. We'll take his Jeep and get help.

prompt: What's the matter with it?
completion: Wet. I don't know.

prompt: Do you have a dime? A quarter?
completion: No. There must be some in the desk somewhere.

prompt: Hey, guys!
completion: It's dead. Try the pay phone.

prompt: Jack?
completion: Marcie?

prompt: I'll go check on Brenda.
completion: Okay.

prompt: Where?
completion: They're off now.

prompt: I'll go take a look.
completion: Did somebody leave the lights on at the softball field?

prompt: Can't hear anything through that wind and rain.
completion: It sounded like Brenda.

prompt: Absolutely.
completion: I don't hear it anymore.

prompt: Well, it hasn't been that long.
completion: Help you clean up?

prompt: It wouldn't matter except Steve should be getting back pretty soon. It wouldn't look so great if he fell over them.
completion: Good point.

prompt: Jack and Marcie are gonna be drenched.
completion: Not if they're where I think they are.

prompt: Trouble?
completion: Bad bulb or no power. It's getting a little gloomy in here.

prompt: How the... did he get in there?
completion: Slipped in. Probably liked the scent of your perfume.

prompt: You can only do what you can do.
completion: And then Steve looks at you with those hurt eyes -- like you don't care about children...

prompt: I didn't know I was asleep... What time is it?
completion: Almost five.

prompt: What'll you do when you leave here?
completion: I don't know.

prompt: It still hurts?
completion: I walked into it knowing I'd get hurt, but I thought I could stand anything.  I just wasn't ready for that kind of pain. We were supposed to meet in L.A. When I got back there, he sent a telegram saying he was going back to his wife.

prompt: Filmmaker.
completion: Artist.

prompt: And it's this place. It makes no sense, but it spooks me.
completion: You're right. It makes no sense.

prompt: It's long and personal. It has nothing to do with you or the other kids.
completion: Maybe I can help?

prompt: You okay?
completion: How come you're leaving?

prompt: Un-hunh.
completion: Oh, my God...

prompt: I'm not sure I'll last all week.  I'll tell Steve.
completion: Steve said you were thinking of leaving. True?

prompt: Everybody except the girl who's supposed to handle the kitchen. Annie.
completion: You think you're gonna last all summer?

prompt: I finished the boats.
completion: Alice? The others show up?

prompt: You're welcome.
completion: Steve said for you to start on the boats.

prompt: Sure.
completion: I'm gonna go lie down and catch some z's. Today wiped me out.  Thanks, Alice.

prompt: I'm sorry.
completion: Ned? We're gonna be working together for a while. You're a nice guy without all the entertainment, okay?

prompt: I'll be along.
completion: Don't burn that gorgeous body, or I'll scratch your eyes out...

prompt: How come?
completion: Some campers drowned. Then some counselors got killed.

prompt: Let's go back, Barry...
completion: I need you so much, Claudette.

prompt: Somebody's there, Barry.
completion: Come on, Claudette. A man's not made of stone.

prompt: Somebody'll see.
completion: No, they won't...

prompt: Oh, you...
completion: Claudette...

prompt: I can't, Barry...
completion: I wouldn't know.

prompt: I meant everything.
completion: You know what I said, though.

prompt: Where's Ned?
completion: You said we were special.

prompt: I'll spot you five points.
completion: You just had some lucky shots.

prompt: Get behind him more.
completion: Chance to get even?

prompt: Is it stuck?
completion: Roll him over!

prompt: A short somewhere.
completion: What is it?

prompt: I figured if I didn't save you. I'd have to give you mouth-to-mouth and that would have ruined my appetite.
completion: Floor probably leaks. This area is full of springs.

prompt: I had to.
completion: Thanks.

prompt: Don't get up. Take a second...
completion: You saved my life.

prompt: Here we go.
completion: I'll be okay. Holy shit...

prompt: For sure.
completion: This is almost like the one at my uncle's cabin in Maine.

prompt: Where'd you get that stuff?
completion: Give me a hand?

prompt: Ha! You wily oriental! The phone was "Mr. Watson, come in here, I need you." "What hath God wrought" was the telegraph.
completion: What the hell?

prompt: What hath God wrought?
completion: That was the telephone.

prompt: No wonder they lost America. How could you sneak around in the bushes wearing that? What's to eat?
completion: Whatever you make yourself.

prompt: Holy shit...
completion: We wouldn't want you thinking you're the only show-off in camp, would we?

prompt: What do you want to be when you grow up?
completion: Dancer.

prompt: You ever fire one of those bows again, and I'll tack you up on the wall to dry.
completion: God, but I love that sexy talk.

prompt: I don't believe you...
completion: Want to see my trick shot? It's even better.

prompt: God, but I love that macho talk! Emergency generators! The Indian used campfires.
completion: Did anyone ever tell you you're beautiful when you're angry?

prompt: Wait, wait! When I was finding these goodies in the shed. I also found this letter which a camper never sent home. Listen.
completion: Steve taught me how to use the emergency generator. The town power lines are supposed to be real shitty.

prompt: Coach, athletic director somewhere.
completion: It's gonna be a long summer.

prompt: Quote: Controlled substances are expressly forbidden. Possession or use of marijuana or alcohol on campgrounds will means instant dismissal. Unquote.
completion: Jack?

prompt: I was just wondering if you thought there'd by any other gorgeous women at Camp Crystal Lake. Besides yourself.
completion: What about the dope paragraph in Mr. Christy's letter?

prompt: Sometimes I only think about kissing women.
completion: Ow!

prompt: Gotta pee. You're lying on my bladder.
completion: Ha!

prompt: Like waves. It's never been likes waves before.
completion: Whassamatta?

prompt: Best over...
completion: Umhummmmph.

prompt: Mmmmmmmph?
completion: Mmmmmmmph.

prompt: Are you wet?
completion: Just a little. Wait a minute, woman.

prompt: This is no dream. Want to escape for a while?
completion: Lead the way!

prompt: It's just a dream.
completion: I call it my shower dream.

prompt: I'm a little scared of storms. Always have been. Since I was a kid.
completion: You? The brick?

prompt: I guess...
completion: Looks like a storm.

prompt: Don't call him.
completion: I thought you wanted to give him one of your motherly lectures. Ned is gonna do whatever he wants to do, you know.

prompt: He keeps on acting like such an asshole!
completion: Ned!

prompt: What about Neddy?
completion: I don't love Neddy.

prompt: I love you.
completion: I love you.

prompt: Wind's up. It's shifted a good hundred and eighty degrees.
completion: Makes me want to hold on and never let go.

prompt: Just a walk, for Chrissakes.
completion: Boy, we sure do have a lot of filthy small-minded people around here.  Wait a minute, I'll get my diaphragm and be right with you.

prompt: How about our last jay?
completion: Good call.

prompt: Wait'll you're really in trouble and see what happens...
completion: But it's in the brochure! "Camp Crystal Lake has a full drama program." You just saw it.

prompt: You okay?
completion: Those things can be nasty.

prompt: Last line of Gone With the Wind?
completion: Frankly, Scarlet, I don't give a damn!

prompt: Doctor. Now, if you were a flavor of ice cream, what would you be?
completion: Rocky Road.

prompt: Girls can't be cowboys.
completion: Okay, Fireman.

prompt: Yeah, and it also look like it hasn't seen a coat of paint in six years.

prompt: Who the hell knows?  Everyone's giving orders.  It's all very democratic.
completion: George, we've got to get you out there before we lose our whole army.

prompt: The last I heard, a bunch of drunken militia have dug in on Breed's hill.  With one stroke the British could cut them off and apparently their leaders are too dumb to see it.
completion: Who's in command out there?

prompt: Horatio!  Horatio Gates, of course you know John Adams of the Massachusetts Delegation.
completion: Good day, Mister Adams... George, what's the word from Boston?

prompt: They are... friends of Congress.
completion: Is that where our meat and boots and uniforms and muskets went?

prompt: George, I'm sorry.  We all know the army will acquit Arnold...
completion: Of course the army will acquit him, that's not the point... Arnold is a man and will understand.  What I need to understand is, John, Sam... what is happening here?  Who are those people in there?  The fat ones in silk?

prompt: Lafayette is a child!
completion: Lafayette is my friend!  He believes in glory and truth and the freedom of all mankind; so, of course he's a child.  But he would have died before he would have let me down.

prompt: I think many would like to see him commander-in-chief.
completion: If he supports the British why is it that every time he gets near them he kills so many of them?  Unlike General Lee... who you and Congress backed for second in command and who is a goddamned incompetent!

prompt: I don't know:  delivering men and delivering men with their goodwill are two different things.  And, if he's popular with his men...
completion: Colonel Charles Lee... Hounds and all.  Quite the character.  He's got a tremendous reputation.

prompt: As does your ability, Horatio.  We must talk further, when it's more convenient.
completion: You won't be needing his largess, Rhode Island is already committed to your appointment.

prompt: Yes, an astonishing power over weak minds.
completion: With your support, Horatio.  As one of our own who has seen combat with the British, your opinion counts.

prompt: It's the political 'cost of doing business', George.
completion: Well, John Adams, your cousin has a marvelous gift.

prompt: Again, just to touch on a touchy subject, but... would the people accept another leader over Washington?
completion: Partially...

prompt: No one wants another failure right now, God knows.  But people like Arnold and, God knows, I'm having my fears about General Washington.
completion: Finally!?  It's people like these who, as soon as they get a little power, want more and more.  More ale, here!

prompt: You think that?
completion: He has the soul of an aristocrat who'd like nothing more than to become a king in the minds of the people!

prompt: Oh, come now...
completion: You invented this, this...

prompt: Makes you gag.
completion: Gag on your own invention, then.

prompt: Let's not over do it...
completion: I tell you every damned place I go the man is adored!  "General Washington!  Champion of Trenton! Savior of the Republic!"  And you should hear the way people are deprecating Congress!

prompt: He's from Virginia -- there is no more classist, elitist... English place on earth than Virginia.  And, what in hell has he done for our cause?  Washington has been preaching compromise, compromise, compromise!  Hancock acts, he led the Boston Tea party!  That's why New England loves him.
completion: Hancock led the Boston 'tea party' because he's a goddamned tea smuggler!  He wasn't protesting inequality, he was eliminating competition.  Now, you listen to me:  we need to get a Southerner elected commander-in-chief, or the south will not fight!  What have we been struggling for all these years?  For this moment!  And, if we fail now, remember:  you stopped us!

prompt: What's the difference?
completion: Washington is perfect.  He's a Southerner, he's a war hero and he's rich!

prompt: We already have black soldiers in our army...
completion: Unofficially, General Greene.

prompt: The British Army is right back there, across that river!  Sir!  I think it must be something else that detains General Lee.
completion: Congress is bitterly opposed to allowing Negroes in the army!

prompt: Detained by what?
completion: The British army, sir!

prompt: I hear General Lee is holding seven thousand fresh infantry back in New York -- why won't he come on!?
completion: General Lee is detained captain...

prompt: These men have suffered but I believe they will fight.
completion: No officer is going to get these men to fight!  They had the life crushed out of them on Long Island. At the most, perhaps we could make a feint at an outpost, then retire to protect Congress.

prompt: If he isn't, then he's stupid.
completion: Did God ever make such a pitiful army?

prompt: Are you all going insane!? Benedict Arnold!  The man who stopped the British on Lake Champlain!  Who carried the day at Saratoga!  Goddamn-it, Joseph, you own two mansions, ride in an expensive, Tory coach!  You are all nothing but a pack of greedy pigs!
completion: I doubt Arnold will be afraid.

prompt: Arnold is indispensable, do you understand?  I need Arnold to help me win this war!
completion: Well, I shall deny him to you!  He is evil on earth!

prompt: The man is a traitor!
completion: How can you say that?

prompt: Joseph, are you afraid to cross that river with me?  I accept your resignation.  With regret.  You have leave to return to Philadelphia...
completion: Gentlemen, let me get to the point, I can't see the wisdom of pursuing this old court-martial against General Arnold.

prompt: They help me understand why we fight.
completion: Understand?  You need to be listening to people like John Adams, and to keep the best interest of the country first in your mind!

prompt: How many generals do we have like Arnold?  He's got guts -- he's vain, and he fights!
completion: And, Hamilton?  Greene?

prompt: They are also very religious.  So, we will attack them three days from now, on Christmas.  One force under me, and another to the south under Colonel Cadwalader...
completion: George, I'm afraid if you go through with this madness I must tender my resignation as your aide. I see where we're headed, you're putting your trust in the likes of Hamilton and Arnold...

prompt: No, I did not.  Really?  Well, what the hell is a deist, precisely?
completion: But the Hessians are there!  No one can beat them!  That's why Cornwallis stationed them there! They have the post of honor!  They are invincible!

prompt: What do you mean you're not a Christian?  Of course you're a Christian, we're all Christians...
completion: I mean, I'm a Deist.  A belief I share with the likes of Tom Jefferson and Ben Franklin.  Surely you knew that.

prompt: No.  As a matter of fact I haven't the slightest idea what you're talking about.
completion: To assert the rights of our founding fathers!  This country was colonized by Christians!  This shall become a Christian revolution.  Surely as a good Christian you understand that!

prompt: A grand scheme?
completion: A ground swell-Christian movement, George, you see?

prompt: Joseph, the British spent thousands of pounds and precious months putting together a fleet that Arnold stopped by sacrificing a heap of old barges.  In my opinion he saved my army.
completion: Well, George, Congress just passed a resolution censuring Arnold for destruction of government property. I wouldn't cast my fate with that man.

prompt: George!  So good to be back!
completion: That damned Arnold is here, isn't he?  Did you know he lost all his ships?  Outrageous and completely unacceptable.

prompt: I understand, George.
completion: Colonel Reed...

prompt: What can he do?  The British have massive superiority.
completion: If we have any hope for a compromise or truce with England now, we have to hold on here:  our men must believe they can win -- the British must believe that somehow, in some mad, impossible way we might actually be able to hurt them.

prompt: A fleet?
completion: My God... They mean to finish us. What about Arnold?  He's up there.

prompt: Any word from Canada?
completion: Spies from Quebec confirm that the British are sending an entire fleet down Lake Champlain...

prompt: I feel the same, sir.
completion: I will continue with our French allies, concentrating on New York.

prompt: General Lee, sir!
completion: Get these men back in line!

prompt: My baby daughter has died... my baby... mon petite Henriette...
completion: My God!  Who ordered this retreat?!

prompt: When the snow melts, mon petite Marquis, I suspect the only thing blossoming will be bright red British soldiers.
completion: What is it, Marquis?

prompt: Yes, I will write him and tell his ministers and the court.
completion: Like flowers after the snow melts.

prompt: Chose another.  Any general worth anything should have a brace of horses.
completion: Because, if the British got off their asses and came up here, now, we would be smashed.  And the revolution would be finished.  Tell King Louis, it's that bad.

prompt: Well, we will accept these charming little gifts.  When we see them. Meanwhile, please, take your pick of a horse.
completion: I rode here, on my horse.

prompt: And how rusty are these muskets?
completion: Sir, these are our finest firearms from the armory at Charleville! They are a gift from the people of France!

prompt: These supplies...?
completion: Muskets and uniforms and Bayonets.

prompt: 'Charming little victories?' Please don't expect much more of us, Monsieur.
completion: I only meant...

prompt: You must be very rich.
completion: I am.  Then, I understand you too serve without salary.  You know, since your charming little victories at Trenton and Princeton, the French court is softening.  I expect any time now a ship load of supplies...

prompt: No, please; an advance on your salary.
completion: Mon General, I have come here to learn and to give, not to take.  I am serving without salary.

prompt: I... they look both the same.
completion: The one with 'Philadelphia' spelled correctly is the counterfeit.

prompt: Uh... none just now, but...
completion: 'Continentals', Congress' paper money.  It was worthless to start with, but as you see, counter feiters have made them even less than worthless.  Can you tell which one is fake?

prompt: What I want to know is sir:  where is your daddy?
completion: Gentlemen, my I introduce a French gentleman, recently appointed major general by Congress...  Marie Joseph Paul Yves Roch Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette. General Lafayette has brought us the greetings and goodwill of his countrymen, and... how many cases of muskets, Mon petite Marquis?

prompt: But, general, I assure you my motives are sincere.
completion: Sir, please accept my commission from Congress... and...  You must see this portrait of my beautiful wife, Adrienne, we had the most perfect little baby girl just before I left.  Her name is Henriette...

prompt: However, through my relations with members of his majesty's court, I am a representative of the French government whose deepest desire is to be one people, united with our American brothers in arms to defeat the rapacious armies of King George of England.  Vive la France!  Vive l'Amerique!
completion: We have more officers created by Congress than we know what to do with.

prompt: I want you to see our hospital.
completion: I don't want to see your hospital.

prompt: Come out and meet my soldiers. They're good people.
completion: Not today.

prompt: Martha!  For God's sake!
completion: Leave me, now sir, I am tired.

prompt: Our 'kind'?  What is that supposed to mean?  These men are all I have left and they stay because they will fight!  They desire it!  They seek it!  Of course Virginia is terrified!  For my soldiers this is a war to obliterate the 'upper class' from the face of the earth! Should I tell them all to go home because if they win it will ruin me!?  It is impossible for me to imagine that Negroes are fighting so that only white men may be free! If we win this war they will own this country too!
completion: Well, we must keep in mind the Dower Laws.  One third of everything we have is mine and since our Negroes have been interbreeding, it would be legally impossible to distinguish them.

prompt: Is that why you come in here tossing pennies to my starving men? It's damned condescending!
completion: Don't condescend to me!  We have both of us prospered from the arrangements of our kind...

prompt: What's the point of a revolution if it doesn't?
completion: Some things must never change.

prompt: To win this war I need an army.
completion: Oh, indeed?  You know very well people are frightened of arming the Negroes!  They beg you to consider the future.  What good is a revolution if it overturns those things we cherish!?

prompt: Martha... what?
completion: Virginia is outraged with your order allowing Negroes to fight in the army.  There's a deep feeling of hurt and betrayal.  They wanted you commander because they expected you would look out for our interests.

prompt: What else?  From Virginia?
completion: Well, I wouldn't want to trouble you with this now.

prompt: I think I heard that.
completion: It's an anti-Christian dogma!  I cannot believe you are so calm about it!

prompt: And have you heard anything from our dear friend, Sally?  What with all the rumors getting back to England.  I thought she might inquire after us.  But then I believe she always looked down on us.
completion: Did you know that Jefferson has proposed a law in Virginia aiming at an absolute separation of state from the church?

prompt: That's when Sally Fairfax was tutoring you...
completion: That's right...

prompt: When you lived with the Fairfaxes?
completion: When I was a young man we used to recite Cato... We would come together recite it like they were words from heaven.  Devotion to country, duty, purity of heart... Purity of heart.  I was drunk on something then...

prompt: You're no fool, George.  You never have been.
completion: "Liberty, Virtue, Country"... That's from Cato... you know, that play about the noble Romans?  As I was riding up to Philadelphia, I found myself thinking about the old days...

prompt: Everything.  If we force Britain into concessions it will open up the western lands -- and that would be a boon for our family.  We already have more slaves than we need, but we need more land.
completion: But, as usual, it will not go well for... them.  Martha, you must trust me.

prompt: The day Tom Jefferson frees a slave I'll ride naked through the streets of Williamsburg on a mule.  Tom Jefferson is one of those people who talks big and acts small.  The only man out there who really does what he says is Sam Adams and everyone thinks he's crazy.  Believe me, this 'disturbance' isn't going to last long.  You have to understand, congress is a chicken coop full of foxes, Martha, each and every one has his eye on a nice, fat prize.
completion: And, what 'prize' do you see?  What could we possible gain?

prompt: Don't be ridiculous, of course that won't happen.
completion: Have you been reading what Minister Jefferson has to say?  If he had his way, all our slaves would be freed no matter what the outcome. And that would destroy us as surely as a British victory.

prompt: I'm very aware of that.
completion: I can not allow the fortune in slaves my first husband created and what our partnership has elevated, to be destroyed...

prompt: The eternal dream of the disenfranchised, my dear:  a classless world.  Not a very real expectation.
completion: Well, a very real expectation is the British will hang you!  They'll burn Mount Vernon and they'll hang you!  Our marriage is a business just as surely as...

prompt: Of course, if it were that simple.  These people?  They're after something else...
completion: My God, what?

prompt: Our beloved father, the King, also refuses to bend.
completion: But to go to war over trade, over money?  Surely there's still time for a compromise.

prompt: Surely you knew this was coming.
completion: War?  No!  I did not!  When you said compromise was possible I believed it was probable.  There's no middle ground at all?  We're the King's children!

prompt: It's another demonstration against the king.  This is the wildest yet.
completion: My God, these people mean to go to war!  They really mean it.

prompt: If the constitution is ratified... we'll have a country.  They'll want to elect you president of the convention, which means president of the country.
completion: You know, I came back to Mount Vernon to retire.  I don't need to be in government.

prompt: Well, this must be about something!
completion: It is; we need you George.

prompt: They're for my bodyguard.  I have an absolute conviction that Arnold is planning to have me assassinated!  It will be harder if I am surrounded by a body of men who look like me, don't you think?
completion: Yes sir, it's a wise idea...

prompt: I'm honored, but, reluctant to leave you.
completion: Sir, I have to act on instructions from you ordering thirty copies of your own dress uniform...

prompt: You've got to stop them here or our whole line will cave-in!  It's all right boys, I'm here!
completion: Nathanael, I'm sending you to Virginia to head the southern army, to harass Cornwallis.  Marquis, you must go with him.

prompt: Then, maybe I do see what you're after -- perhaps... you get to chose again...
completion: What the hell are we doing?

prompt: But you are an aristocrat and a slave owner.  Sir.
completion: At one time I could have chosen not to be.

prompt: No.  We're all of us after something.  It's easy for me to fight for the common man.  My father could only dream that I would be... a general someday?  And what of my daughter or son?  I know what I'm after.  But now, with all this talk about compromise?  It means the rich will just be more wealthy and the common man has no hope.
completion: I will not betray you, Nathanael.

prompt: Sir, if you don't mind my saying, I don't understand your history at all.  I mean, why would you want to win the war?  You're not after glory, like Benedict...  You're a slave owner, and yet you invite blacks to fight in your army.
completion: You don't believe I can fight from a sense of duty and patriotism?

prompt: They're just disgusting, jealous, bottom-feeding swine.  It's their nature.
completion: You have a free tongue, Captain Hamilton.

prompt: I'm with Captain Hamilton.
completion: Yes, I thought that's how you'd feel, Nathanael.

prompt: You wrong me, general; I am an officer and a horse-shoer.
completion: General Greene?

prompt: Well sir, I was an ironmaster before you got me.  Maybe I will let you down yet.
completion: I certainly didn't mean you.  Of course you are a gentleman, an officer and a gentleman.

prompt: Sir, Congress hasn't issued their pay for two months, many have not eaten properly for at least that long.  You're being a little hard on them, don't you think?
completion: Nathanael, someone bred to station, bred to being a gentleman -- unlike these men -- his sense of duty naturally prevails over the baser needs.

prompt: Yes, but I've spent the last winter studying all the great battles of history.  And I read the lives of Caesar, Alexander, Hannibal...  Sir, I'm volunteering you the wholehearted support of the Rhode Island army.
completion: The only way to get discipline into these men is to beat it into them! Fifty lashes each!

prompt: I have commanded the Rhode Island Militia for a year now.  My father is an ironmaster.  As was I.
completion: A horseshoer?

prompt: I was born with a limp, sir.  The Militia used to hate it when I marches with them because my pike would always sway...
completion: But, you do come from a military family?

prompt: I... I'm possessed of the idea of a command in your army, sir.
completion: It isn't my army yet, Colonel Greene.  Looks like you've seen some action -- did you hurt your leg, in a fight?

prompt: Colonel Washington?  Colonel Nathanael Greene, Rhode Island Militia.
completion: Yes, yes, happy to meet you.

prompt: They're finished, they can't help us anymore!  They've done their duty, General Greene, now you do yours!
completion: Yessir!

prompt: We can't take them.  Are you all right?
completion: We're leaving them?

prompt: Really?  Which precious homily was it?
completion: "Mankind is born free, but everywhere he is in chains..."

prompt: I remember a pair of young philosophers once, who laughed at the world.
completion: Well, I remember a philosopher who said something that I used to think was just another of those stupid class denouncements... but which I now see means us all.

prompt: I'd throw everything away for you.
completion: You remember, George, when we were 'studying' the great philosophers?

prompt: Perhaps you've been counting my acres, Mrs. Fairfax, and discovered exactly how poor I really am.
completion: Now that is a lie!  See how much you want to create a scandal in exchange for a glowing reputation and polite society laid at your feet!  When you break off your engagement to Martha Curtis, I'll divorce William!  Do you hear?  You get what you want from this world, then throw it all away on love!

prompt: That's a lie!
completion: Is it?  William says now you have requested a British Commission, why not colonial?  I'll clear it up for you, sir, because as a British officer you can lord over colonial yokels -- more than that, it will even get you into polite society! Your dream come true, George, the only dream that really matters to you.

prompt: But not more than your comfort.
completion: And what is this, then?  Been off to fight the French because you are a patriot?  Or is this you, gaining your long sought after rise in society by becoming victorious in war!?

prompt: Is that the truth?  Well, we can't carry on like animals any longer.
completion: George, you know I only love you, but...

prompt: Well, the widow Curtis will bring you riches, position, land, even half-grown children.  You won't have to do anything at all!  You shan't have to do another thing to prove yourself.
completion: You know very well who it is that I love.

prompt: Think what the play means, William. Perhaps these words have a place in the real world.
completion: Words, words, words!  Sally has been tutoring George in the philosophies, isn't that right?

prompt: Except for that, quite like home; England, that is.
completion: Hear that, George?  Sally's actually taken to thinking of this clod of earth as her home.  And it's her first tour.  We're gratified, aren't we George?

prompt: That's not what I said!  Now, Sally, you're embarrassing me!  Watch out for her, George; she talks refinement, but she has a barbarous soul!
completion: We can grow three primary crops in a season and, if we have some luck, we get a forth.  The temperature is generally mild.

prompt: George, I'm sorry.
completion: Oh, but you must not mind my talking about you!  In fact, William says my main job here at Belvoir is to civilize you; to make an honest English gentleman out of you.

prompt: Voltaire, of course...
completion: So, you are William's wild young neighbor?  Or should I say, 'brother'; William claims you as a member of his family.  I have heard so many unflattering tales about you, and I understand, that except for you, this 'family' is quite cultivated.

prompt: Remember, George, "It is dangerous to be right in matters on which the established authorities are wrong."
completion: That's good... who?

prompt: I'm lost in ecstasy!  And dost thou love, Thou charming maid?
completion: And dost thou live to ask it?

prompt: Those people?  I doubt they'd think of this.  Ooo, you're wonderful this color!
completion: I've been surprised in an unguarded hour, But must not now go back; the love that lay, Half smothered in my breast, has broke through all, Its weak restraints, and burns in its full lustre.  I cannot, if I would, conceal it from thee.

prompt: Why?  Juba was an African and you want to look the part -- hold still.
completion: They can use their imaginations.

prompt: Let's get you darker!
completion: You're out of your mind!

prompt: I think I will disappoint you.
completion: What are you doing?

prompt: What else should I become?  There's no difference between Virginia and England.  I must be educated if I'm to take my place in society.  My father couldn't afford to send me to England for school -- he made a shambles of our fortunes.  Everyone laughs at me.
completion: I don't laugh at you, George.  I like you.  I like you because you will never, ever make it as an aristocrat... and that's because you're completely incompetent at hiding your feelings.

prompt: Well, we must be who we must be...
completion: And to think I am teaching you to become one of them...

prompt: It's the freest land on earth.
completion: Is it?  Well, I'm scared of what we've become in our freedom.

prompt: I think America suits you.
completion: Do you?  When I saw those men yesterday in the field... and the women and children in those hovels? I'm not so sure if America is as far from England as I'd hoped.

prompt: I always though London was the place to be:  capital of the world, the most spectacular city on earth.
completion: The place to want to be is America. Every English child dreams of it. I dreamt it.

prompt: Then why are you teaching me...?
completion: Perhaps you best ask, why you wish it.  You asked William to teach you manners, philosophy, decorum... as I said, it's completely stupid.

prompt: What do you really think of the minuet, anyway?
completion: It's stupid, of course.

prompt: Cranes?  Who needs to walk like a crane?
completion: That's just my interpretation. Actually it's a dance designed as a sentiment of courtly manners. You see?  Walk in a gently 'Z'. There are four distinct movements...

prompt: Or, 'civilized'.
completion: In the minuet, George, every movement is significant, like the strut of cranes...

prompt: Sally, our slave system is a British law...
completion: The word 'minuet' finds its source in minitus, which is Latin meaning 'small' or 'orderly'.

prompt: Slavers capture them and bring them here.
completion: Capture them?  Well, I've never seen anything like it, so... of course I'm curious.

prompt: Africa, of course.
completion: Africa?  That's so far?  How do they get here?

prompt: God damn you, Sam Adams!  You wanted a revolutionary army and now that we've really got one it scares you more than it does the British!
completion: Where... do those men come from, George?

prompt: Well, I hear 'The People'.  Indentured servants, freed slaves... escaped slaves.  The world's castaways.  And, my fear is, in the scramble for power that's coming, you will betray them.
completion: Is that your test of patriotism, George; if a man will die for you?

prompt: You hear that?
completion: That?  I hear a mob:  unemployed, drunkards, vagabonds... the world's dregs.

prompt: And 'others', say... have you even read Locke, Vattel, Voltaire, Diderot...
completion: Are these philosopher going to be here to help you fight your war? You know why I don't trust revolutions?  Because each of us is who we are:  we make speeches, print pamphlets, and we never change.  The world is not a philosophical abstraction, Mister Adams, it's us.  And, I don't believe you can ever change human nature.

prompt: I say!
completion: I see...

prompt: Yes!
completion: Who says so?

prompt: All people have rights!
completion: Just because they are born?

prompt: You are a slave owner!  You have been illegally surveying lands beyond the Ohio Valley!  That land belongs to the natives!
completion: That land belongs to the strongest.

prompt: William, we've been studying hard, I really know my stuff.
completion: Don't be silly, you have whole worlds to fathom.

prompt: Juba was a Numidian.
completion: He was not black!  He was... tan! Weathered!

prompt: This, this is life indeed!  Life worth preserving, Such life as Juba never felt till now.
completion: For God sake, get that horrid stuff off your face.  You look like a damned slave!  It's damned humiliating.

prompt: Though, sometimes we get frost and that can cut the season.
completion: My daughter, I ask only...

prompt: Hey, you want La Tierra Rent-A-Car just over there, but I think all they got are Rabbit convertibles.
completion: The land here is best for grain and corn.

prompt: Yeah, well, this one's the Cadillac of minivans.
completion: You're kidding me, right?

prompt: An Oldsmobile Silhouette.
completion: I reserved a Cadillac.

prompt: You're right.
completion: What is this?

prompt: We'll get it later.
completion: You keep hittin' him like that, he ain't gonna look like he broke in anymore, he gonna look like someone beat him up and then shot him.

prompt: And that's for the airport.
completion: Hey, he should have a weapon, a knife or something.

prompt: Hell, why not just shoot her? Why not shoot everybody. Fuckin' shoot me. Shoot the fuckin' president?
completion: Don't fade on me now, Bear. Not unless you wanna hold Farrah on your lap in a room fulla felons.

prompt: Calm down, Bear...
completion: Calm down? We're going away for life and you tell me to calm down?

prompt: The money. Fuck. I gotta think...
completion: You get life for kidnapping.

prompt: Plan B. Here ya go, honey...
completion: Trade for what?

prompt: You get the money?
completion: No. What's this?

prompt: And if we don't happen to find it under Palmer's mattress or inside Karen Flores' undie drawer? What then?
completion: Just do what I told you and meet me back here at midnight.

prompt: What about him?
completion: I was thinking tonight you could go have a look around Palmer's hotel room while I go check out Karen Flores' place. See if he hasn't stashed it somewhere.

prompt: After this one, I'm out, Cat, you understand? This is the last time we talk to each other.
completion: Remember Harry's story about the dry cleaner Palmer was after? Guy who stole the three hundred grand from the airline?

prompt: I heard in the Federal joints they let you spend an extra five minutes at the glass with your Daddy on Father's Day.
completion: Farrah. Come here.

prompt: He's gonna plea-deal his way out. Give up this ace stunt man now one of the West Coast dope kings, if they go easy on the Cat.
completion: Come here, Farrah...

prompt: Bear. The Colombians are in L.A. Seems they all upset about their money. That ain't enough, as a bonus, it turns out the yoyo was Escobar's nephew.
completion: That's your problem. You shouldn't've smoked the guy.

prompt: Whoa... This is the man used to jump offa high buildings?
completion: Into air bags. There's no cushion under what you're doing. I'm out of it, Cat. I'm done.

prompt: Who?
completion: Her mother. Not that it matters because I don't work for you no more. I quit. I just wanted to come by, tell you to your face so there's no misunderstanding.

prompt: Listen, tonight, later on, I got one for you doesn't involve any heavy work. I want you to go have a look around Chili Palmer's hotel room.
completion: I can't. I got to take Farrah to Satan's place down in Costa Mesa.

prompt: His foot. Jeez, poor Ronnie...

prompt: Finally came to your senses, huh?

prompt: Don't worry.  Janine has a very special way with children.
completion: I think he likes you.  I think I do too.

prompt: Let me jingle you right now.
completion: Maybe I should call Janine.

prompt: Thank you.  If I had that kind of support on a daily basis, I could definitely shape up by the turn of the century.
completion: So why don't you give me a jingle in the year 2000?

prompt: I'm not even good for me.
completion: Why do you say things like that?  You're so much better than you know.

prompt: All right, you want to be real?  So tell me why did you dump me?
completion: Oh, Peter, I didn't dump you.  I just had to protect myself.  You really weren't very good for me, you know.

prompt: Does that start exactly at midnight tomorrow, or could you hold off for a few days maybe?
completion: For one night in your life, do you think it's possible for us to be completely real?

prompt: So -- are you making any New Year's resolutions?
completion: I want to stop getting involved with men who aren't good for me.

prompt: I put them in your hamper.  I thought they were dirty.
completion: I have a hamper?  Next time ask me first, okay.  I have more than two grades of laundry.  There're lots of subtle levels between clean and dirty.

prompt: Okay, but it's not a date.  It's a dinner.
completion: Did you happen to see some shirts on the floor in here?

prompt: Does she know anything about babies?
completion: Janine Melnitz, are you kidding?  Do I have a vase?  I brought some of your clothes.  Wear something intriguing.  I brought along some interesting possibilities.

prompt: I'm not here to date.  I can't leave Oscar in a strange place with someone I don't know.
completion: It's Janine Melnitz, from my staff.  She's one of my most valuable employees.

prompt: They didn't find anything?  In the bathtub ... the pink ooze ... nothing?  So, what do I do now?
completion: Now you get dressed and we go out.  I got a babysitter and everything.  Trust me, you need it.

prompt: Are you all squeaky clean now?
completion: Yes, I'm very clean.  Did they find anything at my apartment?

prompt: Thank you.  Poor baby.  I think I should put him down now.
completion: I'll put him down for you.  You are way too short!  And your belly-button sticks out!  You're nothing but a burden to your poor mother!

prompt: How about you on the sofa and me in bed with the baby.
completion: Or we could do that.

prompt: Really?  And how would we handle the sleeping arrangements?
completion: For me it's best if I sleep on my side and you spoon up right behind me with your arms around me.  If we go the other way I'm afraid your hair will be getting in my face all night.

prompt: Peter, this is very nice, but you don't have to do any of this, you know.
completion: Be careful on that sofa -- it's a butt-biter. But the bed's good and I just changed the sheets so if you get tired, feel free.  In fact, I think you should definitely plan on spending the night here.

prompt: Sounds like another slime job ... No, they're all right.  They're here now ... Right ... Let me know.
completion: Bathroom's right here -- let me just tidy up a few things.

prompt: We'll take care of that.  Ray, Pete.  Listen, get over to Dana's right away ... Her bathtub pulled a fast one -- tried to eat the kid.
completion: It was full of this awful pink ooze.

prompt: This is Joe Namath's old number, you know. You could get a lot of chicks with this. Just don't pee in it.
completion: Peter, what about the bathtub?

prompt: I don't know what to do anymore.
completion: I'll get Ray and Egon to check out the bathtub.  You better stay here.

prompt: I must be losing my mind.  At the museum today I could have sworn that terrible painting of Vigo looked right at me.
completion: Who could blame him?  Were you wearing this nightgown?

prompt: Peter, the bathtub tried to eat Oscar.
completion: You know, if anyone else told me that, I'd have serious doubts.  But coming from you, I can't honestly say I'm surprised.

prompt: I'm sorry.  Were you on your way out?
completion: No, I just got in -- a couple hours ago. Come on in.  Are we having a pajama party?

prompt: Good-bye, Peter.
completion: I'd like to stay, but I really don't have time to hang around here.  I'll call you.  Later, Johnny!

prompt: Yeah, it's not the kind of thing you'd want to hang in the rec room.  You know what it needs?  A fluffy little white kitten in the corner.
completion: I may be wrong, but I think you've got a little crush on this guy.

prompt: As a matter of fact, I stopped by to tell you that I haven't forgotten your problem and that we're still on the case.
completion: He was also a lunatic and a genocidal madman. I hate this painting.  I've felt very uncomfortable since they brought it up from storage.

prompt: I didn't paint it.  I'm just cleaning it. It's an original Ver Meer.  It's worth about ten million dollars.
completion: I'm sure you didn't come here just to talk about art.

prompt: Oh, hello, Peter.
completion: You're really good, you know.

prompt: Thanks.
completion: So this is what you do, huh?

prompt: I'm El Gato.  I always land on my feet.
completion: Good luck.

prompt: Don't worry about me.  I'm like a cat.
completion: You mean you cough up hairballs all over the rug?

prompt: You are personally responsible.  If I can get conjugal rights, will you visit me at Sing Sing?
completion: Please don't say that.  You won't go to prison.

prompt: Okay, let's take a look.
completion: I wish I could stay.  I feel personally responsible for you being here.

prompt: We definitely had a moment or two.
completion: That's where the buggy stopped.

prompt: I'll supervise.
completion: Brings back a lot of sweet memories, doesn't it?  There's our old cash machine.  And the dry cleaners we used to go to.  And the old video store.  We really had some good times, didn't we?

prompt: Unusual?  I don't know.  I haven't had a lot of experience with babies.
completion: I'll do it.

prompt: Oscar!  You poor kid!
completion: Peter, this is serious.  I need to know if you think there's anything unusual about him.

prompt: There's no doubt about it.  He's got his father's looks.  The kid is ugly -- extremely ugly.  And smelly.  You stink!  It's just horrible.  You are the stinkiest baby I ever smelled.  What's his name?
completion: His name is Oscar.

prompt: I may have a few personal problems but one thing I am is a total professional.
completion: What do you think?

prompt: Men are very sensitive, you know.  We need to feel loved and desired, too.
completion: Well, when you started introducing me as "the old ball and chain," that's when I left.

prompt: He ditched you.  You should've married me, you know.
completion: You never asked me, and every time I brought it up you'd get drowsy and fall asleep.

prompt: So what happened to Mr. Right?  I hear he ditched you and the kid and moved to Europe.
completion: He didn't "ditch" me.  We had some problems, he got a good offer from an orchestra in England and he took it.

prompt: I have.  That's why I didn't call you first.
completion: I can see that you're still very bitter about us, but in the interest of science, I'm going to give it my best shot.  Let's go to work, boys.

prompt: Hello, Peter.
completion: You know, Dana, I'm very very hurt that you didn't call me first.  I'm still into all this stuff, you know.  Haven't you ever seen my show?

prompt: Sorry!
completion: Maybe we should discuss this somewhere else.

prompt: I think we hit the honeypot, boys.  There's something brewing under the street.
completion: Peter, do you think maybe I have some genetic problem or something that makes me vulnerable to these supernatural things.

prompt: Is this the spot?
completion: A little to the left.  Right there!  That's where it stopped.

prompt: No problem.  Always glad to help -- and hug.
completion: Hi, Egon.

prompt: No, you can't, and I think that's the whole problem with aliens; you just can't trust them. You may get some nice ones occasionally like Starman or E.T., but most of them turn out to be some kind of lizard.  Anyway, we're just about out of time.  Next week on 'World of the Psychic,' hairless pets.  Until then, this is Peter Venkman saying ...  ... Good night.
completion: Hi, Ray.  It's good to see you.  Thanks for coming.

prompt: Your alien had a room in the Holiday Inn?
completion: It may have been a room on the spacecraft made up to look like a room in the Holiday Inn.  I can't be sure, Peter.

prompt: Valentine's Day.  That's got to be a bummer. Where did you get that date, Elaine?
completion: I received this information from an alien.  I was at the Paramus Holiday Inn, I was having a drink in the bar when he approached me and started talking.  Then he must have used some sort of ray or a mind control device because he made me follow him to his room and that's where he told me about the end of the world.

prompt: Oh, you think so?  Well, I've got news for you.  You've got Dracula's brother-in-law in there and he's got my girlfriend and her kid.  Around about midnight tonight, when you're partying uptown, this guy's going to come to life and start doing amateur head transplants.  And that's just round one.
completion: According to my sources, the world will end on February 14, in the year 2016.

prompt: Now you're talking.
completion: Look, I've had it with you.  Get your stuff together, get back in that clown car and get out of here.  This is a city matter and everything's under control.

prompt: Yeah, I think the Times might be interested, don't you?  The Post might have a lot of fun with it, too.
completion: Before you go running to the newspapers with this, would you consider telling this slime thing to some people downtown?

prompt: Look, you stay away from the mayor.  Next fall, barring a disaster, he's going to be elected governor of this state and the last thing we need is for him to be associated with two-bit frauds and publicity hounds like you and your friends.  You read me?
completion: That's quite a story.

prompt: I know who you are, Doctor Venkman.  Busting any ghosts lately?
completion: No, that's what I want to talk to the mayor about.  We did a little job for the city a while back and we ended up getting sued, screwed and tattooed by deskworms like you.

completion: I'm an old friend of the mayor's.  I just want to say hello to him.

prompt: Can I help you?
completion: Yeah, you can get your hand off my chest.

prompt: You're right.  We should stay.

prompt: Should we go?
completion: I don't think we should leave her alone.

prompt: Motherhood is a very natural instinct for me.  I'd like to have a baby myself. Wouldn't you?
completion: Tonight?

prompt: You're really good with children, Louis.  I can tell.  Why don't you come here and sit with me?
completion: Okay.

prompt: It's really not a bad place.  It just needs a woman's touch.
completion: So they bartered room and board in exchange for housekeeping services, which was a good deal for all of them because then they didn't have to withhold tax and social security, which I'm not saying is right but it's just a story, so I guess it's all right.  I can finish this later if you're tired.

prompt: I can't believe a person could actually live like this.

prompt: I'd like to, but I told Dr. Venkman I'd babysit.  Do you want to babysit with me?

completion: What are you doing up here?

completion: Ghostbusters.

prompt: I'm going to rule out the glue-sniffing theory.  If she says it looked at her, it looked at her.  Hey, you!  Vigie!  Look at me.  I'm talking to you.  Hey!  Look at me when I'm talking to you.

How are you?  What's that you're working on, Johnny?

prompt: I command you.

prompt: -- the sorrow of Moldavia --

prompt: I, Vigo, the scourge of Carpathia --

completion: Keep that up, mister, and I'll find you in contempt.

completion: That's it?  That's all you have to say?

prompt: Can I have some of your water?

completion: Okay, let me rephrase that question.  Didn't you once coach a basketball team for underprivileged children?

prompt: I thought you were like the fifth Ghostbuster.

prompt: You were the one who got me in.
completion: I fixed you up with Diane Troxler and she put out, didn't she?

prompt: Like what?
completion: I got you out of those bad tax shelters.

completion: Sherman, I've done lots of favors for you.

prompt: I can't do it, Louis.  It isn't ethical.  I could lose my license.
completion: Why can't you just have them released? You're a doctor.

prompt: Well, for your sake, I hope you're right.  But I think my other guest may disagree with you. Elaine, you had another date in mind?
completion: Come on, Sherm.  You're my cousin.  Do this for me.  I'm begging you.

prompt: This year?  That's cutting it a little close, isn't it?  I mean, just from a sales point of view, the book just came out, right?  So you're not even looking at the paperback release for maybe a year.  And it's going to be at least another year after that if the thing has movie-of-the-week or mini-series potential. You would have been better off predicting 1992 or even '94 just to be safe.
completion: This is not just some money-making scheme!  I didn't just make up the date.  I have a strong psychic belief that the world will end on New Year's Eve.

prompt: Okay, so can you tell us when it's going to happen or do we have to buy the book?
completion: I predict that the world will end at the stroke of midnight on New Year's Eve.

prompt: Hi, welcome back to the 'World of the Psychic,' I'm Peter Venkman and I'm chatting with my guest, author, lecturer and of course, psychic, Milton Anglund.  Milt, your new book is called The End of the World.  Isn't that kind of like writing about gum disease.  Yes, it could happen, but do you think anybody wants to read a book about it?
completion: Well, I think it's important for people to know that the world is in danger.

prompt: So what are you saying?  That the world of the supernatural is your special province?
completion: No, I guess I'm just saying that shit happens and somebody has to deal with it.

prompt: I'll ask you again, Dr. Venkman.  Why were you digging the hole?  And please remember that you're under oath.
completion: I had my fingers crossed when they swore me in, but I'm going to tell you the truth. There are things in this world that go way beyond human understanding, things that can't be explained and that most people don't want to know about anyway.  That's where we come in.

prompt: So, Dr. Venkman, please explain to the court why it is you and your co-defendants took it upon yourselves to dig a big hole in the middle of the street.
completion: Seventy-seventh and First Avenue has so many holes already we didn't think anyone would notice.

prompt: Yes, I did.  We were city champs.
completion: Objection.  Irrelevant and immaterial.

prompt: They came from Ostrov in Eastern Poland.
completion: Ostrov?  I've been there.  Good party town.

prompt: It's probably the first thing my grandparents saw when they came to this country.
completion: From where -- Neptune?

prompt: I'm worried.  The vibrations could shake her to pieces.  We should have padded her feet.
completion: Pretty impressive, huh?

prompt: They love you, Lib.  Keep it up.
completion: So far so good.

prompt: This won't wait until tomorrow, Venkman. It's hot and it's ready to pop.
completion: It's working.  The positive GeV's are climbing.

prompt: Roach breeding?  Sounds better and better.  Dana?  The boys are going down under the sewers tonight to look for slime.  Egon thinks there might even be some kind of big roach-breeding surge.  Should we forget about dinner and go with them instead?
completion: Boys, listen.  You're scaring the straights. Let's save this until tomorrow, okay?

prompt: It's a rough translation from the Moldavian.
completion: You know, animals and lower life forms often anticipate major disasters.  Given the new magnetheric readings we could see a tremendous breeding surge in the cockroach population.

prompt: A hundred and five years?  He really hung on, didn't he.
completion: That's it?  "I'll be back?"

prompt: You need the exercise.
completion: "Vigo the Carpathian, born 1505, died 1610 --"

prompt: I knew that.
completion: You were supposed to help me with this.

prompt: Finding something abnormal on the street shouldn't be too hard.
completion: That's a thousand million electron volts.

completion: I think we should see if we can find anything abnormal on the street.

prompt: I'd like to have a stool specimen
completion: Yeah, you would.  Is that for personal or professional reasons?

prompt: I think they're more interested in my epididymis.
