prompt: Do it!  Just do it!
completion: Egon!

prompt: Something good --
completion: Don't shoot!  You'll hit Ray!

prompt: We need something that everyone can get behind, a symbol --
completion: Something that appeals to the best in each and every one of us --

prompt: It won't work.  There's no way we could generate enough positive energy to crack that shell.
completion: I can't believe things have gotten so bad in this city that there's no way back. Sure, it's crowded, it's dirty, it's noisy. And there are too many people who'd just as soon step on your face as look at you.  But there've got to be a few sparks of sweet humanity left in this burned-out burg.  We just have to mobilize it.

prompt: If you two are looking for a fight, you got one.  Who wants it first?  Come on, Ray.  Try me, sucker.
completion: Butt out, you pencil-necked geek.  I've had it with you.

prompt: That's it.  It's on the bottom.
completion: Nine feet -- ten --

prompt: This guy was a bad monkey.  He dabbled in all the Black Arts, and listen to this prophecy.  Just before his head died, his last words were, "Death is but a door, time is but a window.  I'll be back."
completion: Six feet -- seven -- eight --

prompt: And we're the ...
completion: No, not exactly a man of the people.  "Also known as Vigo the Cruel, Vigo the Torturer, Vigo the Despised, and Vigo the Unholy."

prompt: It may be ebbing and flowing from some tidal source.
completion: I'm Egon --

prompt: His nickname is "The Hammer."
completion: Hey, I didn't imagine it.  There must have been ten thousand gallons of it down there.

prompt: What's the reading?
completion: Seems like a pretty open-minded guy, huh?

prompt: The New York Pneumatic Railway.  It was an experimental subway system.  Fan-forced air-trains, built around 1870.
completion: This is about as deep as you can go under Manhattan without digging your own hole.

prompt: Nothing.  Not a trace.
completion: Why don't we try the Giga-meter?

prompt: You might want to check those Duke University mean averaging studies on controlled psychokinesis.
completion: Good idea.

prompt: Some crank.  Looking for goat hooves.  Come up with anything?
completion: This one's interesting.  Berlin, 1939, a flower cart took off by itself and rolled approximately half a kilometer over level ground.  Three hundred eyewitnesses.

prompt: There's something very familiar about this painting.
completion: Who was that?

prompt: And it's all flowing toward the museum.
completion: Late Renaissance, I think.  Caravaggio or Brunelleschi.

completion: Rivers of the stuff!

prompt: I'd put my money on that Vigo character.
completion: Is the line sinking?

prompt: You mean this stuff actually feeds on 'bad vibes'?
completion: There's definitely something going on in that studio.  The PKE levels were max-plus and the Giga-meter was showing all red.

prompt: Me?  I'm a little of everything.  Some Irish, some German, some French, Dutch -- the women in my family slept around.  And that's what made this country great.
completion: We've found it at every event site we've been to lately.

completion: I don't think they make Nikes in her size.

completion: I'll keep to the middle of the channel. We're okay to 59th Street, then we'll go ashore and take First Avenue to 79th.

completion: What happened?

prompt: Nothing.  Just some mood-slime residue in and around the bathtub.  But we did turn up some interesting stuff on this Vigo character you mentioned.  I found the name Vigo the Carpathian in Leon Zundinger's Magicians, Martyrs and Madmen.  Listen to this:
completion: Beautiful, beautiful.  Work with me, baby. Just have fun with it.  Okay, he's playing it cool.  Let's finish up and get out of here.

prompt: You're not sleeping with this stuff, are you?
completion: Did you find anything at Dana's?

prompt: What kind of tests?
completion: Well, we sing to it, we talk to it, we say supportive, nurturing things --

prompt: This is an incredible breakthrough, Venkman. A psychoreactive substance!  Whatever this is, it clearly responds to human emotional states.

prompt: It's not that thing you do with your nostrils, is it?

prompt: If he wasn't dead he'd be an Olympic prospect.

prompt: Agile bastard, isn't he?
completion: Forget the trapping!  Just blast him!

prompt: As a duly-constituted representative of the City of New York, and on behalf of the County and State of New York, the United States of America, the Planet Earth and all its inhabitants, I hereby order you to cease and desist any and all supernatural activity and return at once to your place of origin or next parallel dimension.
completion: Well, that ought to do it.

prompt: It doesn't seem to have slowed him down any.
completion: I don't think it's Shandor.

prompt: Who was the architect?
completion: He's listed on the blueprints as I. Shandor.

prompt: I guess they don't build them like they used to, huh?
completion: No!  Nobody ever built them like this!  The architect was either an authentic whacko or a certified genius.  The whole building is like a huge antenna for pulling in and concentrating psychokinetic energy.

prompt: Egon, how's the grid around the storage facility holding up?
completion: It's not good, Pete.

prompt: Boy, that was a rough one.
completion: I can't take much more of this.  The pace is killing me.

prompt: How do you know?
completion: I don't know.  I'm just guessing.

prompt: It's here, Ray.  It's looking at me.
completion: Don't move.  It won't hurt you.

prompt: Sit tight.  I'm on my way.
completion: Well, hurry up.  The needle's going wild.

prompt: Where are you, Pete?
completion: Third floor.  Get down here,

prompt: All right.  Let's cool the negative vibes. These things can sense them.
completion: Ray -- Something's here.

prompt: I'm getting high readings near the air vents.  It must be using the duct system to get around.  See, I told you we'd get something.
completion: So far all we got is a shit smell on the twelfth floor and we almost fried a Puerto Rican bellboy.

prompt: No sense worrying about it now.
completion: Sure.  Each of us is wearing an unlicensed nuclear accelerator on our back.  No problem.

prompt: Do you know when that might be?  We're on the brink of a very serious cash-flow problem.
completion: So do I.

prompt: It wasn't a date.  It was an investigation.
completion: They will.

prompt: Good idea.  Were any other words spoken that you remember?
completion: How was your date?

prompt: Fourteen hundred.
completion: Why don't I check out the building?  It may have a history of psychic turbulence.

prompt: Everybody can relax.  I found the car.  How do you like it?
completion: Do you think it's wide enough?  How much?

prompt: Wow!  Does this pole still work?
completion: This might do ... I don't know ... it just seems kind of "pricey" for a fixer-upper, don't you think?  We're trying to keep our costs down.  You know how it is when you're starting a new company.

prompt: But most people are afraid to even report these things.
completion: Maybe.  But no one ever advertised before.

prompt: You're not going to lose the house. Everybody has three mortgages these days.
completion: But at nineteen percent interest!  You didn't even bargain with the guy.

prompt: You'll never regret this, Ray.
completion: My parents left me that house, I was born there.

prompt: For what purpose?
completion: To go into business for ourselves.

prompt: Do you know what a patent clerk makes?  I liked the University.  They gave us money, they gave us the facilities and we didn't have to produce anything!  I've worked in the private sector.  They expect results. You've never been out of college.  You don't know what it's like out there.
completion: Let me tell you, Ray, everything in life happens for a reason.  Call it fate, call it luck, Karma, whatever.  I think we were destined to get kicked out of there.

prompt: This is like a major disgrace.  Forget M.I.T. or Stanford now ... they wouldn't touch us with a three-meter cattle prod.
completion: You're always so worried about your reputation.  We don't need the University. Einstein did his best stuff while he was working as a patent clerk.'They can't stop progress.

prompt: You said you floored 'em at the Regents' meeting.
completion: Ray, I apologize.  I guess my confidence in the Regents was misplaced.  They did this to Galileo, too.

prompt: If anyone deserves it, it's Spengler and me. We're doing all the hard research and designing the equipment.
completion: Yeah, but I introduced you guys.  You never would've met if not for me.  That's got to be worth something.

prompt: Oh, yeah.  This could be bigger than the microchip.  They'll probably throw out the entire engineering department and turn their building over to us.  We're probably the first serious scientists to ever molest a dead old lady.
completion: If you guys are right, if we can actually trap a ghost and hold it somehow, I think I could win the Nobel Prize.

prompt: "Get her?"  That was your whole plan?  You call that science?
completion: I guess I got a little overexcited.  Wasn't it incredible!  I'm telling you, this is a first.  You know what this could mean to the University?

prompt: Hey, Lady?  Lady!  Can you talk?  Who are you?   This is not working.  Think of something else.
completion: Okay.  Okay.  I got it.  I know what to do. Stay close.  I have a plan.

prompt: What do I say?
completion: Anything!  Just make contact.

prompt: What do we do now?
completion: I don't know.  Talk to it.

prompt: It looks like a big pair of breasts and a pot belly.
completion: I told you it's real.

prompt: Uh-huh.  I've heard about the rockfall, Ray. I think you've been spending too much time with Spengler.
completion: What is it?

prompt: Looked at with your eyes.
completion: Well, I was at an unexplained multiple high-altitude rockfall once.

prompt: Ray, as your friend I have to tell you I think you've really gone around the bend on this ghost stuff.  You've been running your ass off for two years checking out every schizo in the Five Boroughs who thinks he's had an experience.  And what have you seen?
completion: What do you mean by "seen?"

prompt: No, this one's for real, Peter.  Spengler went down there and took some PKE readings. Right off the top of the scale.  Buried the needle.  We're close this time. I can feel it.
completion: Spengler and I have charted every psychic occurrence in the Tri-State area for the past two years.  The graph we came up with definitely points to something big.

prompt: Peter, at 1:40 this afternoon at the main branch of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue, ten people witnessed a free-roaming, vaporous, full-torso apparition.  It blew books from shelves at twenty feet away.  Scared the socks off some poor librarian.
completion: Sure.  That's great, Ray.  I think you should get down there right away and check it out.  Let me know what happens.

prompt: What do you mean "choose?"  We don't understand.
completion: Excuse me for a minute.  Ray, I'm right in the middle of something here.  Can you come back in about an hour?

prompt: LATER, MAN!!
completion: What's he talking about?  Choose what?

prompt: Right.  We'll believe anything.
completion: Stantz?  You okay in there?

prompt: Well, has it ever occurred to you that the reason you've been so busy lately is because the dead have been rising from their graves?
completion: You don't have to worry about that with us, sir.

prompt: Yeah, Judgement Day.
completion: Every ancient religion had its own myth about the end of the world.

prompt: Right.  And the sky would fall ...
completion: Judgement Day ...

prompt: Ray, do you remember something in the Bible about a day when the dead would rise up from their graves?
completion: And the seas would boil ...

prompt: Me, too. Parts of the Bible are great.
completion: The whole roof cap was fabricated with a magnesium-tungsten alloy.

prompt: Do you believe in God?
completion: No.  But I liked Jesus' style.

prompt: Me, too.
completion: Boy!  Solid cores of shielded Selenium .325.

prompt: Are you a Christian, Ray?
completion: Mmmhmmm.

prompt: Hey man.  What is it you're so involved with there?
completion: Uh ... Oh these are blueprints of the structural ironwork in Dana Barrett's apartment building ... And they're most unusual.

prompt: Very impressive resume.  Electronic countermeasures, Strategic Air Command ... Black belt in Karate ... Small arms expert ... Mr. Zeddemore, as you may have heard, we locate ghosts and spirits, trap them with streams of concentrated quantum energy and remove them from people's homes, offices and places of worship.
completion: Yeah, I heard that.  Now tell me what you really do.

prompt: You would have had a full scale revolt on your hands.
completion: What have I got now?  It's exactly as if there were two emperors. Because of this the people have two minds.  He is their champion.

prompt: Do you want posters, too?
completion: Damn him!  I should have killed him on the front -- I let you talk me out of that.

prompt: Send them out!
completion: Lykas, pick a man.  Someone who will look good.  Jerses I want it built up in the Daily Action...

prompt: I am their hero!
completion: Not yet, dear brother...

prompt: I want that bastard dead!
completion: You want control of the crowd -- you can't get it by killing their hero.

prompt: Tell Lykas to send a retiarius and a Samnite to help Tiger.
completion: You can't do that... listen to the mood of the crowd.

prompt: Yes?  Go on!
completion: "... by the emperor of Rome.  This writer asks:  between a Senate that debates truth until they choke, an Emperor who has the birth sign of a woman, is it possible there is more virtue within the arena than without?"

prompt: But I get what I want, always, don't I?
completion: "... encased in the armor of a demigod, Narcissus The Good continues his impossible climb in the arena where he was unjustly cast..."

prompt: Now that we're done with that infatuation forever.
completion: If I ever loved Narcissus it wasn't like you want.

prompt: Now that is a happy sound! Tomorrow, I want the citizens -- my people -- back in the arena.  The Gods know, I'm tired.  Come to bed, now; tonight we're celebrating.
completion: What are you talking about?

prompt: What is that... wailing?
completion: The fans of Narcissus.  They were on vigil outside the school of Proximo. They believe he's dying.

prompt: You must start clearing everything with me -- especially your lovers.
completion: Why are you so surly -- you've won, brother.  The people have bread and the city is quiet.

prompt: Where have you been?
completion: Taking my pleasure.  Do I need to clear my lovers with you?

prompt: You're coming back?
completion: I have to come back.  If I don't come back the people will think I'm a coward.  Tribuus, tomorrow he dies -- I want his blood on the sand.  Do you understand?

prompt: You can't do that!  You came here to turn the crowd around not make them hate you.
completion: Tribuus... tomorrow.

prompt: Why not do it in the Colosseum?
completion: Kill him!  Tribuus -- execute that bastard.

prompt: If I may be so bold...
completion: For the gods, spit it out!

prompt: Commodus is heaving out every thing that belonged to our father.  Except that he can't heave out his ghost.
completion: How about in the forum.  Right in front of the Senate.

prompt: I want every single thing that belonged to my father out of this house!  If it's worth something then sell it!
completion: It's disgusting!  Animals!  I had to come here under armed guard.  Slaves -- get this junk out of my sight.

prompt: Let some time pass... then ask, quietly, without anyone knowing it comes from me.
completion: Those are priceless sculptures.

prompt: I'm sure, I don't know.
completion: No one in Rome has ever heard of him.  Do you want to remind those few in the Senate who have?  The whole sordid thing is far beneath your position to begin with.  Forget about him.

prompt: If you get me pregnant with a boy he'll be a double direct heir and will end up killing you for the throne.
completion: Did Narcissus die today?  Wasn't this his day to die?

prompt: Maybe you should get married.  Pick one of your cousins, it would demonstrate a profound stability.
completion: I should at least have you, don't you think?

prompt: Why?  Then they'll notice when I'm gone.  Well.  I'm making a public appearance aren't I?
completion: They hate me, they really hate me don't they?

prompt: And Caesar!  Let's not forget to serve Caesar!
completion: Don't you think you should at least wave?

prompt: Oh, stay...  Don't you want to join the chorus of praises for Narcissus' glory?  Just remember, he is a married man.
completion: Quite so.  Narcissus and his courageous men; may they live long to serve Rome...

prompt: More wine, sister?  Surely you can drink more than that.
completion: I was suddenly thinking about going to bed.

prompt: Will you please get back in your wagon?  And stay there?
completion: I'm tired of being stuck in that wagon.

prompt: We're nearly there, Lucilla.
completion: That's what you told me two days ago!

prompt: If you set me free I will find my way back to the army, march on Rome and depose you.  Then, the army and I will restore the Republic so that animals like you will never control human destinies again.
completion: Where are we now, Commodus?  Can you see the camp?  My Gods!  The air is turning into ice!

prompt: On what charge?
completion: Endorse me in public.  Do that and I'll make you rich and set you free. I'll return your estates.  I know you would give anything to be outside again.  Endorse me and you will be free.  Think of it.  What would you do with your freedom?

prompt: And my army would have thrown your body into the Danube.
completion: The army is a problem.  They love you.  You have led them from victory to victory in the name of Rome and they love you.  And after all, you're just a hothead acting from a misguided sense of loyalty -- who could fault you for that?  Thus have I reached a compromise with the Senate over your fate: instead of executing you, I'm sending you to Rome where you will be tried...

prompt: Where is my family?
completion: Cooperate and they will be returned to your estate.  I could have executed you.

prompt: They won't break this one.
completion: Apparently my opinion wasn't needed.

prompt: We have to stop the Germans now!
completion: Forgive me, Caesar, but do two Senator represent the mood of the whole Senate or the will of the Roman people?  Besides, every truce we make with the Germans they break!

prompt: That this illness has clouded his mind.
completion: I'm ordering a general stand-down in preparation for withdrawal back across the Danube.

prompt: Being as close, I'm certain you've noticed what we all have noticed.
completion: Caesar?

prompt: You and my father have become very close.  Perhaps one day I may say the same for us.
completion: You flatter me, Caesar.

prompt: But they're not destroyed, not yet.
completion: Do we really need to repair this fort?  It seems like an expensive undertaking.  I propose we burn it to the ground.  That way if the Germans cross the Danube here there will be nothing to help them build an offensive position.

prompt: I would say there's nothing more dangerous than a man who knows what 'right' is.
completion: The dangerous man, Caesar, is the man who doesn't care.

prompt: I back Rome against all her enemies -- if that answer disappoints you, I'm not a politician...
completion: Oh, but with the army behind you, you could become extremely political.  Not a Republican by any chance?

prompt: Gladly Caesar.
completion: Or perhaps into a new one.  But here's to your God and the courage of our legions...

prompt: Perhaps, Master Galen, you may say.
completion: Then you'd be out of a job.

prompt: Do you expect Marcus to be well enough by morning for an audience?
completion: That's difficult to say, general.

prompt: Respectfully Caesar, Quintus and I must report.
completion: Of course, but not now.  However, if he continues to be unwell, you may report to me.

prompt: I wouldn't know who to bet on.
completion: Welcome back from your great triumph Narcissus Meridas.  My father sends his heart felt praise.  Sadly, Marcus is in dark humors -- nothing to worry about, but he needs rest. Likely just the weather.

prompt: Make a gift to the people.  It's your money anyway so it's only fair.
completion: Caesar, let me sponsor your first wager in the arena.

prompt: Sacks of grain, even bread.  I own the grain licenses for the military, I can arrange to divert a shipment bound for the army of the Danube.
completion: Take grain away from the army?

prompt: We can crush Gaius another way. What if you do throw something to the people they really want?  Make them a gift of food.
completion: Give away food?

prompt: I'm serious.
completion: So am I.

prompt: Yes.  You know, that's not a bad idea.
completion: Maybe it'll crush Gaius.

prompt: At the opening of the month of Janus, I will ask this noble body to confirm my emperorship...
completion: Throw it down into the streets! Down into the Forum.  If it's my father they want then give him to them!

prompt: Until your confirmation date.
completion: And like children everywhere they scream "freedom" the most when they desire it least.  I beg you, please continue, Caesar.

prompt: At least stay for the running of the animals.  You are paying for it you know...
completion: Gods of hell!  This must cost a fortune!  How many days is this going to go on?

prompt: Caesar, ignore them.
completion: Ignore that?!  The sooner we leave this disgusting place the better.

prompt: The Senate is out to sink you.  I swear it, Caesar, your generosity is being repaid with public attacks on your honor.  Your enemies want you weak enough so by the first of Janus when you must be confirmed the Senate will be able to deny you.
completion: How can they?  Who else is there?  I have no heir...

prompt: Insubordination.  To the Emperor... and the Senate.
completion: Quintus will tell the army that you are being called to Rome to celebrate your victory.  They will hear that you are living in luxury. He will let them feel you have betrayed them for the good life. And soon the army won't even remember your name.

prompt: Underdog!  How can he be an underdog -- he wins all the time!  I'm the emperor why can't I kill him?  He could be poisoned, or somehow killed to look like an accident.
completion: You don't want to kill him.  If anything happens to him now you will be blamed... and he knows it. Besides, that gladiator school is a fortress.  It would take the army to break in there.  What you want is to... offer him the wooden sword. If he takes it, he's no longer the champion of the people, is he?  He's gone.  And you are a hero for awarding it.

prompt: Narcissus will never support you, Caesar, he has too much of a philosophical temperament.
completion: It's because he comes off as the underdog.

prompt: I met with Falco, and the Senators have agreed to call for a truce with the Germans.
completion: This is the only place in Rome where I thought -- I believed -- I was wholly in power.

prompt: He left us at dawn.
completion: We must obey our emperor and the Senate.

prompt: I'm certain father will be in better humors by then.  Now, honor us with your presence at dinner.  I'll join you as soon as I see my father's physician.
completion: Marcus Aurelius has died.

prompt: We need more statues -- perhaps I should open medical clinics.  For the poor.  Citizens only, though...
completion: Gladly, Caesar.  And, if you'd like we can take you for a tour of the front at first light.

prompt: Tribuus!  Go left here, I want to see my new statue at Via Claudia.
completion: Yes, Caesar.

prompt: Yes, Caesar?
completion: Jerses -- tomorrow...

prompt: Why isn't he dead?  Damn you, you promised me he would be dead!
completion: Caesar, I did my best.  The Colosseum isn't under my control...

prompt: Tribuus, what happened in the arena? Was Narcissus killed?
completion: He must have been.  He was on the list of prisoners to be executed.

prompt: Where is my father?
completion: Where is the emperor and the army, soldier?

prompt: I'll nose around...
completion: You know there were riots last night.  Now the unrest has started again and Commodus has sent for an army division.  You understand what you are doing...

prompt: I don't know...
completion: AGH!  Please!  He's having a secret device constructed for the circus. The brass craftsmen are working overtime.

prompt: Commodus... he's a gladiator... is he mad?
completion: Cos, what in hades is the emperor up to?  And don't tell me you don't know!

prompt: I'm mentioning you in tomorrow's athlete's section, legate.  So, I'd love to know your birth sign; it effects how people bet.  And perhaps you could tell me a bit about... well, who are you?
completion: "Caesar Commodus discovering his lineage converges with the Demigod, Hercules, has determined to display his magnificence before his beloved citizens."  The Emperor's going to fight in the arena.  I'm supposed to write this for tomorrow's edition.

prompt: You won an impossible fight.  You got the attention of the crowd, legate...
completion: This is Cos, this precocious young man.  A scribe for the Daily Action.  I've invited him to write a small piece about you...

prompt: It's time for you to tell the Citizens that Commodus stole the money allocated for defending the German border.  It's time to tell the citizens everything.  Will you write it?
completion: Yes, because I know they'll read it.

prompt: That makes his birth sign... Virgo! Why that's the sign of a little girl!  Can you tell my readers more about your star-crossed connection with Emperor Commodus?
completion: Proximo, we need to talk about my one third... I imagine the betting booths will be doing good business. And, what was the name of that olive oil company?

prompt: The exact month when the Emperor must be confirmed!
completion: The Emperor and I are bound by the threads of The Fates.  He was born on August thirty-first, you know.

prompt: I am prepared to write anything you tell me.
completion: My birth sign is Water Bearer, twenty-fifth day in the month of Janus.

prompt: So tell me, what happened between you and the emperor?  What really happened on the German front?  You know the Senate's arguing your case...
completion: That's their job, isn't it?  To argue.  So, I think my case will be long on talk and short on action.

prompt: But have never been?
completion: My only visits to Rome, Senator, have been through books.  But the war's over, time to close the door of war once and for all.

prompt: You know, general, there is a Gate of Janus in Rome which is only closed in time of peace.  Sadly, it has remained open for three hundred years.
completion: I've read of it.

prompt: God of passages and changes?
completion: I believe we are arriving in an enlightened age; an age of peace that will bring Rome her greatest glory.  Thanks to Marcus Aurelius.

prompt: I hope you live to see what I believe...
completion: The battle was won, today, and I prefer to believe it was a gift of Janus, the eldest God of Rome.  God of my ancestors.

prompt: The Senate too?
completion: The moment you returned from the battle your options were clear.  If you are a friend to neither side, legate, you must be an enemy to both.  We needed to know what you believed.

prompt: The trouble is defining exactly what 'right' is.
completion: We all know what right is, Senator.

prompt: Yes!  The days of Imperial Prerogative and disdain for the Senate are over -- thanks to your father!  Now report to the Senate, Master Galen:  what is Marcus' state?
completion: A republican is a man who strives to create equality among all classes.  At the core he's a man who believes in doing what's right.

prompt: You don't know how wrong you are.
completion: I would venture, with all respect: the Emperor's health is the business of every soul in the empire.

prompt: I need to give you my word when yours is worth nothing?
completion: You're a citizen and a soldier.  Not a gladiator.

prompt: When the Senate and the Emperor agree miracles can happen.
completion: Would you support the Senate if they would give you a trial?  You'd have to give me your word.

prompt: You're hearing about somebody else.
completion: How did you get condemned to the arena without a trial?

prompt: They can't... if this is Rome...
completion: Who are you?  Narcissus The Good?  I have heard of Narcissus Meridas. That's who I hear you are.

prompt: That's what worries me...
completion: Is this Rome?  Are we just going to be executed?

prompt: My loyalties... were in doubt.
completion: Fools to let us both live; we'll be our own best witnesses at our trial.

prompt: You on your way to trial, too, general?  Or do you think they've already had our trial?
completion: Why you?

prompt: Where are they?
completion: Hidden.  Where my brother cannot place hands on them.  He didn't have the guts to watch them die so... I took care of it all.  The sooner he is put out of our misery, the sooner will they be safe.

prompt: He killed his father and then my family...
completion: Narcissus, I have your family. They're alive.  All of them.

prompt: Would that Marcus had lived.
completion: Marcus would have lived but... was poisoned by his son.

prompt: "But what if I wish to be purple?"
completion: You cannot die.

prompt: Do you remember your Epictetus, that little homily we recited when we were children?  The one that was supposed to remind us we were Romans?
completion: "If you consider yourself to be only one thread of many in the tunic, then it is fitting for you to be like the rest of men, just as the thread has no desire to be any better than the other threads. But..."

prompt: For the sake of the Gods, you're not leading these men?  How like my father you are.  You 'believe'... I guess that's why you're still alive.
completion: To think I brought my daughters up on all things Roman.  Read to sleep on Catullus, Lucretius... Virgil... every night.  My beautiful daughters.

prompt: But you do exist.  Narcissus:  hero of the battle of the Danube.
completion: Twenty years I've led men to die. For me it was the glory of Rome. But that was something.  If it wasn't that, then it was the pay or the loot of the next whore -- but that was something!  These men here are butchered for laughs!  Their lives are like jokes delivered in the back alley theaters where their death is a punch line!

prompt: I came here to see that you stay alive.  The people need a living breathing alternative to Commodus, a hero.
completion: You mean a symbol of someone who doesn't exist.

prompt: It's my brother's neck you want, not mine.
completion: Yours will do!

prompt: I don't believe that.  He's got the best doctor in the world and a will of iron.  You know we're preparing for a full-blown invasion of Germany.
completion: Of course I know -- who do you think is paying for it?  The Emperor himself, didn't you know?  Why do you think Commodus came rushing up to the front?  Burning patriotism? Filial love?  He wants to be sure when he takes over there's enough cash left in the treasury to... play Emperor.  Watch out for him, Narcissus; he's inexperienced, but... be careful.

prompt: Why do you play at being drunk?
completion: How do you know I am playing?  Well, the clown is always harmless.  Isn't that right?  And how did you ever get to know me so well?  The last we spent any time together I was fourteen.  I think you know me better than my father.  He's going to die, isn't he?

prompt: I'm not fit for the job and as a matter of fact I'm not taking the job.
completion: Why do you keep playing at being so humble?  It's a little embarrassing.

prompt: Sneaking around with your brother?
completion: Without him.  He'd be weeping if he overheard that.  Well?  The idea of you as my adopted brother is very... exciting.

prompt: Only from a distance.
completion: I thought all good generals were quick to recognize opportunities.

prompt: Narcissus!  Terrified?  You?  The only thing he's scared of is me.
completion: You know our two most senior Senators:  Gaius Cantus and Falco Verus?

prompt: I'll do anything in my power to help you restore the Republic but I can't be that power.
completion: No future-telling, please, I've been terrified enough for one day.

prompt: They fear me.
completion: They fear change.  The new Caesar must be honest enough to know when the emperorship is no longer feasible.  You could be the one, the Emperor, the man who oversees the rebirth of the Republic.

prompt: Marcus, you honor me, but I'm a soldier, politics scare the hell out of me.
completion: The Senators admire you.

prompt: You're too hard on him.  He is a strong young man, with you as his guide...
completion: A man should be upright, not be kept upright.  History shows us that a good general is quick to recognize opportunities -- even if it means making a complete about face at the last minute.  I want you to consider becoming my heir.

prompt: So I understand.
completion: Everyone talking about it?  I wouldn't wonder.  All I seek is a genuine balance of power between the Emperor and the Senate.  Thus I have transferred legal power -- which was theirs to begin with -- back to the Senators.  This includes a shared right to taxation too but some bite in the plan.  It's a start, only a start.  If the Emperor and the Senate can share power then the people will be ready to take their share.  This means Commodus has to bend; does he strike you as that type?

prompt: Commodus is just a young man, he'll learn what you had to learn.
completion: It's not because he's young, it's because he's ignorant and arrogant. His sister is a better man.  That's why I have undertaken to begin sweeping changes in the relationship between the emperor and the Senate.

prompt: He's like you, sir, too tough for the Gods to swallow.
completion: If I'd ever had a sign that you wanted to rule I would have... no, again, it's my own bullheadedness. Narcissus, I should have adopted you years ago.  And now the Gods are begging me to make you my son!

prompt: There's no reason to say that. Everyone knows you're going to be well.  I had Servis groom your horse for a triumphal visit to the front at first light.
completion: Servis made it through again?

prompt: I will, Marcus.  But you're going to be well enough to direct it yourself.
completion: I've made so many mistakes, Narcissus.  We all put off the very last duties of our lives because we're afraid of admitting when our lives are over.

prompt: Commodus -- listen to Narcissus, listen to the man who has never lost a battle for Rome!  You're young with years ahead of you before you gain the experience to wear the purple!
completion: I want you to start your work for the last phase of the campaign.

prompt: Commodus, it's we who are going on the offensive.
