completion: Oh, you did! Well, that's very, very interesting. This happens to be the gun that Earl Williams shot his way out with!

prompt: Get out!
completion: Close that door. Don't let anybody in or out.

prompt: If you've any accusations to make, Hartman, make them in the proper manner. Otherwise, I'll have to ask you to get out.
completion: You'll ask me to what?

prompt: Who do you think you are, breaking in here like this?
completion: You can't bluff me, Burns. I don't care who you are or what paper you're editor of.

prompt: Save that for the Tribune.
completion: What did you say your name was -- Pinkus?

prompt: Out of the mouths of babes.
completion: He's insane or drunk or something. Why, if this unfortunate man, Williams, has really been reprieved, I personally am tickled to death. Aren't you, Pete?

prompt: The power of the press, huh!
completion: That's absurd on the face of it, Mr. Burns! He's talking like a child.

prompt: All the lawyers in the world aren't going to help you!
completion: This is the Morning Post you're talking to!

prompt: Your luck's not with you now!
completion: Duffy! Get Liebowitz!

prompt: You -- you!!
completion: Does it? You forget the power that always watches over the Morning Post.

prompt: Sure, Heaven! You've probably thought up another coal mine to send me down in -- to get a new story for your paper!
completion: But, Hildy -- I can explain --

prompt: Yes -- 'Hildy, darling'. I'm just a fool. That's what I am. I know what it's going to be like.
completion: It'll be Heaven!

prompt: Sure, I can. Look at the policy I gave him!  "With this ring I thee wed and with all my worldly goods I thee endow: And thereto I plight thee my troth."
completion: Hildy, darling!

prompt: How about Bruce's?
completion: Walter, you can't do that!

prompt: Hildy, from this time on no tricks, no double-crossing -- everything on the level!
completion: You're not fooling anybody.

prompt: Now don't argue, Hildy.  How about it, Judge?
completion: That's what he said the last time. Don't believe him, Judge.

prompt: I don't want to rush you. Take a couple of seconds.
completion: What!

prompt: What's the good of arguing about something that probably doesn't exist? Look, Hildy, I'm proposing to you. What do you say?
completion: Well, I'd like to be lady-like and think it over.

prompt: Well, if she looked like you -- Say! My brains and your looks -- that mightn't be such a bad combination.
completion: What's the matter with my brains?

prompt: Sure, I can't last forever. I want a son I can train to take my place on this paper.
completion: What would you do if it was a daughter?

prompt: Sure I do. And I'll tell you something else -- I'd like a baby.
completion: Walter!

prompt: Hildy, if that's what you want, all right. We'll even go to -- how about Niagara Falls?
completion: Niagara Falls! Walter, you don't mean that?

prompt: That's what makes it romantic. Every other married couple goes away on a honeymoon and for two weeks the bride knows just where the groom is, and vice versa. But us -- you never know where I am and I'm not sure where you are. That's Romance!
completion: Well, maybe I'd like to know just once!

prompt: Sure, it was good -- it was wonderful! Only you expected it to be like other marriages. It can't be like other marriages -- we're different! We're a different world. Look at what we went through today. I wouldn't trade that for any honeymoon in the world. I bet you wouldn't, either.
completion: A fine honeymoon, with a murderer right in the boudoir! And that other honeymoon in a coal mine!

prompt: Both jobs are open, Hildy. The paper -- and being Mrs. Walter Burns.
completion: Thanks, Walter, but it's no good. We tried it.

prompt: Sure.
completion: It's awfully clear now. Bruce needs a wife who can give him a home -- and affection -- and peace. I couldn't do that for him, Walter. I'm what you made me -- a cheap reporter who'd give up her soul for a story!... Is that job still open?

prompt: Where'd you wire him?
completion: On the nine o'clock train. That's the one he took, isn't it?

prompt: What do you mean? Bruce'll be waiting for you in Albany.
completion: No, he won't. I wired him that I wasn't coming.

prompt: And what a way to quit. While you're still champion! That's the way to leave, Hildy!
completion: Yeah. Only -- only I'm not leaving, Walter.

prompt: The greatest yarn ever written by anybody. My hat's off to you, Hildy!
completion: Thanks.

prompt: Then why are you doing it?
completion: Because I'm a newspaper woman, Heaven help me!

prompt: Hildy!
completion: Don't touch me! I'm not doing it for you!

prompt: Well -- what is it?
completion: What's the difference? I'm going to write that story -- and you know it!

prompt: Flip a coin.
completion: All right.  Heads I go -- tails I stay to write the story. Ready?

prompt: He's going to have you the rest of his life, Hildy. Can't you give me another hour?
completion: I don't know what to do, Walter.

prompt: Suit yourself, kid. This isn't for me to decide. Of course, you could make a later train and still be in Albany tomorrow morning.
completion: Yeah. I suppose I could. But, Walter --

prompt: Bruce is making the nine o'clock train. I told him you'd be on it -- unless you want to write this story yourself.
completion: Well, if it's my last story, I'd like it to be a good one. But -- I guess I can't, Walter.

prompt: Sorry, Hildy. I didn't mean to be making love to another man's fiancee.
completion: That's all right, Walter. It's as much my fault as yours.

prompt: In the Shoreland Hotel. And our only chaperon was the poor old lady's stomach.
completion: Don't remind me. That's how we happened to --

prompt: Yeah - but that time we stole Old Lady Haggerty's stomach off the Coroner's physician. We proved she was poisoned though, didn't we?
completion: We sure did, but we had to go in hiding for a week.

prompt: Remember the time we broke into the D.A.'s office, and copied Fifi Randell's diary?
completion: Yeah. What about the time we hid the missing heiress in the sauerkraut factory? Six scoop interviews!

prompt: I mean -- working together. Just like the old days. The things we've been through, Hildy.
completion: We've certainly been in some swell jams.

prompt: Uh-uh. As long as we were in there together pitching -- they couldn't lick us. Well, it's been a lot of fun.
completion: In a way.

prompt: Don't tell me you were worried!
completion: Worried! I was petrified. Weren't you?

prompt: And your arrest. You'll each get about ten years, I think.
completion: How was that for a tight squeeze?

prompt: Which ought to be about three hours more, I'd say.
completion: Just until we can get out a special edition asking for your impeachment.

prompt: When did you deliver this first?
completion: Who did you talk to?

prompt: Murder, uh?
completion: Hanging an innocent man to win an election!

prompt: Yes! What are you afraid of Hildy? I dare him to move that desk out of here.
completion: Wait a minute!  Let go there!

prompt: What is it? Here!
completion: No!

prompt: Who says so? I'm going to the morgue -- to look --
completion: No, you don't! Walter!

prompt: I don't care what you say. I'm going to find Bruce's mother.  Oh-h...  I'm going out and find her!
completion: Don't open that!

prompt: Yes.
completion: Hildy, you just can't leave me out on a limb now. It -- it wouldn't be cricket!

prompt: Oh, I see. I beg your pardon.
completion: When I'm surrounded, with my back against the wall, you're not going to lay down on me, are you --

prompt: Hello -- hello! Is this the Lying -- In Hospital? Did you have an auto accident in the last --
completion: Will you come here?

prompt: Ring that number, will you?
completion: Come here. See if we can move it.

prompt: Lafayette two-one-hundred.
completion: That dumb immigrant'll flop on me. I know it.  Can you imagine Butch doing this to me -- at a time like this?

prompt: Shut up, will you?  You sure? Nobody?
completion: Duffy!!!!   Duffy!!!!  Well, where is Duffy?  Diabetes! I ought to know better than to hire anybody with a disease.  Louie.

prompt: Hello, Max, Hildy Johnson. Was there an old lady --?
completion: Butch! I'd put my arm in fire for you -- up to here!  Now, you can't double-cross me!... She does? All right -- put her on. I'll talk to her... Hello! Oh, hello, Madam... Now listen, you ten-cent glamour girl, you can't keep Butch away from his duty... What's that? You say that again and I'll come over there and knock your eye out! Hello?  I'll kill 'em! I'll kill both of 'em!  Duffy!  Mousing around with some big blonde Annie on my time! That's co-operation!  Duffy!!

prompt: Is this the Community Hospital?
completion: I don't care if you've been after her for six years! Butch, our whole lives are at stake! Are you going to let a woman come between us after all we've been through?

prompt: Nobody?  Morningside three-one-two-four.
completion: I can't hear... You got who? Speak up! A what?... You can't stop for a dame now!

prompt: Hello -- Eddie? Hildy Johnson. Was there an old lady brought in from an auto smashup?
completion: Oh, for --  H. Sebastian -- Butch! Listen, it's a matter of life and death! Listen!

prompt: Mission Hospital? Gimme the Receiving Room.
completion: What are you doing there? Haven't you even started?

prompt: Gimme Western four-five-five-seven.
completion: Who?  Hello, Butch! Where are you?

prompt: Louie, where'd it happen? I'm going out!
completion: Hello -- hello...

prompt: I'm looking at you -- you murderer!
completion: If it was my own mother, I'd carry on! You know I would. For the paper!

prompt: I killed her. I'm responsible. Oh- h... what can I do now? How can I ever face him? Oh, I hope he never comes back!
completion: Look at me, Hildy --

prompt: What am I going to say to Bruce? What'll I tell him?
completion: If he really loves you, you won't have to tell him anything.  Snap out of it! Would you rather have had the old dame dragging the whole police force in here?

prompt: Was she? Did you notice?
completion: It's Fate, Hildy. What will be, will be.

prompt: Louie!
completion: Don't tell me -- was she killed?

prompt: You been in a fight?
completion: Where is she? Tell me!

prompt: What did you do with her?
completion: What happened?

prompt: Hildy, you think I could? After this story?  Here! You're just nervous.
completion: Where's Mrs. Baldwin?

prompt: Finished!
completion: Bruce ought to be back by now. Walter, you're not trying anything again, are you?

prompt: Tear into it, will you? Don't sit there like a frozen robin!
completion: I'm finished.

prompt: Double-crossing swine!
completion: You said it! But this'll teach him a lesson. He won't quit his paper without giving notice after this.

prompt: Is he coming back here?
completion: Didn't you hear him? Of course he's coming back here. Keep going, will you?

prompt: What tickets?
completion: Railroad tickets.

prompt: Where's Bruce?
completion: Bruce? Oh -- er -- he went out to get the tickets.

prompt: Where's Butch?
completion: Well, keep going! We want an extra out on the streets before it's too late!

prompt: All right, Walter.
completion: Listen, did you impress it on Butch that I want him and his gang here right away? You did? Every minute counts. All right.  Duffy's getting old!

prompt: Okay, Walter.
completion: Hildy!

prompt: Give him the works.  Hello, Duffy, get set! We've got the biggest story in the world. Earl Williams caught by the Morning Post -- exclusive!
completion: For Pete's sake, Hildy, they're waiting for the rest of that story!

prompt: Call him a love-child, if you want to.  Duffy!
completion: How about the time he had his house painted by the Fire Department?

prompt: Where's some paper?
completion: Can I call the Mayor a bird of prey -- or is that libelous?

prompt: How much do you want on it?
completion: All the words you've got.

prompt: Huh!
completion: Get the lead out of your typewriter and start pounding out a load, will you? Snap into it!

prompt: We'll lower it out of the window with pulleys. Quit stallin'.
completion: Hildy!

prompt: Not if he's inside the desk. We'll carry the desk over.  Give me Duffy!
completion: You can't take that desk out. It's crawling with cops outside.

prompt: We're going to take him over to my private office.  Where's our phone?
completion: That one -- how you gonna take him? They'll see him.

prompt: Attagirl! Why, they'll be naming streets after you -- Hildy Johnson Street! There'll be statues of you in the parks, Hildy. The radio'll be after you -- the movies!  By tomorrow morning I'll betcha there's a Hildy Johnson cigar! I can see the billboards now. Light up with Hildy Johnson!
completion: Whoa -- wait a minute. We can't leave Williams here. One of the other fellows'll --

prompt: You've kicked over the whole City Hall like an apple-cart. You've got the Mayor and Hartman backed against a wall. You've put one administration out and another in. This isn't a newspaper story -- it's a career! And you stand there belly-aching about whether you catch an eight o'clock train or a nine o'clock train! Still a doll-faced mugg! That's all you are.
completion: Let me get at that typewriter and I'll show you how a doll-faced mugg can write!

prompt: Well, think it then, because it's true! We'll crucify that mob. We're going to keep Williams under cover till morning so the Post can break the story exclusive. Then we'll let the Governor in on the capture -- share the glory with him.
completion: I get it!

prompt: Don't get technical at a time like this! Do you realize what you've done? You've taken a city that's been graft-ridden for forty years under the same old gang and with this yarn you're kicking 'em out and giving us a chance to have the same kind of government that New York's having under La Guardia! We'll make such monkeys out of these ward-heelers next Tuesday that nobody'll vote for them -- not even their wives!
completion: I'd like to think.

prompt: You know! You've got the brain of a pancake! That wasn't just a story you covered -- it was a revolution! Hildy! This is the greatest yarn in journalism since Livingstone discovered Stanley for the New York Herald!
completion: Wait a minute -- wasn't it Stanley who discovered Livingstone?

prompt: You drooling idiot! What do you mean, you're getting out! There are three hundred and sixty-five days in the year one can get married -- but how many times have you got a murderer locked up in a desk? -- Once in a lifetime! Hildy, you've got the whole city by the seat of the pants!
completion: I know, but --

prompt: Get Bruce out of jail! How can you worry about a man who's resting comfortably in a quiet police station while this is going on? Hildy, this is war! You can't desert now!
completion: Oh, get off that trapeze!  There's your story! Smear it all over the front page -- Earl Williams caught by the Morning Post! And take all the credit -- I covered your story for you and I got myself in a fine mess doing it -- and now I'm getting out! I know I told you that twice before today -- but this time I mean it!

prompt: Where do you think you're going?
completion: Let go o' me! I've got to get Bruce out of jail! Oh, Walter, why did you have to do this to me?

prompt: She jumped out of the window.
completion: I know. Where is he, I said.

prompt: Walter! D-did you see --  -- that?
completion: Yes. Where is he?

prompt: It better be fifteen minutes, because Bruce is waiting downstairs in a taxicab and that meter's clicking away to beat the band.
completion: Hold on a minute.

prompt: No, this is on the level, Walter. I'm not good enough to make this one up. The Sheriff gave his gun to the Professor, the Professor gave it to Earl, and Earl gave it right back to the Professor -- right in the stomach! Who? No, Egelhoffer wasn't hurt badly. They took him to the County Hospital where they're afraid he'll recover.
completion: That's great work, Hildy... Huh? Oh, will you stop worrying about the money? I'll see you get it in fifteen minutes.

prompt: Well, I'm coming to it. It seems the Professor had to have a gun to re- enact the crime with -- and who do you suppose supplied it? Nobody else but that great thinker, Sheriff Hartman!
completion: No kidding, Hildy.  Say, this isn't a rib?

prompt: I meant on my grandmother's grave. Don't be so technical, Hildy. What's the story?!
completion: Well, this expert Dr. Egelhoffer, from New York, decides to make Williams re-enact the crime --

prompt: You'll get it. Now what's the story?  I'll have the paper send the money right down to you. I swear it on my mother's grave.
completion: Wait a minute. Your mother's alive.

prompt: Never mind that. What's the story?
completion: Never mind it? That's not my money! That's Bruce's money!

prompt: Exclusive? That's great.
completion: It cost me four hundred and fifty bucks to tear it out of Cooley.

prompt: All right. The check will be certified. Want my fingerprints?
completion: No thanks, I've still got those. Well, I'll step into some working clothes and hop over to the Press Room for the background on this yarn. It'll be kind of fun to see the boys again, too. Remember, Bruce, it must be certified.

prompt: What do you think I am -- a crook?
completion: Yes --- and that's putting it mildly! No certified check -- no story -- Get me?

prompt: What tricks would I pull?
completion: Oh, nothing! Of course, you might cancel the check. Yes! Wait a minute! What would be his first payment on that policy?

prompt: Now you're talking!
completion: You keep out of this. Bruce, suppose you examine Mr. Burns in his office. I'll get my bag and go over to the Press Room in the Criminal Courts Building. You phone me as soon as Mr. Burns has given you his check. Then I'll go get the interview and you phone Mother that we're taking the six o'clock train.  And no tricks, Walter!

prompt: We're not interested.
completion: Maybe you'll be. You're a smart young man. You let Hildy do this story for me and you can write out a $100,000.00 insurance policy for me. What do you say?

prompt: I happen to know Sweeney was married only three months ago. If he's got twins this morning, I claim it was done with mirrors.
completion: All right, Hildy, I'm licked. But I'll make you and Bruce a business proposition.

prompt: Well, it's either an act on your part or a miracle on Sweeney's.
completion: What do you mean?

prompt: What a performance! Bravo! Don't let him fool you, Bruce -- it's only an act!
completion: What do you mean, only an act? Haven't you got any feeling?

prompt: You see what I had to put up with? She never trusted me! You argue with her -- otherwise you're going on a honeymoon with blood on your hands!
completion: How can you have any happiness after that? All through the years you'll remember that a man went to the gallows because you were too selfish to wait two hours! I tell you, Earl Williams' face will come between you on the train tonight -- and at the preacher's tomorrow -- and all the rest of your lives!

prompt: I'm an editor. I know what ought to be written, but I can't write it the way you could. It needs a woman's heart --
completion: Why, Walter, you're getting poetic!

prompt: Especially with an election coming up in a few days.
completion: No, Bruce, dear. Don't you see? This is a trick to get your sympathy. No, Walter, I've been waiting for something like this -- but I wasn't sure when you'd spring it. If you want to save Earl Williams' life, you can interview him yourself. You're still a good reporter. Bruce and I will be on that four o'clock train -- and thanks just the same.

prompt: Because it happened to be a colored policeman.
completion: The colored vote happens to be very important to the Mayor of this town.

prompt: So -- Sweeney gets twins -- and Earl Williams gets hanged tomorrow.
completion: If he's nuts, why doesn't the State just put him away?

prompt: His wife had twins and he went out to celebrate and got as drunk as a lord. They can't even find him.  I tell you, drink is the ruin of this nation.
completion: You said it.

prompt: Thank you.
completion: What now?

prompt: Anyway, I'm glad you two are going to be happy and have all the things I couldn't give her. You know, Hildy is about the best reporter in the country -- and that goes regardless of sex. But all she really ever wanted was a home.
completion: Here's luck to the bride and bridegroom.

prompt: Well, I'll tell you one thing, old man, she never looked at me the way she's looking at you.
completion: I might have, Walter, but you were never there.

prompt: I suppose I can't call this off without creating a scene -- but remember, it's your last fling.
completion: How do you like that? Here I am being nice to you and your sweet-heart and that's the thanks I get!

prompt: Allow me.
completion: Thanks.

prompt: And when he walks with a lady, he waits for her!
completion: Oh, I'm sorry.

prompt: And he takes his hat off when he's with a lady.
completion: What for?

prompt: You wouldn't believe this, Walter, but Bruce holds the door open for me.
completion: No kidding?

prompt: Now you got me.
completion: Nothing personal. I was just asking.

prompt: Better.
completion: Then what does he want with you?

prompt: Afraid? I should say not!
completion: All right then, come on and let's see this paragon.  Is he as good as you say?

prompt: Oh, better not, Walter. Wouldn't do any good.
completion: You're not afraid, are you?

prompt: Well, he's waiting in the anteroom for me now.
completion: Say, could I meet him?

prompt: Thanks...
completion: Too bad I couldn't see this guy first. I'm pretty particular about whom my wife marries.

prompt: The quicker the better. Well -- I finally got out what I came in to tell you.  So long, Walter, and better luck next time.
completion: I wish you everything I couldn't give you, Hildy.

prompt: Well, I'll give you a hint. By tomorrow they'll be calling me Mrs. Bruce Baldwin.
completion: Tomorrow? Tomorrow... as quick as that?

prompt: I don't know about water buffaloes, but I know about him. He's kind and sweet and considerate. He wants a home -- and children.
completion: Say, sounds more like a guy I ought to marry. What's his name?

prompt: Well, I can, and I love it! He forgets the office when he's with me. He doesn't treat me like an errand-boy -- he treats me like a woman.
completion: He does, does he? How did I treat you -- like a water buffalo?

prompt: It's a good, honest business, isn't it?
completion: Oh sure, it's honest. But somehow, I can't picture you with a guy who sells policies.

prompt: He's in the insurance business.
completion: The insurance business?

prompt: Not what you'd call rich. Makes about five thousand a year.
completion: What's his line?

prompt: Bermuda.
completion: Bermuda... Rich, eh?

prompt: A journalist! Peeking through keyholes -- running after fire engines -- waking people up in the middle of the night to ask them if they think Hitler's going to start a war -- stealing pictures off old ladies of their daughters that got chased by apemen! I know all about reporters -- a lot of daffy buttinskies going around without a nickel in their pockets, and for what? So a million hired girls and motormen's wives will know what's going on! No, Walter, I'm through.
completion: Where'd you meet this man?

prompt: That's why I'm quitting. I want to go some place where I can be a woman.
completion: I know you, Hildy, and I know what it would mean. It would kill you.

prompt: You can't sell me that, Walter.
completion: Who says I can't? You're a newspaper man.

prompt: I tried to tell you right away but you started reminiscing. I'm getting married, Walter, and also getting as far away from the newspaper business as I can get! I'm through.
completion: Get married all you want to, Hildy, but you can't quit the newspaper business.

prompt: Oh! In that case, the raise is off and you go back to your old salary and like it. Trying to blackjack --
completion: Look at this!

prompt: Great grief! What's that other paper going to give you?
completion: I'm not working for any other paper!

prompt: All right -- thirty-five, and not a cent more!
completion: Please! Will you just --

prompt: If you won't do it for love, how about money? Forget the other offer and I'll raise you twenty-five bucks a week.
completion: Listen, you bumble-headed baboon --

prompt: Don't mock, Hildy, this is bigger than anything that's happened to us. Don't do it for me! Do it for the paper.
completion: Get away, Svengali.

prompt: It'll bring us together again, Hildy -- just the way we used to be.
completion: That's what I'm afraid of. "Any time -- any place -- anywhere!"

prompt: You've got to help me, Hildy.
completion: Keep away --

prompt: There's nobody else on the paper who can write! This'll break me, unless --  Hildy!
completion: No!

prompt: I don't care whether he did or not. He's supposed to be covering the Earl Williams case and there he is -- waiting at the hospital! Is there no sense of honor left in this country?
completion: Well, haven't you got anybody else?

prompt: Not yet. Might just as well be. The only man on the paper who can write -- and his wife picks this morning to have a baby!
completion: Sweeney?  Well, after all, he didn't do it on purpose, did he?

prompt: Sweeney.
completion: Dead?

prompt: Sweeney! You can't do that to me! Not today, of all days! Jumping Jehosophat! Oh, no, Sweeney... Well, I suppose so... All right. If you have to, you have to.  How do you like that? Everything happens to me -- with 365 days in the year -- this has to be the day.
completion: What's the matter?

prompt: Well, you practically did! Making goo-goo eyes at me for two years till I broke down. And I still claim I was tight the night I proposed. If you'd been a gentleman you'd have forgotten all about it. But not you!
completion: You -- you --

prompt: It would have worked if you'd been satisfied with just being editor and reporter. But no! You had to marry me and spoil everything.
completion: I wasn't satisfied! I suppose I proposed to you!

prompt: I made a great reporter out of you, Hildy, but you won't be half as good on any other paper, and you know it. You need me and I need you -- and the paper needs both of us.
completion: Well, the paper'll have to learn to do without me. And so will you. It just didn't work out, Walter.

prompt: Why should I? I thought it would be a novelty to have a face around here a man could look at without shuddering.
completion: Listen, Walter --

prompt: What were you when you came here five years ago? A little college girl from a School of Journalism! I took a little doll-faced mugg --
completion: You wouldn't have taken me if I hadn't been doll-faced!

prompt: Well, go on and take it. Work for somebody else! That's the gratitude I get for --
completion: I know, Walter, but I --

prompt: You've had a better offer, eh?
completion: You bet I've got a better offer.

prompt: You mean you're not coming back to work here?
completion: That's the first time you've been right today. That's what I --

prompt: What do you mean by that?
completion: Just what I said. That's what I --

prompt: Sure you can. Come on.
completion: Don't tell me what to do! We're divorced -- I'm a free woman. You're not my husband and you're not my boss! And what's more, you're not going to be my boss.

prompt: You can break it, can't you?
completion: No, I can't.

prompt: Sure, come on. We'll have some lunch and you can tell me everything.
completion: I have a lunch date. I just want --

prompt: I haven't any hard feelings.
completion: Walter, you're wonderful in a loathesome sort of way. Now, would you mind keeping quiet long enough for me to tell you what I came up here for?

prompt: Let's not fight, Hildy. Tell you what. You come back to work on the paper and if we find we can't get along in a friendly way, we'll get married again.
completion: What?!!

prompt: Deny it! I'm proud of it! We beat the whole country on that story.
completion: Well, suppose we did? That isn't what I got married for. What's the good of -- Look, Walter, I came up here to tell you that you'll have to stop phoning me a dozen times a day -- sending twenty telegrams -- all the rest of it, because I'm --

prompt: Was it my fault? Did I know that coal mine was going to have another cave-in? I meant to be with you on our honeymoon, Hildy -- honest I did.
completion: All I know is that instead of two weeks in Atlantic City with my bridegroom, I spent two weeks in a coal mine with John Kruptzky -- age sixty-three -- getting food and air out of a tube! You don't deny that. Do you?

prompt: Well, I don't want to brag, but I've still got the dimple -- and in the same place -- I just acted like any husband who doesn't want to see his home broken up.
completion: What home?

prompt: Well, I meant to let you go -- but, you know, you never miss the water till the well runs dry.
completion: A fellow your age, hiring an airplane to write:  'Hildy: Don't be hasty -- remember my dimple. Walter.! It held things up twenty minutes while the Judge ran out to watch it.

prompt: Now, that's a nice thing to say.
completion: Well, why did you promise me you wouldn't fight the divorce and then try and gum up the whole works?

prompt: Nonsense. You've got the old-fashioned idea that divorces are something that last forever -- till 'death us do part'. Why, a divorce doesn't mean anything today. It's only a few words mumbled over you by a judge. We've got something between us nothing can change.
completion: I suppose that's true in a way. I am fond of you, Walter. I often wish you weren't such a stinker.

prompt: Divorced me. It sort of makes a fellow lose faith in himself. It almost gives him a feeling he wasn't wanted.
completion: Holy mackerel! Look, Walter, that's what divorces are for.

prompt: You know, Hildy, I sort of wish you hadn't done it.
completion: Done what?

prompt: I notice you still remember it.
completion: I'll always remember it. If I hadn't remembered it, I wouldn't have divorced you.

prompt: Oh, yes I would. I'd know you any time --
completion: You're repeating yourself! That's the speech you made the night you proposed.  "-- any time -- any place -- anywhere!"

prompt: Maybe it was yesterday. Been seeing me in your dreams?
completion: No -- Mama doesn't dream about you any more, Walter. You wouldn't know the old girl now.

prompt: You know what. How long since we've seen each other?
completion: Let's see. I was in Reno six weeks -- then Bermuda... Oh, about four months, I guess. Seems like yesterday to me.

prompt: Hello, Walter.  Hi, Louie -- how's the slotmachine king?
completion: How long is what?

prompt: Why, I'm surprised, Mr. Burns. That's no way to talk to your wife -- even if she's no longer your wife.
completion: Hello, Hildy!

prompt: Let me out! Let me out of here!
completion: What do you want?

prompt: Oh, dear! Oh, dear!
completion: You grey-haired old Judas!

prompt: Come on, Sheriff. We've got to get bail.
completion: I was in here -- and they had some kind of murderer in with them. They were hiding him!

prompt: Are you referring to me, Madam?
completion: You know you did!

prompt: Louie, take this lady over to Polack Mike's and lock her up. See that she doesn't take to anyone on the way.
completion: What's that -- what's that?

prompt: I mean real money -- not counterfeit!
completion: I always have both.

prompt: You got plenty of money?
completion: Sure, boss.

prompt: Anybody with hair on his chest. Get 'em off the street -- anywhere. Offer them anything -- only get them.  We've got to get this desk out of here.
completion: You know me. The shirt off my back.

prompt: Beat it out and get hold of some guys.
completion: Who do you want?

prompt: Western an' Thirty-fourth.
completion: Anything you want, Boss.

prompt: I don't think she's talking much... You know what I mean?
completion: You stay here. I'll find out everything.

prompt: What do you mean, I handed her? The patrol wagon was on the wrong side of the street.
completion: Now everything's fine. She's probably squawking her head off in some police station.

prompt: Take that mush out of your mouth!
completion: Butter-fingers! I give you an old lady to take somewhere, and you hand her over to the cops!

prompt: Don't worry, Duffy, you'll have it back by five.  Thanks, Duffy. Stick around.
completion: Down Western Avenue. We were going sixty-five miles an hour. You know what I mean?

prompt: Yeah! Well, I do the firing, too. Remember that, Duffy, and Keep a civil tongue in your head.
completion: Here's that certified check, Walter.  I drew out my wife's savings, and if this isn't back by 5:30 I'm a ruined man!

prompt: They can't do that to me!
completion: Don't blame me. I'm City Editor in name only. You do all the hiring around here.

prompt: You're crazy. Where's Mac?
completion: He's on my phone. He just called me.

prompt: What?
completion: And that means Earl Williams dies tomorrow morning and makes a sucker out of us!

prompt: I'm busy, Duffy.
completion: Well, you're not too busy to know that the Governor hasn't signed that reprieve!

prompt: First we talk. How did Earl Williams get that gun?
completion: Walter!

prompt: It's a deal. Let me up.
completion: Let's see the money.

prompt: How much?
completion: Four hundred and fifty dollars. Is it a deal?

prompt: I can't Hildy. It means my job! It means --
completion: A lot of money.  Four hundred and fifty dollars --

prompt: Hildy -- I can't. I'm busy -- I -- Let me up, Hildy. Earl Williams has escaped --
completion: There's money in it, Cooley.

prompt: I thought so. Come on, I'm in a hurry.
completion: Cooley, I want to talk to you.

prompt: Say, isn't this your twenty dollars?
completion: I think it is.

prompt: I want to interview Earl Williams, Warden. How about a little service?
completion: No more interviews. Besides, a doctor's coming over.

prompt: Come, come, Sheriff, lightning doesn't strike in the same place twice. Nothing's going to happen.
completion: Hello, Hildy! What are you doing around here?

prompt: Yes, I suppose so. It all helps.
completion: I don't know --

prompt: Yes, shaking hands. I don't take a very good picture, though.
completion: It doesn't matter. The publicity's the main thing.

prompt: We'll have to satisfy them. What would you say to giving them a joint interview? I could give them some of the psychological aspects of the case and you could give them the legal aspects.
completion: A joint interview, eh? That might be all right. We could have our pictures taken together, Doctor.

prompt: Of course, I sort of promised them I would give out a statement when I got through here. You don't mind?
completion: Well, I don't know if that's ethical. You see, all statements are supposed to come from me.

prompt: They're always after me for interviews.
completion: Me, too.

prompt: The newspapers! Sheriff, they're the scum of modern civilization.
completion: You said it!

prompt: Well, it wasn't exactly that way --
completion: Point the gun at me!

prompt: Yes, sir.
completion: So -- now I say to you: 'Earl Williams, you are under arrest!' and you point your gun at me.

prompt: In a legal sense, yes. But not actually. Actually, I'm innocent. I didn't do anything.
completion: Now, the Sheriff will be Mollie Malloy, in whose room you were. You will be Earl Williams. And I will be the policeman. Follow me, Mr. Williams?

prompt: The system. But I'm not afraid to die, Doctor. I'm dying for what I believe.
completion: I see. You realize, however, that you committed a crime?

prompt: Oh, I'm sorry. I forgot you were here. No, Mr. Williams, we still have some questions for you. Sheriff, will you kindly extinguish the lights?
completion: You know you are to be executed, Mr. Williams. Who do you feel is responsible for that?

prompt: Aw, why don't you let her alone? She's ill!
completion: Are you gentlemen all through with me?

prompt: It's easy for you to talk. You're retired. We're still working.
completion: Better let us in on it, Mollie.

prompt: Okay.  Up you go, Mollie.
completion: A fine bunch of reporters. Biggest story in two years and they're too lazy to go after it.

prompt: She looks as though she's going to come to.
completion: Give me a hand with her, will you?

prompt: Mollie Malloy -- what happened to her?
completion: Came up here -- had hysterics and passed out. I've been trying to get her to come to.

prompt: Kind of exclusive, ain't you? We got calls to make, you know.
completion: Run down and get some smelling salts, will you?

prompt: Hey!
completion: Mollie, drop down here! You've fainted!

prompt: Open up there, will you!
completion: All right -- all right!

prompt: Who locked the door?
completion: Just a second, Mike ---  Mollie, I got it!

prompt: Three bullets! Any good?
completion: Beats king up.

prompt: I know, I just want to give him a thrill.
completion: I call. What you got?

prompt: Good. Now I want to ask you fellows a couple of questions. Did Earl Williams know what he was doing when he fired that gun?
completion: Say, that's old Prissy Bensinger's desk.

prompt: I'll have it in a minute.
completion: Well, that about covers everything.

prompt: Make them talk and you got Williams, Pinky!
completion: Hold the phone!

prompt: Where is he, before we beat it out of you?
completion: Come on, Pinky! Give 'em a little third degree.

prompt: Come on, you! Before we slap you down.
completion: Do you want us to call the cops and have them give you the boots?

prompt: Oh, you two are pals now -- I think you're right, Endicott. Mollie did give her some kind of story.
completion: I tell you, it's a screwy set-up. We better hold onto 'em both.

prompt: Say, Hildy, if I know you, you sound pretty anxious to get rid of us. Are you trying to scoop us or something?
completion: Something smells around here. If you ask me Mollie gave her the story on how Williams got that gun.  Did you smuggle that gun into Williams, Mollie?

prompt: What's the dope, Sheriff?
completion: Who engineered this getaway?

prompt: Call you back.
completion: So have we!

prompt: No, I tell you! Nobody knows where he got it.
completion: The Crime Commission has offered a reward of ten thousand dollars for Williams' capture.

prompt: Boy, did you see her go?
completion: Lioness Rushes to Defense of Cub.

prompt: You guys wanna play some more poker?
completion: What's the use? I can't win a pot.

prompt: She says she's gonna write fiction.
completion: Well, if she's gonna write fiction, there's nothing like being a reporter.

prompt: Well, a guy can win when Hildy ain't around.
completion: Who's this guy she's gonna marry?

prompt: Trouble is, when the Red Menace shows up the Sheriff will still be crying 'Wolf!'
completion: What have you got, Hildy?

prompt: Yeah? What did he ever do for his country?
completion: Don't you remember? He's the guy went to Washington to interview the Brain Trust, and gave out a statement that they were all sane. It created a sensation!

prompt: That must be the tenth alienist they've had on Williams. Even if he wasn't crazy before, he would be after ten of those babies got through psychoanalyzing him.  Gimme the desk.
completion: This Egelhoffer's pretty good.

prompt: We know what you're up to.
completion: Probably goin' out to get Williams.

prompt: You ain't gettin' out o' here!
completion: Now, where is he?

prompt: What a chase!
completion: No luck on Williams, yet -- call you back.

prompt: Goodbye, Yonson.
completion: So long, Hildy.

prompt: I'll call.
completion: Three sixes. Is that any good?

prompt: Gus, this --
completion: Good coffee, isn't it?

prompt: Oh, I'm sorry, Gus! My foot must have slipped.
completion: That's all right.

prompt: No -- just coffee, Gus.
completion: Just coffee.  And you, sir?

prompt: Little rum in yours, too?
completion: I guess so.

prompt: I can't complain.
completion: Oh -- I'll take the same, I guess. And coffee.

prompt: All right! Carl! Frank! One of you get on each side of the desk. Take hold of the cover.
completion: How's everything, Gus?

prompt: He can't hurt anybody. You've got his gun.
completion: That's murder!

prompt: He's harmless.
completion: Don't take any chances. Shoot through the desk.

prompt: What?
completion: With a bag of marshmallows.

prompt: Not this gun!
completion: He went over to the hospital to call on Professor Egelhoffer.

prompt: Where'd you get this?
completion: I've got a right to carry a gun if I want to.

prompt: What do I know about Williams?
completion: All right, boys. Take her along. I got ways of making her talk.

prompt: Nobody's trying to put anything over on you. I'm getting out of here and you can't stop me!
completion: Johnson, I'm going to the bottom of this. What do you know about Williams? Are you going to talk or aren't you?

prompt: You can send somebody with me if you don't believe me!
completion: I wasn't born yesterday. Now the boys tell me you and this Mollie Malloy --

prompt: I don't know anything, I tell you. There's been an accident.
completion: Johnson, there's something very peculiar going on.

prompt: Let me go!  Fellows, something's happened to my mother-in-law.
completion: Hang onto her! Keep her in here!

prompt: Take your paws off me!
completion: Hold her, boys!

prompt: Just a minute, Johnson!
completion: Let go o' me. What's the idea?

prompt: You ought to stay over. You always wrote a good hanging story, Hildy.
completion: That's awful kind of you, Sheriff. I've got to get started on my interview. See you later.

prompt: Oh, that'll be all right, Hildy. Go ahead, run it. And you can say I treated him well, too.  'Lo, Earl. How are you feeling?
completion: No, thanks Sheriff. I'm leaving town tonight.

prompt: Now, wait a minute! I'm not afraid of anything. What were you going to write about Williams?
completion: Oh, nothing much. Just that the state had proved he was sane -- and he admits it himself. If you don't want me to run it --

prompt: I gave strict orders that nobody was to interview Williams without my permission.
completion: All right, then, I'll just run the story that Sheriff Hartman is afraid to let reporters interview his prisoner. Of course, with election coming, that might do you a lot of harm, but just as you say.

prompt: Where he used to live. You can catch the Riot Squad -- it's just going out.
completion: Same way you did.  Through that gate.

prompt: Howard Shenken, the Sheriff's uncle on his mother's side --
completion: Where is he?

prompt: The names are Merwyn D. Mayor, who is the Mayor's brother-in-law --
completion: After all I've done for you --

prompt: Four of Mr. Hartman's Deputy Sheriffs were rushed to the hospital --
completion: A fine fair-weather friend you are!

prompt: This tear bomb went off unexpectedly in the hands of Sheriff Hartman's Bombing Squad.
completion: What went off?

prompt: That's good, because my health ain't what it used to be.
completion: If the Mayor wants me, he knows where I am.

prompt: No, I couldn't do that.
completion: Just one second --

prompt: Yeah. But I --
completion: Well, wait a minute, will you? I'm in conference.

prompt: Earl Williams. The reprieve.
completion: Read it! Insane, he says.  He knows very well that Williams ain't insane!

prompt: You're certainly a hard fellow to find, Sheriff.
completion: For who?

prompt: So do you what, you hoodoo!  And now, Mr. Pinkus, if you'll come with us, we'll take you over to the Warden's office and deliver this reprieve.
completion: I'm Sheriff Hartman. You want me?

prompt: I was only doing my duty. Nothing personal in it.
completion: And so do I!

prompt: I was just going to!
completion: Walter, I can't tell you how badly I feel about this. There was no excuse for Hartwell to fly off the handle.

prompt: I never saw him before!
completion: Take those handcuffs off our friends, Pete. That wasn't at all necessary.

prompt: It's a frame-up! Some imposter!
completion: That's a lie!!

prompt: Throw him out, Frank.
completion: You drunken idiot! Arrest him! The idea of coming here with a cock-and- bull story like that!

prompt: Well! Looks like about ten years apiece for you birds!
completion: Who is this man?

prompt: A sight for sore eyes!
completion: Aiding an escaped criminal! And a little charge of kidnapping I'm looking into.  But that's the jail! There must be somebody there!

prompt: Fine work, Pete! You certainly delivered the goods. I'm proud of you.
completion: Look kind o' natural, don't they, Fred?

prompt: Now take that guilty look off your face, Pete -- and stop trembling like a horse.
completion: If we didn't have election Tuesday I'd have this on my conscience.

prompt: Nobody reprieved that policeman he murdered. Now, do as I tell you.
completion: Hello, Olsen... Listen...  Shoot to kill... That's the orders pass the word along... No! We dont want him! And listen, Olsen, five- hundred bucks for the guy that does the job... Yes, I'll be right out there.  Well, I hope that's the right thing to do.

prompt: Shoot to kill, I said.
completion: I don't know, Fred. There's that reprieve if they ever find out.

prompt: All right. Tell 'em to shoot to kill.
completion: What?

prompt: We'll fix that, too.
completion: Just -- one -- second!

prompt: Hold your horses -- will you, Olsen? Hurry up, Fred!
completion: Now what do you say?

prompt: No -- don't out me off.
completion: How would you like to have a job for three hundred and fifty dollars a month. That's almost a hundred dollars a week!

prompt: I did.  Hold the wire.
completion: Cover up that transmitter!

prompt: They got him!  Wait a minute -- hold the wire.  They got Earl Williams surrounded -- the Riot Squad has -- in his house.
completion: Tell 'em to hold the wire.

prompt: Sssh. Wait, Fred.  What?... Where?... Where? Holy Moses!
completion: What is it?

prompt: Ah, Fred --  Hello... this is Hartman --
completion: And you can tell 'em as an afterthought that I want your resignation now!

prompt: We got to think fast before those lying reporters get hold of this. What'll we tell 'em?
completion: Tell 'em the party is through in this State on account of you.

prompt: An attempt to ruin us!
completion: Dementia praecox Oh-h-h!

prompt: And you fell for it, Pete. It frightens me what I'd like to do to you.  Who else knows about this?
completion: Pure politics!

prompt: But we're going to hang him, Fred. He can't get away.
completion: The Governor gave me his word of honor he wouldn't interfere. Two days ago!

prompt: Well, there's a lot of Communistic sympathizers around --
completion: I know it! But they've got nothing to do with this case! Do you realize there are two hundred thousand votes at stake and unless we hang Earl Williams we're going to lose 'em?

prompt: We're up against a lot more than that with that nutty slogan you invented: 'Reform the Reds With a Rope'.
completion: Williams ain't a Red, and you know it!

prompt: If there was any way out...
completion: That gives you an idea of what I'm up against!

prompt: I wish you wouldn't talk like that, Pete.
completion: Our families, Fred. I've always looked on Bessie as my own sister.

prompt: Now, Pete! Please don't appeal to my Sentimental side.
completion: Fred, I don't know what to say. A thing like this almost destroys a man's faith in human nature.

prompt: I mean I'm scratching your name off the ticket Tuesday and running Czernecki in your place. It's nothing personal. And, Pete -- it's the only way out. It's a sacrifice we all ought to be glad to make.
completion: Fred!

prompt: Pete, you're through!
completion: What do you mean -- through?

prompt: Twelve dollars! -- For those rheumatic uncles of yours?  Out shooting everybody they see for the fun of it?
completion: If you're talking about my brother- in-law, he's worked for the city fifteen years.

prompt: Four hundred! Do you want to bankrupt this administration?
completion: I'm getting them for twelve dollars a night.

prompt: Pete, I've got a mighty unpleasant task to perf --
completion: Now, listen, Fred. Just give me a few hours before you make any decisions. I'll get results. I'm doing everything humanly possible. I've just sworn in four hundred deputies.

prompt: Did you actually give Williams that gun?
completion: The professor asked me for it -- I thought it was for something scientific!

prompt: Pete, I want to talk to you!
completion: I ain't got time, Fred, honest. I'll see you after.

prompt: Got you, Williams!
completion: Go on -- shoot me!

prompt: I hope you're pretty nearly through with me, Doctor, I'm getting a little fatigued.
completion: Yeah, you don't want to tire him out, Doctor.

prompt: I won't.
completion: Hildy, how'd you like a couple of tickets for the hanging?

prompt: Fine, thanks, Sheriff.
completion: That's good, Earl. Oh, they've got another alienist to see you. He ought to be here any minute. Don't go to sleep, will you?

prompt: You'll take fifty and like it!
completion: Well, all right. But I'm liable to get into a jam.

prompt: You can let him out on bail, can't you?
completion: Five hundred dollars.

prompt: All right. You can't. But tomorrow the Post will run the story of that roulette game on 43rd Street that your brother-in-law runs. And we'll print that you get five hundred a month for forgetting about it!
completion: Now, Hildy, don't be hasty! I can't let him out.

prompt: Don't Hildy me! Are you going to let him out?
completion: I can't.

prompt: And who accused him? Diamond Louis! One of the worst crooks in town! Why don't you arrest Louis instead of innocent people that he frames?
completion: Now, Hildy --

prompt: Let him out of here, Lieutenant.
completion: But, Hildy, I can't. He's accused of stealing a watch. And they found the watch on him.

prompt: Nobody's going to rush me into anything!  You keep away from me!
completion: All right, Judge.

prompt: -- You were with her. You were in the cab, weren't you?
completion: Was I? The driver got knocked cold.

prompt: What did you do with her?
completion: Search me! When I come to I was running down Thirty-fifth Street.

prompt: Oh-h-h... was she hurt?
completion: I'm telling you. Can you imagine bumping into a load of cops?! They come rollin' out like oranges!

prompt: I'm telling you!
completion: We run smack into a police patrol. You know what I mean? We broke it in half!

prompt: My name is Louis Peluso.
completion: Where's the old lady?

prompt: Editorials?
completion: Wait a minute, Walter. You can't do that!

prompt: I'll go right after it.
completion: Oh, I ain't doing that any more. I'm retired. I'm one of you fellas now -- a newspaper man.

prompt: Give me that!
completion: There goes another scrub lady.

prompt: Who is it?
completion: Oh, some insurance man. Are you in?

prompt: Gentlemen of the Press! Always picking on somebody who can't defend himself -- the littler the better.
completion: Phone for you, Hildy.

prompt: Any news?
completion: Yeah. I was never so tired in my life.

prompt: Hello, Mr. Burns. Yes, she's still here.
completion: I'll take it.  What's the matter, Mr. Burns -- don't you understand English? -- Why, your language is shocking, Mr. Burns -- positively shocking! I don't mind because I was married to you and know what to expect, but suppose Central is listening in... Oh, did you hear that, Central? We ought to report him, don't you think?... Oh, fooey on you!

prompt: Well, Hildy, we were only saying that a swell reporter like you wouldn't give this up so easily.
completion: This is Hildy Johnson...  Oh, I can give it up all right. Without a single quiver. I'm going to live like a human being -- not like you rats.  Oh, is that you, Walter dear? Oh, I didn't mean "dear." That was just habit, I guess. Oh, be yourself, Walter. I've got some news for you... Yes, I got the interview, but I've got some news that's more important.

prompt: What's the matter? Getting yellow?
completion: It's getting so a girl can't step out of the room without being discussed by a bunch of old ladies.  Hello, Post... Mr. Walter Burns, please.

prompt: What's the use of fighting, Hildy?
completion: Well, anyhow, I won't be covering stuff like this any more.

prompt: What's the matter with you boys? Afraid it might rain? If you want to go, I'll cover this end.
completion: Look out, you --

prompt: Okay, Hildy.  Well, we can't get any official statement --
completion: Okay.  Forget it.

prompt: No -- what?
completion: If Walter Burns calls, hold the wire for me, will you? I'll be right back.

prompt: I thought so, too.
completion: Did you get that, Hildy?

prompt: I made it up just now, and who's asking you?  I know it's silly, honey, but do it for me, won't you?... Yes, right now.
completion: Hello, Hildy. I thought you were gone.

prompt: But, Bruce, don't keep it in your wallet!... Well, you see --  -- there's an old newspaper superstition that the first big check you get you -- you put in the lining of your hat. That brings you good luck for ten years.
completion: Say, I've been a reporter twenty years and never heard any hooey like that. Where'd you get it?

prompt: Nothing doing. I'm playing for keeps.
completion: Certified, eh? Who is it -- your milkman?

prompt: I don't know why you boys are so good to me.
completion: Your poker's improved a lot, Hildy. Lend me two bucks, will you?

prompt: You fight it cut.
completion: And up a dime.

prompt: No -- and you don't know that your cheap boss has had Mr. Baldwin arrested again -- do you?
completion: What -- already? Why, the dame left only a minute before I did!

prompt: You know it is!
completion: I didn't frisk him. He must have dropped it in Burns' office. I didn't know whose it was.

prompt: None of that innocent stuff, you double-crossing hyena! You stuck Bruce Baldwin in jail this afternoon on a phony charge that he swiped your watch, and you frisked his wallet! Now, give me that wallet or I'll stick you in jail and it won't be on any phony charge either! It'll be for life!
completion: Now don't get excited, Hildy! I don't know what you're talking about -- but is this Mr. Baldwin's wallet?

prompt: So long, nothing! Where's Bruce Baldwin's wallet?
completion: Huh?

prompt: Here!
completion: Thanks. So long, Hildy!

prompt: Where's the money?
completion: Keep your shirt on. I got it -- right here.  One hundred -- two hundred -- three hundred -- four hundred -- and fifty. Now sign.

prompt: Come on with that money!
completion: First you got to sign a receipt.

prompt: Four hundred and fifty and I'll cut your throat if you try any tricks!
completion: All right, all right. You can't blame a guy for tryin', can you?

prompt: Have you got my dough?
completion: Oh, sure. The boss sent me over with it. Four hundred dollars, wasn't it?

prompt: Hiding him where?
completion: Mother!

prompt: Well -- I was going, but Mollie fainted away and I thought I ought to do what I could.
completion: Some Hallowe'en goin' on outside. The whole police force standing on it's ear.

prompt: From all I can get the Sheriff let him out so's he could vote for him.
completion: Hildy, I thought you were gone --

prompt: 'Kings and sixes The pot affixes'... Poetry. I learned that at my grandma's knee.
completion: Any dope yet on how he got out?

prompt: Kings and sixes.
completion: That's good.

prompt: That man there!
completion: Mother! Oh, I'm so glad to see you! Are you all right? Tell me.

prompt: I'm quoting my son, and he has never lied to me.
completion: Mother!

prompt: You don't have to go with me at all! Just give me my son's money and you can stay here forever as far as I'm concerned. Stay with that murderer you caught!
completion: I don't know what she's talking about. I never said any such thing.

prompt: Don't you mother me! Playing cat-and- mouse with my poor boy! Keeping him looked up -- making us miss two trains -- and supposed to be married tomorrow!
completion: Mother, I can explain everything. I'll go with you in five minutes and --

prompt: We'll get you out in ten minutes.
completion: Mother!

prompt: Let 'em take me. It's better that way.
completion: What good'll it do?

prompt: Down the drainpipe. I didn't mean to shoot him. You believe me, don't you, Mollie?
completion: Stop screaming, Mollie or we're sunk. I'm trying to think of something before those reporters get back.

prompt: Don't cry, Mollie, there's nothing to cry about.
completion: How'd you get here, Earl?

prompt: Sure I do, Earl.
completion: Quiet, Mollie, quiet!

prompt: Don't talk too loud.
completion: Wakin' me up in the middle of the night -- talkin' to me about things they don't understand. Callin' me a Bolshevik. I'm an anarchist. It's got nothin' to do with bombs. It's the philosophy that guarantees every man freedom. You see that, don't you?

prompt: Oh, I'm awful tired. I couldn't go through another day like this.
completion: Well, maybe you think I could!

prompt: Keep away!
completion: Earl, you must never do that again.

prompt: What's that? Only -- you're getting too near. I don't trust anybody.
completion: I don't blame you, Earl.  If I were in your place I wouldn't trust anybody, either.

prompt: No, no, you're right. I don't want to kill anybody. All I want to do is be let alone.
completion: Earl, there's just one thing I ought to clear up for the interview.

prompt: Maybe you're my friend and maybe you're not -- but don't come any nearer. You can't trust anybody in this crazy world. Say, I'll bet I could shoot you from here.
completion: Sure you could, Earl -- but you wouldn't want to do that, would you? You wouldn't want to kill anybody.

prompt: Earl, you don't want to hurt your friends, do you?
completion: Don't move!

prompt: You're not going to shoot me, Earl. I'm your friend, remember? I've got to write that story about your "Production for Use".
completion: Yes -- that's right. Production for use.

prompt: You're not going to phone anybody where I am.
completion: Put down that gun, Earl.

prompt: Don't forget about production for use.
completion: I won't, Earl.

prompt: "Production for use only." Well, maybe that's the answer.
completion: It's the only answer. Everything has a use and if we let it be used for its purpose, we could solve all our problems. Food was meant to be eaten, not stored away in restaurants while poor people starved; clothing was meant to be worn, not piled up in stores while people went naked. Doesn't that make sense?

prompt: What are your beliefs, Earl?

Williams has read the papers, thinks the cop is going to kill him and shoots first. That is all.
